questions.text: A 58-year-old lady with a previous history of breast conservation surgery presents to the OPD with complaints of hardness in the region of the scar. What is the best-suited investigation in this case?
questions.solution:
In a patient with hardness in the region of the BCS scar, MRI must be performed to rule out scar recurrence. 

MRI  of the breast can be used in the following cases:

  • To detect scar recurrence in women with a history of breast conservative surgery  
  • To assess lobular cancer and high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS)
  • To assess multifocality and multicentricity
  • Women with breasts implants
  • Women with BRCA or other genetic mutations or strong family history.
  • Women with dense breasts or discordant or equivocal findings on mammogram/ultrasonography.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with palpitations and a heart rate of 150/minute. An ECG is done which is shown below. If the blood pressure is normal, what is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Administer IV dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker

questions.solution:
The ECG showing sawtooth flutter waves along with the clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of atrial flutter. The next best step is to administer an intravenous (IV) beta-blocker for rate control as the patient is hemodynamically stable.

The initial management of atrial flutter targets rate control through IV atrioventricular (AV) nodal blocking agents. These include beta-blockers or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (CCB) such as verapamil and diltiazem. Intravenous ibutilide, a class III antiarrhythmic agent can be used for rhythm control.

If the patient presents with severe symptoms or is hemodynamically unstable, electrical cardioversion is the first step. If the episode duration is > 48 hours, or if the patient has an increased risk of thromboembolic stroke based on the CHAD2DS2 -VASc scoring system, anticoagulation must be provided before the cardioversion. The drugs which can be used are direct oral anticoagulants (DOAC) such as apixaban, edoxaban, and rivaroxaban. Dabigatran, an antithrombin inhibitor, and warfarin, a vitamin K antagonist can also be used. 

The first episode does not warrant the continuation of antiarrhythmic drugs after conversion to sinus rhythm. In recurrent episodes, sotalol or amiodarone may be used.

At least 4 weeks of anticoagulation therapy is carried out after electrical or chemical cardioversion, as done in atrial fibrillation. Patients with risk factors for thromboembolism should continue it for longer. The definitive treatment is catheter ablation for recurrent cases.

The ECG shows characteristic sawtooth flutter waves due to the atrial activity in the inferior leads ( leads II, III, and aVF). Positive P waves are seen in lead V1. Conduction of more than 230 impulses/ minute through the AV node is not possible in adults. Hence a 2:1 or greater AV block is almost always associated. So patients present with tachycardia of 130-150 beats/minute. Typically, the atrial rate is around 240-300/minute.

Atrial flutter is more commonly seen in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease or structural heart disease. Symptoms include palpitations, dizziness, and fatigue.

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with narrow QRS complex:

  • Narrow QRS with regular RR interval
   Tachycardia                ECG features
Sinus tachycardia Normal P wave, normal ECG features except for the rate
Focal atrial tachycardia A single type of abnormal p wave morphology is seen
Junctional tachycardia No p waves. Heart rate is 100- 200/ min
AV nodal reentry tachycardia No p waves. Pseudo R' waves may be seen. Heart rate is 150-250/ min
Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia P wave always follows QRS. RP interval< PR interval
Atrial flutter Sawtooth shaped flutter waves are seen

 

  • Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval
     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with wide QRS complex:

  • Antidromic AVRT (atrioventricular reentry tachycardia)
  • Supraventricular tachycardias with bundle branch block

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of the active principle of this plant?

choices.text: Inhibiting the muscarinic effects of acetylcholine

questions.solution:
The plant in the image is Digitalis purpurea. The active principle digitonin acts by inhibiting the sodium/potassium ATPase pump. 

Digitalis purpurea contains digitoxin, digitalin, digitonin, and digoxin. It can cause cardiac dysrhythmia in acute toxicity. 

Digitalis purpurea is also known as 'foxglove'. Digitalis contains digitoxin, digitalin, digitonin, and digoxin that act by inhibiting the sodium/potassium ATPase pump. It can cause early GI symptoms followed by cardiac dysrhythmia in acute toxicity resembling that of digoxin.

Option A: Opiates act by activating receptors that are normally occupied by endorphins.

Option B: The active principle of Atropa belladonna is 1-hyoscyamine. It acts by inhibiting the muscarinic effects of acetylcholine.

Option C: The poisonous component of Ricinus communis is toxalbumin ricin. It is a glycoprotein that blocks protein synthesis.

Related Pearl: Plant poisons

Datura stramonium (Jimsonweed) : Flower and fruit are poisonous

Ricinus communis : Seed is poisonous

Digitalis purpurea 

Atropa belladonna

Calotropis gigantea

questions.text:
Arrange the following corticosteroids in the order of increasing t1/2.
  1. Dexamethasone
  2. Hydrocortisone
  3. Methylprednisolone
  4. Prednisolone
questions.solution:
Corticosteroids in the order of increasing t1/2: 

Hydrocortisone→Prednisolone= Methylprednisolone→Dexamethasone

1. Hydrocortisone t1/2- 8 to 12 hours
2. Prednisolone= Methylprednisolone t1/2- 12 to 36 hours
3. Dexamethasone t1/2- 36 to 72 hours.
 
Hydrocortisone is extensively metabolized in the liver during its first pass through the body, resulting in a low oral-to-parenteral activity ratio. However, synthetic corticosteroids have a high oral bioavailability. Approximately 90% of hydrocortisone binds to plasma proteins, mainly a specific protein called cortisol-binding globulin (CBG or transcortin), as well as albumin. The liver's microsomal enzymes primarily metabolize corticosteroids, and these metabolites are further conjugated with glucuronic acid or sulfate before being excreted in the urine. Synthetic derivatives of corticosteroids are more resistant to metabolism and have longer-lasting effects.

Related Pearl: Classification of Glucocorticoids

Short-acting (t1/2 < 12 hours)

  • Hydrocortisone

Intermediate-acting (t1/2 of 12-36 hours)

  • Prednisolone
  • Methylprednisolone
  • Triamcinolone
  • Deflazacort

Long-acting (t1/2 > 36 hours)

  • Dexamethasone
  • Betamethasone

questions.text: A 39-year-old man, who is a chronic alcoholic, presented with complaints of abdominal distension, yellowish discoloration of eyes, and dark-colored urine for the past 6 months.  After a detailed workup, he is diagnosed with early-stage hepatocellular carcinoma in the left lobe and is scheduled for left hemi-hepatectomy. Which of the following segments has to be removed in the patient?

choices.text: II, III, IV, V, and VI

questions.solution:
In left hemi-hepatectomy (also called left hepatectomy), the segments marked as II, III, and IV should be removed. 

Cantlie’s line or main portal fissure extends from the midpoint of the gallbladder fossa at the inferior margin of the liver to the midpoint of the inferior vena cava. It divides the liver into the right and left hemiliver. It contains the middle hepatic vein. The liver has 3 major fissures and 3 minor fissures.

Couinaud classification is the commonly used classification of the liver. It divides the liver into eight segments. It is based on the distribution of portal venous branches in the liver parenchyma. Each segment has its own vascular supply, biliary drainage, and lymphatic drainage. Segment I corresponds to the liver's caudate lobe, and segment IV corresponds to the quadrate lobe of the liver. 

The Couinaud's liver segments are as follows:

Segments removed in various liver surgeries:

  • Right hepatectomy or right hemi-hepatectomy - V, VI, VII, VIII
  • Right tri-sectionectomy or extended right hepatectomy - IV, V, VI, VII, VIII
  • Left hepatectomy or left hemi-hepatectomy - II, III, and IV
  • Left tri-sectionectomy or extended left hepatectomy - II, III, IV, V, and VIII
  • Left lateral sectionectomy or bi-segmentectomy - II and III
  • Right posterior sectionectomy - VI, VII
  • Caudate lobectomy or segmentectomy - I

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

Other segments:

Liver sections

Couinaud's Segments

Right anterior sections

Segments V,VIII

Right Posterior sections

Segments VI, VII

Left medial sections

Segment IV (quadrate lobe)

Left lateral sections

Segment II, III

questions.text: Which of the following formula would you use for measuring the estimated fetal weight in a pregnant woman with fetal head at station +2?

choices.text: [Height of uterus above pubic symphysis (in cm)-9] x 155 in grams
[Height of uterus above pubic symphysis (in cm)-10] x 155 in grams
[Height of uterus above pubic symphysis (in cm)-11] x 155 in grams
[Height of uterus above pubic symphysis (in cm)-12] x 155 in grams

questions.solution:
The fetal weight can be measured by Johnson's formula which is [Height of uterus above pubic symphysis (in cm)-11] x 155 in grams for a fetus which is at station +2 (below the level of ischial spine). 

Estimation of fetal weight:

  • Johnson’s formula: This is only applicable in vertex presentation.
    • If station of head is below the level of the ischial spine: [Height of uterus above pubic symphysis (in cm)-11] x 155 in grams
    • If station of head is above the level of the ischial spine: [Height of uterus above pubic symphysis (in cm)-12] x 155 in grams (Option D)
  • Sonography: Fetal weight has been estimated by combining a number of biometric data, e.g. biparietal diameter (BPD), head circumference (HC), abdominal circumference (AC) and femur length (FL), using the following formulae:
    • Shepard’s formula
    • Hadlock’s formula.

questions.text: The rate and extent of bioavailability of the active ingredient in two preparations of a drug are not significantly different under suitable and identical test conditions. This is known as_____
questions.solution:
The rate and extent of bioavailability of the active ingredient in two preparations of a drug being not significantly different under suitable and identical test conditions is known as bioequivalence.

Pharmaceutically equivalent drug products contain the same active ingredients and are identical in strength or concentration, dosage form, and route of administration.

Two pharmaceutically equivalent drug products would be considered bioequivalent if the rates and extents of bioavailability of the active ingredient in the two products are not significantly different under suitable and identical test conditions.

A generic equivalent is a generic drug that contains the same active ingredient as the brand name drug. The drug lisinopril, for example, is the generic equivalent of brands Zestril® and Prinivil®. The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) thoroughly reviews generic equivalent drugs and requires them to be the same in safety and effectiveness as their brand-name counterparts.

Pharmaceutical alternatives are drug products that contain the identical therapeutic moiety, or its precursor, but not necessarily in the same amount or dosage form, or the same salt or ester. e.g., tetracycline hydrochloride, 250 mg capsules vs. tetracycline phosphate complex, 250 mg capsules

questions.text: An HIV-positive mother on ART is in her first trimester. She undergoes screening for Down's syndrome. Which of the following markers of Down's syndrome is affected?
questions.solution:
β-hCG levels are affected in an HIV-positive mother on ART. 

Maternal levels of free β-hCG in treated HIV-positive pregnant women are lower than those in non-treated HIV-positive and HIV-negative women, whereas the PAPP-A levels and fetal nuchal translucency remain unaltered.

MSAFP is used as a screening test in the 2nd trimester as part of triple test and quadruple test.

  Trisomy 21 Trisomy 18 Neural tube defect or abdominal wall defect
MSAFP Low Low High
Unconjugated estriol Low Low Normal
β hCG High  Low Normal
Inhibin A High

Normal /Low

 Normal

Various antenatal screening tests for aneuploidy are as follows:

Dual test (1st trimester) Triple test (2nd trimester) Quadruple test
(2nd trimester)

1. Beta HCG 

2. PAPPA (Pregnancy-associated plasma protein A)

This can be combined with nuchal translucency by USG

1. Beta HCG 

2. Unconjugated estriol

2. Unconjugated estriol

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of frequent episodes of dysphagia and postprandial chest pain. Her barium study is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario history of dysphagia and postprandial chest pain with a barium study showing a protrusion of a portion of the stomach through the esophageal hiatus of the diaphragm is suggestive of a hiatus hernia.

Hiatus hernia is the protrusion of any abdominal structure other than the esophagus into the thoracic cavity through a widening of the hiatus of the diaphragm.

Types of hiatus hernia:

Type 1 or sliding hernia - gastroesophageal junction migrates into the thoracic cavity. The length of the intraabdominal esophagus is reduced leading to GERD.

Type 2 or rolling hiatus hernia - gastroesophageal junction is normal in position but a portion of the stomach migrates into the thoracic cavity. The length of the intraabdominal esophagus remains the same in a true rolling hiatus hernia. Clinical features include dysphagia and chest pain. In severe cases, it can cause obstruction, strangulation, ischemia, perforation, and compression of the lungs, leading to impaired lung function.

Type 3 or mixed hiatus hernia - a combination of sliding and rolling hiatus hernia.

Type 4 hiatus hernia - other contents of GIT herniates into the thoracic cavity. Ex:- Colon.

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect. 

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with dysmenorrhoea, menorrhagia, and infertility. After ruling out other possible causes, the gynecologist suspects endometriosis. Which of the following investigations will be most helpful in the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the investigation that will be most helpful in the diagnosis is laparoscopy.

Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus. The patient usually presents with symptoms of abdominal pain, dyspareunia, dysmenorrhea, and infertility. The presence of puckered spots in the posterior fornix is pathognomonic of endometriosis. It is an estrogen-dependent disease of the childbearing age group. The most common site of occurrence is the ovary, followed by the pouch of Douglas.

The gold standard for the diagnosis of endometriosis is visual inspection by laparoscopy, preferably with histological confirmation. Typically, there are small black dots, the so-called powder burns/tattooing seen on the uterosacral ligaments and pouch of Douglas. 

Role of laparoscopy in endometriosis:

  • To detect and diagnose pelvic endometriosis.
  • Locate the site of endometriosis and staging.
  • To take biopsy
  • To surgically treat endometriosis by ablation, removal.

Other investigations:

  • CA-125 levels are raised in endometriosis.
  • Monocyte chemotactic protein (MCP-1) levels are raised in the peritoneal fluid of women with endometriosis.
  • Transvaginal ultrasound reveals an echo-free cyst, low level echoes or clumps of high-density level echoes representing clots.

The image below shows powder burns/tattooing appearance of endometriosis on diagnostic laparoscopy.

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: A woman brings her husband to the psychiatry OPD for evaluation. She says that while watching the news, her husband insists that the news reporter is talking about him and there is a hidden message in the news specifically meant for him. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is the delusion of reference.

In the given scenario, the husband firmly believes that the news reporter is talking about him and there is a hidden message in the news for him. Hence, this is a case of delusion of reference.

Delusions are firm, false beliefs that are held despite objective and obvious contradictory proof. Other members of the culture do not share this belief. Patients with delusional disorders usually have non-bizarre delusions, i.e. situations that can happen in real life, such as making an important discovery (grandeur), having an unfaithful partner (Othello syndrome), etc. This should be differentiated from schizophrenia, where patients have bizarre delusions, such as aliens controlling them or having weird creatures around them, etc.

Risk factors for delusional disorders:

  • Increasing age
  • Sensory impairment or isolation
  • Personality features (e.g.unusual interpersonal sensitivity)
  • Positive family history
  • Isolated socially
  • Recent immigration

DSM-5 criteria for diagnosis of delusional disorder:

  • The presence of one (or more) delusions with a duration of 1 month or longer.
  • Criteria for schizophrenia have never been met.
  • Functioning is not markedly impaired, and behaviour is not bizarre or odd.
  • If manic or major depressive episodes have occurred, these have been brief relative to the duration of the delusional periods.
  • Not attributable to substance abuse, another medical condition, or another mental disorder.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

Related Pearl: Psychotic disorders

Differential diagnosis of DSM-5 psychotic disorders

Psychotic disorder

 Criteria for diagnosis
Brief psychotic disorder

Sudden onset and a full return to function

Duration: > 1 day and < 1 month
Schizophreniform disorder

Same symptoms as schizophrenia and functional decline not required

Duration: > 1 month & < 6 months
Schizophrenia

Requires functional decline

At least 6 months (includes at least 1 month of active symptoms, can include prodromal and residual periods)
Schizoaffective disorder

With concurrent mood episode. Active-phase symptoms of schizophrenia with at least a 2 weeks of lifetime history of delusions or hallucinations in absence of prominent mood symptoms
Delusional disorder

One or more delusions for > 1 month

No other psychotic symptoms and normal functioning apart from the direct impact of delusions
Shared psychotic disorder (folie a deux)

Development of delusions in a person who is in a close relationship (ex: spouse, child) with someone who has a delusional disorder (the inducer)

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of pain and swelling in the penis. He provides a history that there was a popping sound during sexual intercourse. On examination, the penis has the appearance given in the image below. What is the management of this condition?

choices.text: Exploration of penis & repair of tunica albuginea

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario history of a sudden pooping sound during sexual intercourse with the image showing eggplant deformity of the penis, which is bruised and bent out of shape is suggestive of a penile fracture. The management of this condition is the surgical repair of the tunica albuginea 

Penile fractures occur when the erect penis is bent suddenly. It leads to the rupture of the tunica albuginea. There is extravasation of blood from within the penis. The patient feels a cracking or popping sound followed by pain and detumescence. On examination, there is bruising and penile hematoma. Investigations include ultrasound and MRI. Management includes early exploration of the penis with surgical repair of the tunica albuginea.

Penile fractures are occasionally associated with urethral injuries. Blood at the urethral meatus may indicate coexisting urethral injury. This should be evaluated with either a retrograde urethrogram or cystoscopy at the time of repair.

Other options

Option B: Nesbitt's procedure is performed for Peyronie's disease.

Option C: Orthoplasty is the procedure performed to correct chordee

Option D: Partial penectomy is done in a case of carcinoma of the penis

questions.text:
Which of the following fetal presentations/positions cannot be delivered vaginally?
  1. Brow presentation
  2. Mentoposterior position
  3. Breech presentation
  4. Occipitoposterior position 
  5. Mentoanterior position
questions.solution:
Brow presentation and mentoposterior position cannot be delivered vaginally.

Vaginal delivery of face presentation is contraindicated if the mentum is lying posteriorly or is in a transverse position. In this position, the diameter of the head is larger than the maternal pelvis, and it cannot descend through the birth canal. 

Persistent brow presentation is a contraindication for vaginal delivery unless the fetus is significantly small or the maternal pelvis is large.

Definitions of various terminologies used for the fetus in utero:

  • Lie: Relationship of the long axis of the fetus to the long axis of the maternal spine
  • Presentation: Part of the fetus occupying the lower pole of the pelvis
  • Presenting part: Part of the presentation that overlies the internal os
  • Attitude: The relation of the different parts of the fetus to one another
  • Position: Relation of the denominator to the different quadrants of the pelvis
Presentation Denominator
Breech Sacrum
Vertex Occiput
Face Mentum (chin)
Brow Frontal eminence
Shoulder Acromion

 

Diameters Measurement in cm (inches) The attitude of the head Presentation
Suboccipitobregmatic 9.5 cm Complete flexion Vertex
Suboccipito-frontal 10 cm Incomplete flexion Vertex
Occipitofrontal 11.5 cm Marked deflexion Vertex
Mento-vertical 14 cm Partial extension Brow
Submentovertical 11.5 cm Incomplete extension Face
Submentobregmatic 9.5 cm Complete extension Face

questions.text: Given below are anti-obesity medications and their mechanism of action. Which of the following pair is incorrectly matched?
questions.solution:
Liraglutide is a GLP-1 agonist used in the treatment of obesity.

Antiobesity medications can be considered in patients with a BMI of ≥30, or a BMI of ≥27 with comorbidities related to weight. The patients should be counseled that the medications should be viewed as an additional measure rather than a replacement for a healthy diet and exercise. 

The drugs that are currently approved for the management of obesity include:

  • Phentermine: adrenergic agonist
  • Orlistat: inhibitor of intestinal lipase; reduces dietary fat absorption
  • Phentermine plus topiramate: adrenergic agonism and appetite suppression
  • Naltrexone plus bupropion: reduction of appetite and food cravings
  • Liraglutide, semaglutide: GLP-1 agonists

questions.text:
A newborn baby is brought with jaundice. Further evaluation leads to a diagnosis of Crigler-Najjar syndrome type-I. Which of the following defects of bilirubin metabolism is responsible for this condition?

UDP-GT - Uridine diphosphate glucuronyl transferase

MRP- Multiple drug-resistant protein-2
questions.solution:
Crigler-Najjar syndrome type-I is due to the absence of UDP-GT activity.

Crigler Najjar type 1 Crigler Najjar type 2

Autosomal recessive

Autosomal recessive > dominant

Complete absence of UDPG-T activity.

 Decreased UDPG-T activity 
 

Kernicterus in >50% 

Kernicterus is usually not seen. 
Requires exchange transfusion and no effect on treatment with phenobarbitone. Responds to phenobarbitone therapy

Phenobarbitone is used in the treatment of Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 2. The presence of the UDPGT enzyme is crucial for the drug's action. It helps convert unconjugated bilirubin to conjugated form at a faster rate. However, Crigler-Najjar type 1 syndrome has a complete absence of the UDPGT enzyme. Therefore, these patients do not respond to Phenobarbitone.

Gilbert syndrome: Partial deficiency of UDPGT caused by polymorphism. It occurs after puberty. It is not associated with chronic liver disease and no treatment is required. Treatment is usually not warranted.

Dubin Johnson syndrome: Disease results from the absent function of MRP2, encoded by the gene ABCC2. Due to an accumulation of epinephrine metabolite, a black liver is seen on biopsy.

Related Pearl: Hereditary Hyperbilirubinemias

Disorder Inheritance Defects in bilirubin metabolism Clinical course

Unconjugated Hyperbilirubinemia

      

Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I

AR

Absent UGT1A1 activity

Fatal in the neonatal period

Crigler-Najjar syndrome type II

AR

Decreased UGT1A1 activity

Generally mild,

occasional kernicterus

questions.text:
Match the following radiograph images with their views.
  1. Submentovertical view
  2. Caldwell view
  3. Water's view
  4. Towne's view
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pair is 1-c, 2-b, 3-d, 4-a.

Waters' view (also known as the Occipitomental view or nose-chin position) is a radiographic view, where an X-ray beam is angled at 37° to the orbitomeatal line. The rays are passed from behind the head and are perpendicular to the radiographic plate.

  • It is commonly used to get a better view of the maxillary sinuses.

Structures observed:

  • Maxillary sinuses
  • Frontal sinuses
  • Sphenoid sinus (through open mouth)
  • Zygoma
  • Zygomatic arch
  • Nasal bone

Caldwell's view (also known as the occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position) is a radiographic view of the skull, where the X-ray plate is angled at 15° to the orbito-meatal line. The rays pass from behind the head and are perpendicular to the radiographic plate.

  • It is commonly used to get a better view of frontal sinuses.

Structures seen are: 

  • Frontal sinuses 
  • Ethmoid sinuses
  • Maxillary sinuses
  • Frontal process of the zygoma and the zygomatic process of the frontal bone
  • Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure)

The image below shows Caldwell's view 

Towne's view: 

It is taken with the patient in the supine position and lying on his back with the chin often depressed into the neck. The X-ray camera is angled at 30 degrees towards the feet so that the rays enter the head at the level of the hairline.

  • This is usually taken for acoustic neuroma and apical petrositis.
  • Bilateral petrous pyramids are visible in this view and hence can be compared.
Structures seen are:
  • Arcuate eminence and superior semicircular canal.
  • Mastoid antrum.
  • Internal auditory canal.
  • Tympanic cavity.
  • Cochlea.
  • External auditory canal.

The image below shows Towne's view 

Submentovertical view (also known as the basal view or Hirtz view) is taken with vertex near the film and X-ray beam projected at right angles to the film from the submental area.

 Structures seen are:
  • Sphenoid, posterior ethmoid, and maxillary sinuses (seen best in that order).
  • Zygoma.
  • Zygomatic arch.
  • Mandible along with coronoid and condyloid processes.
  • External auditory canal.
  • Middle ear cleft, i.e. mastoid cells, middle ear, and eustachian tube.
  • Internal auditory canal.

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of paranasal sinuses and mastoid

questions.text:
Arrange the following morphological changes of myocardial infarction in sequence.
  1. Collagen deposition
  2. Coagulative necrosis
  3. Relaxation of myofibrils
  4. Granulation tissue formation
  5. Phagocytosis by macrophages
questions.solution:
The correct sequence is as follows: 

3. Relaxation of myofibrils
2. Coagulative necrosis
5. Phagocytosis by macrophages
4. Granulation tissue formation
1. Collagen deposition

Relaxation of myofibrils is the earliest detectable ultrastructural feature of myocardial infarction.

questions.text:
Which cyclin-CDK (cyclin-dependent kinase) combination is essential for the G2 to M phase transition of cell cycle?

G2 - Gap 2
M - Mitotic
questions.solution:
Cyclin B-CDK1 combination is essential for the G2 to M phase transition.

Cell cycle progression is driven by the formation of complexes of proteins called cyclins and associated enzymes known as cyclin-dependent kinases. Cyclins are synthesized only during the cell cycle to regulate the progression of the cell across the phases of the cell cycle, while cyclin-dependent kinases are constitutively present irrespective of the cell cycle.

Cyclins D, E, A, and B appear sequentially during the cell cycle and bind to one or more CDKs.

  1. G1-S transition: Cyclin D-CDK4, cyclin D-CDK6, and cyclin E-CDK2
  2. S-phase: Cyclin A-CDK1 and cyclin A-CDK2
  3. G2-M transition: Cyclin B-CDK1

CDK inhibitors (CDKIs) enforce the cell cycle checkpoints. There are several families of CDKIs:

  • CDKIs that broadly inhibit multiple CDKs: p21, p27, p57
  • CDKIs that inhibit CDK4 and CDK6: p15, p16, p18, and p19

Related Pearl: Cell Cycle Regulators and Associated Cancers

Cell cycle regulator

Proto-oncogene

Mode of activation in tumor

Associated tumor

Cyclins

CCND1 (Cyclin D1)

Translocation

Amplification

Mantle cell lymphoma, multiple myeloma

Breast and esophageal cancers

Cyclin-dependent kinase

CDK4

Amplification or point mutation

Glioblastoma, melanoma, sarcoma

questions.text: A patient with STEMI developed cardiogenic shock, and was treated with thrombolysis. He continues to have systemic hypoperfusion due to low ejection fraction. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Repeat one dose of thrombolytic agent

questions.solution:
In a patient with STEMI and cardiogenic shock, the next step after thrombolysis has been given as a temporizing measure, is coronary angiography and PCI.

The treatment recommendations for patients with MI with cardiogenic shock and without are the same — with just differences in the level of evidence.

In a patient with STEMI, primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) — angioplasty with/without stenting but without prior fibrinolysis — is more effective than fibrinolysis alone in opening the occluded coronary vessel and has better clinical outcomes. In case the patient has presented to a PCI-capable hospital, primary PCI should be done within 90 minutes of the patient presenting.

If the patient has presented to a non-PCI-capable hospital, a fibrinolytic agent is given within 30 minutes of the patient presenting if the anticipated time to PCI is >120 minutes. This time limit includes the time spent in non-PCI-capable hospital and the time taken to transfer the patient to a PCI-capable setup. If the anticipated time to PCI is ≤120 minutes, the patient is directly transferred to PCI-capable hospital without fibrinolysis.

In addition to the above management, the patients are also stated on oxygen (if hypoxemia is present), morphine, aspirin, sublingual nitroglycerine, and beta-blockers. Nitrates should be avoided in patients with suspected right ventricular infarction — hypotension with clear lung fields on auscultation.

In addition, hemodynamic support is provided using inotropic agents and vasopressors. The initial vasopressor of choice is noradrenaline. Dobutamine is given if the patient has borderline low blood pressure and high PCWP. If the patient continues to have hypoperfusion despite revascularization and inotropic support, left ventricular assist devices may be considered. 

Intraaortic balloon pump (option D) is not routinely used for patients with MI and cardiogenic shock. It may provide some benefits in patients with mechanical defects such as mitral regurgitation. There is no role of observation (option C) or repeating a dose of thrombolytic agent (option A) in a patient who requires urgent revascularization.

questions.text: A physician is evaluating for speech abnormalities in a patient with a cerebrovascular accident. During the examination, it is found that the patient is unable to understand the written or spoken words. He speaks fluently, but what he speaks cannot be understood by the doctor and relatives. It also consists of some new words. Repetition is also impaired. Damage to which of the following areas will lead to this clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
The areas marked in the image are:

1- Middle temporal gyrus

2- Inferior frontal gyrus

3- Superior temporal gyrus

4- Superior frontal gyrus

The clinical scenario shows that comprehension and repetition are impaired in the patient while fluency is intact. This is seen in Wernicke’s aphasia. The structure marked as 3 is the Wernicke's area which is the superior temporal gyrus.

Broca's area (Brodmann area 44, 45) is present in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant cerebral hemisphere. A lesion in this area results in Broca's aphasia or motor aphasia. In Broca's aphasia, comprehension of language is intact, and speech fluency, repetition, and naming are impaired.

questions.text: A 47-year-old female patient comes to the clinic for evaluation of constant dribbling of urine. Upon performing the following test, the swab labeled "B" is stained blue. Which of the following procedure is not done to repair this defect?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a case of the vesicovaginal fistula(VVF) which is diagnosed using a methylene blue 3 swab test in which the middle swab is stained with methylene blue. McDonald's procedure is not done to repair VVF. It is done for cervical cerclage during pregnancy. 

Methylene blue - 3 swab test: Here, methylene blue is injected into the bladder via the catheter, and three sterile swabs are placed into the vaginal cavity.  

  • The uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter, seen in the ureterovaginal fistula
  • The middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder, seen in vesicovaginal fistula
  • The lowermost swab gets stained- the leak is from the urethra, seen in the urethrovaginal fistula

Most vesicovaginal fistulae are repaired vaginally. The various surgeries done for the repair of VVF (vesicovaginal fistula) are as follows:

  • Latzko procedure
  • Chasser Moir technique
  • Ureteric implantation

Latzko's procedure: It is done by denudation of vaginal epithelium around fistulous edges, freshening the edges, and approximation of raw surface with absorbable sutures. This technique is suited for post-hysterectomy fistula that is caused by cancer cervix. It can lead to narrowing of the vagina or vaginal atresia.

Chassar Moir technique widely separated the vagina and bladder all around by the flap-splitting method and suturing the bladder and vagina separately into two. It has the advantage of tension-free sutures and avoidance of the superior position of the bladder over the vaginal suture. 

Ureteric implantation is considered in cases with extensive loss of bladder tissue, or repetitive failures to close the fistula. Here ureters are implanted into the sigmoid colon creating an ileal loop bladder, or rectal bladder. The disadvantage of this procedure is the high incidence of ascending infection to the kidneys and the risk of electrolyte imbalance.

Related Pearl: Difference between bladder fistula & ureteric fistula

  Bladder fistula   Ureteric fistula 
Etiology

Obstetric causes:

  • Prolonged obstructed labor
  • Instrumental deliveries
  • Iatrogenic injury during caesarean section or sling operations

Surgical injury during:

  • Abdominal hysterectomy
  • Vaginal hysterectomy
  • Wertheim's hysterectomy
  • Laparoscopic surgeries
  • Caesarean section
Clinical features

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is unable to micturate

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is able to micturate
Methylene blue 3-swab test Middle swab stains with methylene blue   Uppermost swab stains with urine, but not with methylene blue
Intravenous pyelography Normal Hydronephrosis and hydroureter present on the affected side

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman developed fever, malaise and a polymorphic rash during the 3rd month of gestation. The characteristic lesions are shown in the image below. Which of following features will not be seen in the infant born to this infected mother?
questions.solution:
The rash with vesicular lesions on an erythematous base is suggestive of varicella infection (Chickenpox) in the pregnant woman, and blueberry muffin rash is not a feature of congenital varicella syndrome.

Congenital varicella syndrome: Fetal varicella infection occurs if the mother gets infected during the first half of pregnancy. Clinical features include:

  • Cicatrix, a zigzag scarring in a dermatomal distribution
  • Microphthalmia
  • Cataracts
  • Cortical atrophy
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Microcephaly
  • Limb hypoplasia
  • Neurogenic bladder, swallowing dysfunction, and aspiration pneumonia
  • Hydroureter and hydronephrosis

Chickenpox or varicella is caused by the Varicella–zoster virus. Its incubation period is 10 to 21 days. Fever, malaise, anorexia, headache, and occasionally mild abdominal pain may occur 24-48 hr before the rash appears. The rash starts as intensely pruritic, erythematous macules that become papules and finally clear, fluid-filled vesicles. The lesions are polymorphic - simultaneous presence of rashes in various stages of evolution.

It is treated with acyclovir 20 mg/kg/dose for 5 days.

Complications:

  • Cutaneous: Secondary bacterial superinfection of the skin
  • Systemic: Acute cerebella ataxia, encephalitis, pneumonia etc.

Note:

Blueberry muffin rash is seen in congenital rubella syndrome. The rash is shown in the image below. 

 

Related Pearl: Viral infections associated with rash

Viral infection  Rash characteristics 
Chickenpox Appears 1st day of fever, centripetal, pleomorphic, dewdrops on rose petal appearance
Measles Appears on the 4th day over the face and retroauricular origin
Rubella Rash on day 1 over the face

Erythema infectiosum

 Rash on cheeks (slapped cheek appearance), moves to trunk and extremities
Exanthem subitum Macules or maculopapular rash
Infectious mononucleosis Associated with maculopapular rash

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the management of thyroid storm?

choices.text: Give propylthiouracil followed by potassium iodide one hour later
Give potassium iodide followed by propylthiouracil one hour later

questions.solution:
In the management of a patient with thyroid storm, propylthiouracil (PTU) is given first, followed by potassium iodide one hour later. PTU prevents the incorporation of excess iodine into the thyroglobulin and the formation of new thyroid hormones. Potassium iodide blocks the release of thyroid hormones by the Wolff-Chaikoff effect.

Related Pearl: Thyroid storm / Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is an emergency caused by an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. 

Precipitating factors:

  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy
  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Stress
    • Infection
    • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
    • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Acute iodine load
    • Amiodarone administration 
    • Exposure to iodinated contrast agents
    • Following RAI therapy

Clinical features:

  • Fever
  • Tachycardia
  • Altered mentation (delirium, psychosis, coma)
  • GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea)
  • Atrial fibrillation and cardiac failure - most common causes of death

Treatment of thyroid storm:

Treatment modality Effect
IV Fluids, ice packs Rehydration and external cooling
Propylthiouracil
(DOC)

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Propranolol

Block adrenergic effects

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Corticosteroids

Inhibits the release of thyroid hormone from the gland

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Lugol’s iodine/ sodium ipodate Inhibits the release of thyroid hormone from the gland
Digoxin Controls the associated atrial fibrillation
Diuretics and administration of oxygen

To manage cardiac failure

Related Pearl: Radioiodine uptake of thyroid gland

Radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) scans are interpreted as follows:

  • High (or normal) radioiodine uptake indicates de-novo synthesis of the hormone. Therefore, there is increased hormone synthesis
  • Low (nearly absent) radioiodine uptake indicates:
    • Inflammation and destruction of thyroid tissue with release of the preformed hormone into the circulation
    • Extrathyroidal source of thyroid hormone

Conditions with high and low RAIU are given below:

High RAIU Low RAIU
  • Graves’ disease
  • Toxic multinodular goiter
  • Toxic adenoma
  • Thyroid cancer
  • Hydatidiform mole
  • TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma

 

 

 
  • Acute phase of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis
  • Drug-induced— iodine, amiodarone-induced thyroiditis
  • Subacute/ Dequervain thyroiditis
  • Radiation thyroiditis
  • Metastatic follicular thyroid carcinoma
  • Factitious (iatrogenic) thyrotoxicosis
  • Struma ovarii (extrathyroid source)
  • Hamburger thyrotoxicosis (exogenous source)

questions.text: Which of the following antibodies is not implicated in type 1 diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
Anti-gliadin antibodies are present in patients with gluten-sensitive enteropathy.

Islet cell autoantibodies (ICAs) are several antibodies that are directed against pancreatic islet molecules. These include:

  • anti-GAD65 (glutamic acid decarboxylase 65)
  • anti-insulin
  • anti-ZnT-8 (zinc transporter 8)
  • anti-IA2

Most patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus are positive for one of these antibodies, and so their testing is an important diagnostic step in the evaluation of a patient suspected to have the disease. The presence of ICAs also indicates a risk of developing type 1 diabetes mellitus in the future, if the patient does not have the overt disease at the moment. 

However, the ICAs themselves are not responsible for the destruction of beta cells. The beta cell destruction is actually mediated by CD8+ T-cells.

Related Pearl: Comparative Features of Type I and Type II Diabetes mellitus

Type 2 DM

Insulin resistance which later leads to impaired insulin secretion

Adult

No HLA association

Normal / Underweight

Usually strongly positive

Oral hypoglycemics, later insulin

Low

High

 

Clinical Features

Diabetic ketoacidosis is common 

It is associated with other autoimmune diseases like:

Thyroid disorders

  • Addison's disease
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Schmidt syndrome/ Polyglandular failure syndrome

Non-ketotic hyperosmolar coma is common

questions.text:
Choose the correct statements about glucokinase.
  1. Located in β cells of the pancreas and helps in insulin release.
  2. Has a high affinity for glucose.
  3. Is induced by insulin.
  4. Inhibited by glucose-6-phosphate directly.
  5. Mutations in the glucokinase gene can lead to MODY.
questions.solution:
Glucokinase is located in pancreatic β cells and helps in insulin release. It is also stimulated by insulin, leading to increased hepatic uptake of glucose and glycogen synthesis. Mutations in glucokinase can lead to maturity onset diabetes of young (MODY).

The enzyme responsible for glucose phosphorylation in liver and pancreatic β cells (statement 1) is glucokinase. In the liver, its function is to remove glucose from the portal blood during postprandial hyperglycemic state. This limits the amount of glucose available to the peripheral tissues, and enables glycogen synthesis and lipogenesis in the liver. In pancreatic β cells, glucokinase detects the changes in blood glucose levels. If there is more glucose, more glucose-6-phosphate is produced by glucokinase, leading to increased glycolysis and ATP production. Increased ATP leads to the closure of ATP-sensitive potassium channels and insulin release. 

Compared to hexokinase, glucokinase has:

  • High Km — has a lower affinity (statement 2) for glucose, and requires a higher concentration of glucose for its action.
  • High Vmax — has a higher capacity to convert substrate into product.

Glucokinase is inhibited indirectly by fructose-6-phosphate. It is not inhibited by glucose-6-phosphate directly (statement 4), even though it is the end product of the reaction catalyzed by glucokinase. In the presence of fructose-6-phosphate, glucokinase binds tightly to its regulatory protein and is translocated to the nucleus, rendering it inactive. Glucokinase is stimulated by insulin (statement 3).

Mutations in the gene encoding for glucokinase lead to maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY) type 2, in which the patients have impaired insulin secretion and hyperglycemia.

The differences between hexokinase and glucokinase are summarized below:

  Hexokinase Glucokinase
Location  Most tissues except liver and pancreatic cells Liver and pancreatic β cells
Km Lower (Higher affinity) Higher (Lower affinity)
Vmax Lower (Decreased capacity) Higher (Increased capacity)
Induced by insulin No Yes
Inhibited by Glucose-6-phosphate Fructose-6-phosphate

Related Pearl: Steps in Glycogenesis & Respective Enzymes

Steps

Enzymes

Glucose Phosphorylation

Hexokinase in Muscle

Glucokinase in Liver

Glucose-6-PO4 to Glucose-1-PO4 conversion

Phosphoglucomutase

Attachment of UTP to Glucose-1-PO4

UDP Glucose Pyrophosphorylase

Attachment of UDP-Glucose to Glycogen Primer (Glycogenin)

Glycogen initiator synthase

Glycogen synthesis

Glycogen synthase

Glycogen Branches formation

Branching enzyme (amylo-[1—4]—>[1—6]-transglucosidase)

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of vomiting, abdominal distention, and postprandial epigastric pain. She provides a history of recent profound weight loss. A barium meal follow-through of the patient is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the barium follow-through demonstrating dilation of the duodenum with an abrupt cut-off at its third part, coinciding with the line of the superior mesenteric artery is suggestive of superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome/Wilkie syndrome.

Wilkie syndrome is usually seen in young women. It is a rare condition in which the SMA compresses the third portion of the duodenum. The normal aortomesenteric angle is between 25-60 degrees. This is reduced in SMA syndrome. The SMA obstructs the third part of the duodenum by compressing it against fixed retroperitoneal structures.

SMA syndrome is associated with supine immobilization, profound weight loss, scoliosis, and body cast, hence also called cast syndrome. Clinical features include profound nausea and vomiting, abdominal distention, weight loss, and postprandial epigastric pain. Upper gastrointestinal barium studies are used for diagnosis. CT is also useful in some cases.

Management includes:

  • Duodenojejunostomy with the division of the ligament of Treitz is the most common and most successful procedure done.
  • Strong's operation -the division of ligament of Treitz and transposition of the SMA.
  • Anterior transposition of the 3rd part of the duodenum.

The given image shows a compressed angle between SMA and the abdominal aorta in CT angiography.

questions.text:
Which of the following will be seen in primary hyperaldosteronism?
  1. Hyperkalemia
  2. Metabolic alkalosis
  3. Increased serum renin
  4. Resistant hypertension
  5. Low aldosterone renin ratio
questions.solution:
Primary hyperaldosteronism is likely to present with metabolic alkalosis and resistant hypertension.

Patients with primary hyperaldosteronism present with elevated aldosterone levels. This causes sodium retention, expansion of the intracellular volume, and hypertension. This hypertension is resistant to usual drugs and is accompanied by hypokalemia (statement 1) because aldosterone also increases K+ excretion from the kidney. There is also increased H+ excretion from the kidney, leading to metabolic alkalosis.

Because of high aldosterone, serum renin levels are low (statement 3), and serum aldosterone to renin ratio is high (statement 5). 

 

Primary hyperaldosteronism occurs due to excess mineralocorticoid production by adrenal zona glomerulosa. The most common cause for this is bilateral micronodular hyperplasia, but can also occur due to unilateral adrenal adenoma. When primary hyperaldosteronism occurs due to unilateral adrenal adenoma, it is known as Conn's syndrome.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old male patient comes to the clinic with a history of fatigue and dizziness. He also complains of unbearable itching while taking a shower which has been present for many months. Physical examination shows the presence of facial plethora and conjunctival injection. Laboratory examination shows a hemoglobin of 20 g/dL. Choose the right option from those given below with regards to the various parameters shown -
  Plasma Volume RBC Mass O2 Saturation EPO Levels
1. Increased Increased Increased Increased
2. Increased Increased Normal Decreased
3. Increased Decreased Decreased Decreased
4. Decreased Increased Decreased Increased
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of polycythemia vera. This patient has aquagenic pruritus with facial plethora and conjunctival injection which raises the suspicion for increased hematocrit. Plasma volume and RBC mass will be increased, EPO levels will be decreased and O2 saturation will be unchanged.

Polycythemia vera:

  • Polycythemia vera is an acquired myeloproliferative disorder that causes the overproduction of all three hematopoietic cell lines, most prominently the red blood cells.
  • Clinical features:
    • Increased marrow production of red cells, granulocytes, and platelets (panmyelosis)
    • Low erythropoietin levels and elevated hematocrit
    • Blood viscosity and sludging lead to both thrombosis and bleeding.
    • Headache, dizziness, hypertension, dizziness, venous thrombosis (Budd Chiari syndrome due to hepatic vein thrombosis), bowel infarction, and stroke.
    • Intense pruritus especially aquagenic pruritus which is due to the release of histamine from the basophils
    • Peptic ulceration, hyperuricemia
    • 15% to 20% of patients after an average period of 10 years ->Myelofibrosis and extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis,
    • PCV transforms into AML in 2% of patients.
  • According to the WHO 2017 criteria, the hallmark of polycythemia vera is a hematocrit (at sea level) that exceeds 49% in males or 48% in females.
  • Erythroid production is independent of erythropoietin, and the serum erythropoietin level is low. RBC morphology is normal.
  • JAK2 (V617F) mutation has been demonstrated in 95% of cases.
  • Usually elevated white blood count and platelet count. Basophilia and eosinophilia are frequently present.
  • Thrombosis is the most common complication of polycythemia vera and the major cause of morbidity and death in this disorder. 
  • Vitamin B12 levels are strikingly elevated because of increased levels of transcobalamin III (secreted by white blood cells). Overproduction of uric acid may lead to hyperuricemia.
  • Bone marrow is hypercellular with residual fat. There will be an increase in red cell progenitors, granulocytic precursors, and megakaryocytes. There is an increase in reticulin fibers in the initial stages. This is followed by a spent phase where there is extensive fibrosis and intramedullary hematopoiesis. The peripheral smear will show an increased number of basophils and abnormally large platelets. 
  • The treatment of choice is phlebotomy. Hydroxyurea and busulfan have also been used as second line agents. 

Other types of polycythemia:

  • Polycythemia denotes an abnormally high red cell count, usually with a corresponding increase in the hemoglobin
  • level.
  • It may be relative when there is hemoconcentration due to decreased plasma volume, or absolute when there
  • is an increase in the total red cell mass.
  • Relative polycythemia results from dehydration, such as occurs with deprivation of water, prolonged vomiting or diarrhea, or excessive use of diuretics. It is also associated with an obscure condition of unknown etiology called stress polycythemia, or Gaisböck syndrome. Affected individuals are usually hypertensive, obese, and anxious (“stressed”).
  •  Absolute polycythemia is primary when it results from an intrinsic abnormality of hematopoietic precursors and secondary when the red cell progenitors are responding to increased levels of erythropoietin.
  • The most common cause of primary polycythemia is polycythemia vera, a myeloproliferative disorder associated with mutations that lead to erythropoietin-independent growth of red cell progenitors.
  • Much less commonly, primary polycythemia results from familial mutations in the erythropoietin receptor that induce erythropoietin-independent receptor activation.
  • Secondary polycythemia may be caused by compensatory or pathologic increases in erythropoietin secretion. Causes of the latter include erythropoietin-secreting tumors and rare, but illustrative inherited defects that lead to the stabilization of HIF-1α, a hypoxia-induced factor that stimulates the transcription of the erythropoietin gene.

 Peripheral blood smear in Polycythemia vera showing three red blood cell precursors and slight to moderate anisopoikilocytosis. (Wright-Giemsa stain)

Related Pearl: Comparison between Properties of Various Types of Polycythemia

Relative

polycythemia

vera

EPO: Erythropoietin

Related Pearl: WHO Polycythemia Vera Criteria

Major criteria:

1. Hemoglobin >16.5 g/dL in men

     Hemoglobin >16.0 g/dL in women 

Or

     Hematocrit >49% in men

     Hematocrit >48% in women 

2. Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage hyperplasia (panmyelosis) and prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation with pleomorphic mature megakaryocytes in the bone marrow, and 

3. Presence of JAK2 exon 12 mutation

Minor criterion:

Subnormal serum erythropoietin level

Diagnosis of polycythemia vera requires meeting either all 3 major criteria or the first 2 major criteria along with the minor criterion

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with polymyalgia rheumatica?
questions.solution:
Polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) is associated with giant cell arteritis.

PMR is characterized by symmetrical pain and stiffness around the shoulders, neck, torso, and hip girdle. It is worse on waking up in the morning. Because the stiffness involves the proximal parts of the limbs, there can be difficulty in activities of daily living. 

In any patient presenting with PMR, features in history which suggest giant cell arteritis should be sought. These include headache, jaw claudication, scalp tenderness, and any visual changes. Laboratory testing shows elevated ESR and CRP. 

If there are symptoms suggestive of giant cell arteritis, steroids should be started immediately and temporal artery biopsy should be done to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with numerous itchy skin lesions on his chest and back which show characteristic collarette scales. 2 weeks prior to this he had noticed the lesion shown in the image given below on his thigh, which he shows to you on his mobile phone. Identify the lesion.
questions.solution:
The image shows a Herald patch and the subsequent development of lesions with collarette scales is suggestive of pityriasis rosea.

Pityriasis rosea is an acute self-limiting papulosquamous disorder. It is commonly seen in children and young adults.

It begins with a prodrome of a sore throat, gastrointestinal disturbance, fever, or arthralgia. Large and conspicuous eruptions on the thigh, upper arm, trunk, or neck covered by fine scales occur first and are known as Herald patches. After 5-15 days, new eruptions occur as discrete oval lesions, dull pink in color, and are covered by fine dry silvery-grey scales. The secondary lesions occur as macules and papules that are elliptical or ovular, symmetric, and commonly involve the thorax, back, and abdomen. It is followed by a marginal collarette of scale with central wrinkling and atrophy.

The image given below shows collarette scales. The long axes of these lesions characteristically follow the lines of skin tension parallel to the ribs in a Christmas tree pattern on the upper chest and back

Other options:

Option A: A hypopigmented ring surrounding individual psoriatic lesions as shown below is known as the Woronoff ring. It is usually associated with treatment, most commonly UV radiation or topical corticosteroids. The pathogenesis of the Woronoff ring is not well understood but may result from the inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis.

Option B: Halo dermatitis is the occurrence of an eczematous ring surrounding a melanocytic nevus.

Option C: Iris or target lesions are seen in Erythema multiforme. These lesions have three or more zones. A central area of dusky erythema or purpura and an outer ring of erythema is present. The middle paler zone is due to edema.

questions.text: Among the following women with bleeding per vaginum (PV) who are being evaluated, which would be diagnosed as secondary post-partum hemorrhage?

choices.text: A 32 year old woman at 40 weeks gestation in second stage of labour
A 26 year old woman who delivered twins vaginally 6 hours ago
A 29 year old woman who delivered a preterm baby 1 week ago
A 36 year old woman at 32 weeks gestation bleeding PV

questions.solution:
A 29-year-old woman who delivered a preterm baby 1 week ago, now having bleeding per vaginum has secondary post-partum hemorrhage (PPH).

Secondary postpartum hemorrhage is defined as bleeding from or into the genital tract, occurring beyond 24 hours of birth and within the puerperium. 

Causes of secondary PPH include: 

  • Retained bits of placental cotyledons or membranes
  • Infection of deep cervicovaginal laceration and separation of the slough
  • Endometritis and subinvolution of the site of the placenta 
  • Withdrawal bleeding following estrogen therapy for lactation suppression
  • Rare causes - chorionepithelioma, puerperal inversion of the uterus

Other Options:

Options A and D: These women have antepartum hemorrhage. Antepartum hemorrhage is defined as bleeding from or into the genital tract after the 28th week of pregnancy but before the birth of the baby. Therefore a patient in the second stage of labour and a patient with bleeding PV at 32 weeks gestation have antepartum hemorrhage.

Option B: This woman has primary PPH. Bleeding within 24 hours following the birth of the baby. Common causes of primary PPH include atony of the uterus, trauma during labor, retained tissues, and coagulopathies. Primary PPH is of two types:

  • Third stage hemorrhage - bleeding before the expulsion of placenta
  • True post-partum hemorrhage -bleeding after the expulsion of placenta

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who is in her 12th week of gestation was referred to you by an obstetrician for sonographic evaluation. You notice the following sign on USG. You would report as ______
questions.solution:
The image shows the lambda sign or twin peak sign seen in dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy.

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick septum between the two gestational sacs. A triangular projection is seen at the base of the membrane. This is known as lambda or twin peak sign.

Lambda sign:

Note: "T sign" is the sonographic image seen in a monochorionic twin pregnancy. There is a single gestational sac with a thin dividing membrane and two fetuses.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

Related Pearl: Important radiological signs in OBG

Sign
Significance
Bagel sign
Gestational sac in the adnexa with a hyperechoic ring.
USG sign in tubal ectopic.
Ball Sign
X-ray shows a crumpled up spine of the fetus.
Radiological sign of intrauterine fetal death.
Banana Sign
Abnormal anterior curvature of the cerebellum due to the associated Arnold-Chiari malformation.
USG sign in open spina bifida.
Double decidual sac Sign
Two concentric echogenic rings separated by a hyperechoic space.
Normal USG appearance of an intrauterine gestational sac.
Lambda Sign
The chorionic tissue in between the two layers of the membrane between the twins.
USG sign seen in di-chorionic pregnancies.
‘T’ Sign
USG sign seen in monochorionic twins. As the intertwin membrane does not have any chorionic tissue it gives rise to ‘T’ sign in ultrasound.
Bunch of grapes sign
USG appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.
Butterfly sign
Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.
Cloverleaf skull
Seen in craniosynostosis
Empty amnion sign
Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A young man was diagnosed with acute epididymitis. Which of the following is likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
A positive Prehn’s sign is used to differentiate epididymitis from testicular torsion. A Prehn’s sign is said to be positive when the pain gets relieved on lifting the testis as seen in epididymo-orchitis. In the case of torsion, the pain worsens on eliciting this sign.

Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of acute epididymitis in young, sexually active males. In older men (>40 years) with bladder outflow obstruction, epididymitis results from a urinary infection, most commonly due to Escherichia coli.

Acute epididymitis is managed by antibiotics and scrotal support.

Signs seen in torsion of the testis: 

  • Deming’s sign- spasm of the cremaster muscle due to twisting of the spermatic cord causes the affected testis to be positioned higher than the normal testis.
  • Angell’s sign- the testis on the normal side lies horizontally because of the mesorchium between the testis and epididymis.
  • Cremastric reflex- absent on the side of the affected testis

questions.text: A 48-year-old female presented with a neck swelling measuring 2 cm. There was a history of previous radiation exposure to the neck. There were no palpable lymph nodes. Based on the workup, she was diagnosed to have a papillary thyroid carcinoma. What is the ideal surgical management of this patient?
questions.solution:
In this given scenario, the patient has been diagnosed with papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) following radiation exposure to the neck; total thyroidectomy is the ideal surgical management.

Radiation-induced differentiated thyroid cancer (DTC): This patient's history of radiation exposure increases her risk of multifocal and bilateral disease, as well as recurrent disease. In such cases, total thyroidectomy is the recommended approach, irrespective of tumor size, to ensure complete removal of the thyroid tissue and minimize the risk of recurrence. Differentiated thyroid cancers include papillary thyroid cancer, follicular thyroid cancer, and hurtle cell cancer. 

Total thyroidectomy is performed in the following scenarios:

  • Tumors ≥4 cm
  • Gross extrathyroidal extension
  • Evidence of metastatic disease
  • Radiation-induced DTC
  • Familial nonmedullary thyroid cancer
  • Multifocal bilateral DTC

A central neck dissection is performed when level VI lymph nodes are involved. If both level VI and other lymph nodes are enlarged, the surgical approach includes total thyroidectomy, central neck dissection, and modified radical neck dissection. Prophylactic central neck dissection is advised for tumors exceeding 4 cm (classified as T3 and T4).

The TNM staging for differentiated thyroid carcinoma, according to the 8th edition of the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) (2018), is as follows:

1. Primary Tumor (T):

  • TX: Primary tumor cannot be assessed
  • T0: No evidence of primary tumor
  • T1: Tumor ≤2 cm, limited to the thyroidT1a: Tumor ≤1 cm
  • T1b: Tumor >1 cm but ≤2 cm
  • T2: Tumor >2 cm but ≤4 cm, limited to the thyroid
  • T3:
    • T3a: Tumor >4 cm, limited to the thyroid      
    • T3b: Gross extrathyroidal extension invading only strap muscles
  • T4:
    • T4a: Tumor extends beyond the thyroid capsule to invade subcutaneous soft tissues, larynx, trachea, esophagus, or recurrent laryngeal nerve     
    • T4b: Tumor invades prevertebral fascia or encases carotid artery or mediastinal vessels.

2. Regional Lymph Nodes (N):

  • NX: Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed
  • N0: No regional lymph node metastasis
  • N1: Regional lymph node metastasis: 
    • N1a: Metastasis to level VI (pretracheal, paratracheal, and prelaryngeal/Delphian lymph nodes)                 
    • N1b: Metastasis to unilateral, bilateral, or contralateral cervical (levels I, II, III, IV, or V) or retropharyngeal or superior mediastinal lymph nodes (level VII)

3. Distant Metastasis (M):

  • M0: No distant metastasis
  • M1: Distant metastasis present

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine-sufficient areas, among children, and among those exposed to ionizing radiation. It is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia, and dyspnea are associated with local invasion. On the scan, papillary carcinoma usually presents as a cold nodule.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis are lung > liver > bone > brain. It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

Other options:

Option A: Hemithyroidectomy is typically performed for tumors between 1-4 cm without extrathyroidal extension or metastatic disease. 

Option B and D: Subtotal thyroidectomy and near-total thyroidectomy are not typically preferred because they leave residual thyroid tissue, which can complicate follow-up care and monitoring for recurrence.

Related Pearl: AJCC 8th edition Changes in the TNM staging of Thyroid neoplasms:

Differentiated Thyroid Cancer:

  • The age cutoff used for staging is increased from 45 to 55 years of age at diagnosis. 
  • Minor extrathyroidal extension detected only on histological examination is removed from the definition of T3 disease and therefore has no impact on either T category or overall stage.
  • N1 disease no longer upstages a patient to stage III. If < 55 years of age at diagnosis, N1 disease is stage I. If ≥ 55 years of age, N1 disease is stage II.
  • T3a is a new category for tumors > 4 cm confined to the thyroid gland
  • T3b is a new category for tumors of any size demonstrating gross extrathyroidal extension into strap muscles (sternohyoid, sternothyroid, thyrohyoid or omohyoid muscles)
  • Level VII lymph nodes, previously classified as lateral neck lymph nodes (N1b) is re-classified as central neck lymph nodes (N1a) to be more anatomically consistent and because level VII presented significant coding difficulties for tumor registrars, clinicians and researchers.
  • In differentiated thyroid cancer, the presence of distant metastases (M1) in older patients is classified as IVB disease rather than IVC disease. Distant metastasis in anaplastic thyroid cancer continues to be classified as IVC disease.
