T4, Any N, M0
IV C  Any T, Any N, M1  -do-

questions.text: When is the cardiac output maximum in a pregnant woman?
questions.solution:
Cardiac output is maximum immediately following delivery.

The cardiac output starts to increase from the 5th week of pregnancy and reaches a peak at 30-34 weeks, after which it remains static till term. It further increases during labor and reaches maximum immediately following delivery. Cardiac output usually remains elevated for 24 to 48 hours postpartum and declines to non-pregnant values by 10 days.

 

Related Pearl: Cardiovascular changes in pregnancy

  • The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min
  • The apex is moved laterally 
  • Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum period)
  • X-Ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shifted apex)
  • ECG: Slight left axis deviation

Heart sounds:

  • First heart sound: Loud with an exaggerated split
  • Second heart sound: Normal but loud
  • Third heart sound: Loud and easily heard

Murmurs:

  • A systolic murmur that was intensified during inspiration or expiration
  • A soft diastolic murmur (in 20%)
  • Continuous murmur arising from the breast vasculature (in 10%)

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient came to dermatology OPD with the clinical features shown in the image below. The likely diagnosis is ______.
questions.solution:
The given image shows bluish patchy skin lesions on the face in the region of the first and second branches of the trigeminal nerve and sclera which are suggestive of nevus of Ota.

Nevus of Ota is an extensive, bluish, patchy, dermal melanocytosis. A large number of elongated dendritic melanocytes can be seen scattered among collagen bundles mainly of the superficial dermis.

It affects the sclera and the skin adjacent to the eye. Distributed along with the first and the second branches of the trigeminal nerve.

Most lesions are present at birth or develop during the first year of life, increasing in size and number in subsequent years. Lesions are more common in females and in Asians.

Q‐switched laser systems are the first-line treatment, as they achieve higher rates of pigment clearing.

Other options:

Option A- Nevus of Ito appears as a  unilateral, blue‐greyish macular discoloration location in the area innervated by the posterior supraclavicular and lateral cutaneous brachial nerves- acromioclavicular region.

 

Option B- A compound nevus is an acquired melanocytic nevus. It is a slightly raised, oval, or round symmetrical papule. This nevus is also pigmented, with shades of brown according to the skin color of the patient.

 

Option D- Hypomelanosis of Ito refers to the skin abnormalities characterized by unusual unilateral or bilateral cutaneous macular hypopigmented whorls, streaks, and patches, corresponding to the lines of Blaschko. It is often associated with epilepsy and mental retardation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man complains of colicky abdominal pains and frequent bowel movements. Diarrhea associated with tenesmus and heme-positive stool is seen. Colonic epithelium shows the following findings on biopsy. What is the most likely cause of this disease?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features and biopsy is suggestive of amoebiasis caused by Entamoeba histolytica. 

The biopsy shows flask-shaped ulcers typical of amoebiasis.

In amoebiasis, amoeba attach themselves to the colonic epithelium, induces apoptosis, invade crypts, and burrow laterally into the lamina propria. This recruits neutrophils and causes tissue damage, resulting in flask-shaped ulcers with a narrow neck and broad base.

Clinical manifestations:

  • Amebic Colitis
    • Colicky abdominal pains and frequent bowel movements.
    • Diarrhea associated with tenesmus and heme-positive stool.
    • Trophozoites invade the intestinal mucosa, produce flask-shaped ulcers.
  • Amebic Liver Abscess
    • Fever is the hallmark of amebic liver abscess
    • It is associated with abdominal pain, abdominal distention, and enlargement and tenderness of the liver.
    • Changes at the base of the right lung, such as elevation of the diaphragm and atelectasis or effusion, may also occur.
    • The most common finding is a single abscess in the right hepatic lobe, detected on ultrasonography,computed tomography, or magnetic resonance imaging.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant with dysmorphic facies was brought to the clinic with complaints of recurrent bacterial infections of the skin, mouth, and respiratory tract. Interestingly, the baby has a Bombay blood group. Which of the following is likely to be associated with the underlying condition in this infant?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation points towards a diagnosis of leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD)- type 2, which results from defective fucose incorporation. Craniofacial dysmorphism and the Bombay blood group are features unique to LAD-2.

LAD-2 is also known as the congenital disorder of glycosylation II-C. This abnormality prevents the incorporation of fucose into various cell surface glycoproteins, including the carbohydrate structure Sialyl Lewis X, which is critical for the rolling and adhesion of neutrophils to vascular endothelium.

Other options:

Option A- Defective β2 integrin occurs in LAD-1 in which steady adhesion of leukocyte to endothelial surfaces is defective. Some of the characteristics seen in LAD-1 are delayed separation of the umbilical cord, recurrent pyogenic infections with onset in the first week of life, infections caused by Staphylococcus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa, absent pus formation, and periodontitis. 

Option C- Defective kindlin-3 gene, which affects integrin activation cascade, is seen in LAD-3. LAD-3 is characterized by a Glanzmann thrombasthenia-like bleeding disorder, delayed separation of the umbilical cord, and skin and soft tissue infections similar to those seen in LAD-1.

Option D- Defective lysosomal traffic regulator (LYST) gene in chromosome 1 is associated with Chediak-Higashi syndrome (CHS). Patients have light skin and silvery hair. They frequently complain about recurrent infections, photosensitivity, photophobia, infections, and neuropathy. 

Note:

Both LAD and CHS are autosomal recessive disorders. 

Related Pearl: Defects in Leukocyte Function

Disease

Defect

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 1

Mutations in β chain of CD11/CD18 integrins

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 2

Mutations in fucosyltransferase

Chediak–Higashi syndrome

Decreased leukocyte functions because of mutations affecting protein involved in lysosomal membrane traffic (LYST)

Chronic granulomatous disease

Defect in gene encoding phagocyte oxidase

Myeloperoxidase deficiency

Decreased microbial killing because of defective MPO-H2O2 system

questions.text: Which of the following drugs act by reversible inhibition of P2Y12 receptor?
questions.solution:
Ticagrelor is a reversible inhibitor of P2Y12 receptor.

Injury to the vessel wall exposes the subendothelial collagen and causes platelets to adhere and activate at the site. Activated platelets release ADP, which binds to P2Y12 receptors on other platelets in the circulation and causes their activation. This can cause amplifying cycles of clot formation and complete occlusion of the blood vessels. This is especially dangerous in patients with atherosclerotic plaques in the coronary arteries. Any acute plaque change, such as ulceration, can lead to thrombosis and acute coronary syndromes. 

This is where anti-platelet drugs such as P2Y12 inhibitors come in. P2Y12 inhibitors include clopidogrel, prasugrel, ticagrelor and cangrelor. Some of the features of these drugs are summarized below:

Clopidogrel Irreversible P2Y12 antagonist, oral

It is a prodrug; that requires activation by CYP 2C19 to work.

Blocks platelet aggregation for the entire lifetime of platelets

PPIs such as omeprazole and pantoprazole inhibit CYP 2C19, thus reducing the formation of the active metabolite of clopidogrel and leading to therapeutic failure.
Prasugrel Irreversible P2Y12 antagonist, oral It has a more rapid onset of action compared to clopidogrel.
Ticagrelor Reversible P2Y12 antagonist, oral

More rapid onset and offset of action compared to clopidogrel.

Associated with dyspnea and higher risk of intracranial bleeding; contraindicated in patients with a history of intracranial bleeding.
Cangrelor Reversible P2Y12 antagonist, intravenous The action begins within minutes and lasts for one hour following the stoppage of the drug.

Related Pearl: Classification of anti-platelet drugs

Class Drugs
Cyclooxygenase- I inhibitors Aspirin
Irreversible P2Y12 inhibitors

Ticlopidine, Clopidogrel, Prasugrel
Reversible P2Y12 inhibitors Ticagrelor, Cangrelor
GpIIb/IIIa inhibitors Abciximab, Eptifibatide, Tirofiban
Thrombin (PAR-1) receptor antagonist Vorapaxar 
Phosphodiesterase inhibitors

Dipyridamole

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about obstructive jaundice?

choices.text: Presence of bilirubin in the urine

questions.solution:
Obstructive jaundice is characterized by an absence of urobilinogen. Features like increased direct bilirubin, increased alkaline phosphatase, and the presence of bilirubin in the urine are seen in obstructive jaundice.

Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia refers to the increase in direct bilirubin levels. It usually occurs due to impaired excretion of bilirubin due to obstructive biliary pathology. The diagnosis can be made by elevation of serum direct bilirubin levels, hepatic enzymes (Alkaline phosphatase specifically raised in cholestasis), and absent urinary urobilinogen. Obstruction of biliary ducts may be intrahepatic or extrahepatic and can be localised by imaging techniques.  

Bilirubin is the breakdown product of heme metabolism which is formed in the reticuloendothelial cells of the liver. It is insoluble in water and is known as unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin. It is transported to the liver after binding to albumin, where it undergoes conjugation with glucuronic acid. The final product is known as conjugated bilirubin (direct bilirubin) which drains into the duodenum. On reaching the colon, the unconjugated form is acted upon by bacterial beta glucuronidases and reduced into colorless urobilinogen. Almost 90% is excreted through feces as stercobilinogen, and the remaining will undergo enterohepatic cycling. A small fraction of this escapes hepatic uptake and will be excreted in the urine as urobilinogen.

Normally, urine bilirubin is absent. However, in obstructive jaundice, bilirubin cannot drain to the intestine to be converted into urobilinogen. Thus, fecal urobilinogen is absent, which gives the characteristic clay-colored stools. The presence of urine bilirubin is an indication of post-hepatic obstruction and presents as cola/dark-colored urine. Increase bilirubin deposition in the skin, resulting in yellowish discoloration and may lead to pruritus.

Related Pearl: Types of Jaundice

Type of jaundice Serum bilirubin Urine Urobilinogen Urine bilirubin
Pre-hepatic ↑ Indirect          ↑        -
Hepatic ↑ Direct and indirect   Normal/ ↓       +/-
Post-hepatic ↑ Direct          -        +

Related Pearl: Hyperbilirubinemia- Causes

Excess production of bilirubin

Resorption of blood from internal hemorrhage (e.g., alimentary tract bleeding, hematomas)

 Biliary tract diseases like primary biliary cirrhosis and primary sclerosing cholangitis

Dubin Johnson syndrome

Reduced hepatic uptake

Rotor syndrome

Drug interference with membrane carrier systems

questions.text: Oral digoxin is being given to a 65-year-old male patient with congestive heart failure as a maintenance dose to gradually digitalize him. A target plasma concentration of 0.70 ng/mL is decided upon. The digoxin clearance for this particular individual is calculated as 60 mL/min. Knowing that the oral bioavailability of digoxin is 70%, what is the dosing rate in this patient?
questions.solution:
The dosing rate in this patient is 60 ng/min.

The oral bioavailability of digoxin is 70% (F = 0.7) and the required target plasma concentration (Cp) is 0.70 ng/mL. CL is the clearance of digoxin which is 60 mL/min.

Hence, the appropriate dose rate for this patient can be calculated as:

Dosing rate = Target Cp x CL/F

= [0.70 ng/mL × 60 mL/min] ÷ [0.7]

= 60 ng/min

questions.text: A female patient presents to the OPD with redness of the eye. The examination findings of her eye are shown in the image below. She had been previously diagnosed with glaucoma and was receiving a topical drug. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The image in the above clinical scenario shows conjunctival hyperemia. It is the side effect of apraclonidine. It occurs due to an allergic response to apraclonidine. 

Apraclonidine is an alpha-adrenergic agonist. It is used in the treatment of ocular hypertension and glaucoma. It is available as a topical preparation of 0.5 and 1% solutions.

The notable side effects of apraclonidine include conjunctival hyperemia, sleepiness, and dry mouth. 

Prostaglandin analogs like latanoprost and bimatoprost can also be associated with conjunctival hyperemia.

Other options:

Option A: Pilocarpine is associated with side effects that include corneal edema, miosis, induced myopia associated with decreased vision, brow ache, and retinal detachment

Option B: Timolol is associated with exacerbation of respiratory conditions like asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, bradycardia, depression, and impotence.

Option C: Echothiophate is associated with retinal detachment, miosis, cataract, pupillary block, glaucoma, iris cysts, brow ache, and punctal stenosis, which may further result in epiphora.

Related Pearl: Important adverse effects of anti-glaucoma drugs

Anti-glaucoma drug The adverse effects

Lid retraction

CNS depression and apnea in infants and children (<2 years)

Retinal detachment

Cataract
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

questions.text:
A patient with gastric carcinoma may present with:
  1. Enlarged left supraclavicular lymph nodes
  2. Krukenberg’s tumor
  3. Rectovescial secondaries
  4. Hyperkeratotic palms
  5. Migratory thrombophlebitis
questions.solution:
Enlarged left supraclavicular lymph nodes, Krukenberg’s tumor, periumbilical nodules, hyperkeratotic palms, and migratory thrombophlebitis are atypical presentations of gastric carcinoma.

Atypical presentations of gastric carcinoma include

  • Sister Mary Joseph's nodule
    • Due to periumbilical metastasis. 
    • See in both gastric cancer (most common) and ovarian cancer.
  • Krukenberg’s tumor
    • Bilateral ovarian metastasis
    • Due to transcoelomic spread
  • Irish nodule
    • Left axillary lymphadenopathy.
  • Blumer shelf nodules
    • Pelvic metastasis into the pouch of Douglas/ retrovesical pouch
    • Felt on digital palpation
  • Trosseau syndrome
    • Migratory thrombophlebitis
  • Leser Trelet sign
    • Multiple seborrheic keratoses
  • Tripe palms
    • Hyperkeratosis palm.

The image below shows an elderly man with left supraclavicular lymph nodes enlarged.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with recurrent episodes of breathlessness, wheezing, and chest tightness. Auscultation of the chest revealed bilateral wheeze. Sputum microscopy reveals the following. Which of the following statements is false regarding her condition?

choices.text: Chromosome 5q is the site of the susceptibility locus
It is a type-1 hypersensitivity reaction

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the sputum microscopy showing Charcot–Leyden crystals (arrows in below image), lakes of mucus, and numerous eosinophils, are diagnostic of bronchial asthma. Reid index is normal in bronchial asthma and is increased in chronic bronchitis.

Asthma is characterized by reversible bronchoconstriction caused by airway hyperresponsiveness to a variety of stimuli. Atopic asthma is caused by a TH2 and IgE-mediated immunologic reaction to environmental allergens (type-1 hypersensitivity reaction). Triggers for non-atopic asthma are less clear but include viral infections and inhaled air pollutants.

Genetic susceptibility for developing asthma:

  • Chromosome 5q - site of the susceptibility locus for asthma (Statement C)
  • IL-13 gene polymorphisms (on 5q chromosome) - most consistent associations with asthma or allergic disease
  • IL-4 receptor gene variants - associated with atopy, elevated total serum IgE, and asthma

The sputum of patients with bronchial asthma shows:

  • Charcot–Leyden crystals - made of an eosinophilic membrane protein called galectin 10
  • Curschmann spirals - spirals of mucus plugs from subepithelial mucous gland ducts or bronchioles
  • Creola bodies - desquamated epithelial cells
  • Numerous eosinophils

Note: The hygiene hypothesis was previously used to explain the development of asthma and other hypersensitivity disorders.

Reid index is the ratio of the thickness of the mucous gland layer (y) to the thickness of the wall between the cartilage and the epithelium (x). It is normally 0.4 and is increased in chronic bronchitis.

questions.text: A neonatologist assess a baby 5 minutes after birth and assigns an APGAR score of 5, with a score of 1 in each of the components. Which of the following is the baby likely to have?
questions.solution:
This baby with an APGAR score of 1 in each component is likely to have a weak cry.

Other options:

Option A: HR > 100/min gives a score of 2.

Options B and C: If present, each is given a score of 0. 

The Apgar score is a systematic way of assessing the infant after birth at 1 and 5 minutes of life. It gives a maximum score of 10 which indicates the newborn is in the best possible condition.

Scores between 0-3 require immediate resuscitation. Changes in the Apgar scores denote the response of the infant to resuscitation. If the score at 5 minutes remains less than 7, the infant should be assessed again every 5 minutes for the next 20 minutes.

questions.text: A patient with an underlying pulmonary disease develops pneumonia. The causative organism was found to be Moraxella catarrhalis. Which of the following is the likely underlying disease?
questions.solution:
Pneumonia due to Moraxella catarrhalis is likely to be associated with underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) or smoking.

The presence of certain epidemiological factors suggests possible etiological agents of community-acquired pneumonia, as given in the table below:

Factor Possible pathogen
Alcoholism S. pneumoniae, Klebsiella pneumoniae, oral anaerobes
COPD and smoking S. pneumoniae, Hemophilus influenzae, Moraxella catarrhalis
Bronchiectasis Pseudomonas, Burkholderia, Staphylococcus aureus
Decreased level of consciousness (leading to aspiration) Oral anaerobes, gram-negative enteric bacteria
Lung abscess MRSA, oral anaerobes, Mycobacteria
Stay in a hotel or a cruise ship in the past 2 weeks Legionella
Exposure to birds Chlamydia psittaci
Exposure to rabbits Francisella

Related Pearl: Typical Pneumonia v/s Atypical Pneumonia

Typical pneumonia  Atypical pneumonia 
Extracellular organism  Intracellular organism
Alveolar exudates in air spaces Interstitial involvement
Neutrophilic in nature Lymphocytic in nature
High-grade fever Low-grade fever
Productive cough

Dry cough
hemoptysis   scanty sputum
Pleuritic chest pain Extrapulmonary manifestation
X-Ray shows large areas of consolidation X-Ray shows an interstitial pattern of involvement.

 

  • The most common cause of Community-acquired Pneumonia- Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • The most common cause of Atypical Pneumonia- Mycoplasma pneumoniae.
  • The most common cause of Nosocomial Pneumonia-
    • Overall- gram-negative bacilli (implicated as a group)
    • The single most common agent- Staphylococcus aureus (i.e., gram-positive cocci)

Note:

  • Ciprofloxacin*

Related Pearl: CURB-65 Criteria

This is a score to determine the severity of pneumonia.

The CURB-65 criteria include five variables(1 point for each variable):

  • Confusion 
  • Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN) >7 mmol/L
  • Respiratory rate ≥30/min 
  • Blood pressure, systolic ≤90 mmHg or diastolic ≤60 mmHg 
  • Age ≥65 years.

Management:

0 point: Treat as an outpatient

1 to 2 points: Admitted to the hospital

≥3 points: ICU admission

Treatment of Community-Acquired Pneumonia 

Score - 0: The drug of choice is macrolides.

                     Azithromycin 500mg OD

                                  or

                   Clarithromycin  500mg BD

                                  or

                   Doxycycline  100mg BD.

Score - 1: Treated with azithromycin  500mg OD + ceftriaxone 2gm OD.

               Respiratory quinolones (Levofloxacin) are not preferred.

Score - >2: Azithromycin 500mg OD + Ceftriaxone 2gm IV OD and specific management.

NOTE:- In a modified version of the CURB-65, the criteria of blood urea nitrogen has been removed.

           This elimination removes the need for lab testing.

questions.text:
Match the following:
  1. Used to deliver the after coming head in breech
  2. Used in the correction of asynclitism of the head
  3. Exclusively outlet forceps
  4. Delivers head in mento-posterior position
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-B, 2-A, 3-C.

Image 1: Kielland forceps: It is used as a rotation forceps. It is a long and almost straight (very slight pelvic curve) obstetric forceps without any axis-traction device. It has a sliding lock that facilitates the correction of asynclitism of the head. For forceps rotations from an OP to OA position, deep transverse arrest, unrotated vertex or face presentations, the Kielland forceps are preferred since their pelvic curve is less pronounced.  

Image 2: Pipers forceps: have a distinct perineal curve and allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

Image 3: Wrigley's forceps are used exclusively in outlet forceps operations for the extraction of the head. It is used to provide traction force. The instrument is light and short due to a reduction in the length of the shanks and handles. It has a marked cephalic curve with a slight pelvic curve. Outlet forceps are used when:

  • the fetal scalp is visible without separating the labia
  • the fetal skull has reached the pelvic floor, at or on the perineum
  • the sagittal suture is in the anteroposterior diameter or right or left occiput anterior or posterior position (rotation does not exceed 45°)

Other forceps used in obstetrics include:

  • Low or mid-cavity forceps, e.g. Neville Barnes, Andersons, Simpsons. They are used when:

    • the fetal head is one-fifth palpable per abdomen
    • the leading point of the skull is above  +2 cm but not above the ischial spines
    • rotation of 45° or less.

Mento-posterior position: Forceps should not be applied because vaginal delivery is impossible unless the fetus is very small. 

Related Pearl: Obstetrics forceps

Commonly used forceps: 

1) Simpson forceps

  • The most commonly used types of forceps in outlet delivery.
  • Has elongated cephalic curve.
  • These are used when there is substantial molding of the fetal head.

2) Elliot forceps

  • Has an adjustable pin for regulating the lateral pressure on the handles.
  • They are used most often when there is minimal molding.
  • More suitable for outlet delivery.

3) Kielland forceps

  • Has small pelvic curve and a sliding lock.
  • Suitable for head with little molding.
  • The most common forceps used for rotational delivery.
  • Helps correct asynclitism.

4) Piper forceps

  • Distinct perineal curve.
  • Allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

5) Tucker-McLane forceps

  • Suitable for fetal head with little molding.
  • Used in rotational delivery.

6) Barton forceps and traction handle

  • Used in rotational delivery.
  • Most importantly used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.
  • It is an obsolete procedure.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old female patient is brought to the casualty with a history of slip and fall in the bathroom. The patient is having pain in the left hip and is not able to walk. On examination, the left lower limb is shortened and externally rotated. An X-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following are the other radiological findings that can be seen in this condition?

1) Prominent lesser trochanter 

2) Intact Shenton's line 

3) Displacement of greater trochanter

4) Break in the trabecular stream

5) Break in the medial cortex of the neck
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and x-ray are suggestive of fracture neck of femur and statements 1,3,4 and 5 are correct.

Plain radiograph of fracture neck of the femur may show the following features:

  • Fracture in the neck of femur
  • Break in the medial cortex
  • External rotation of the femur with the lesser trochanter appearing more prominent
  • Displacement of the greater trochanter
  • Break in the trabecular stream
  • Break in Shenton's line

Fracture of neck of the femur:

Clinical features:

  • Painful movements of the hip joint
  • Shortening and external rotation of the affected limb
  • Tenderness in the hip 
  • Active straight leg raising is not possible

Risk factors:

Common risk factors for femoral neck fractures include:

  • Elderly age
  • Female sex
  • White population of Europe and North America
  • Smoking
  • Decreased level of physical activity

Comorbidities that can cause femoral neck fractures are:

  • HIV
  • Celiac disease
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Hypo and hyperthyroidism
  • Primary hyperparathyroidism
  • Chronic kidney and liver disease

Medications that can cause femoral neck fractures are:

  • Corticosteroids
  • Proton pump inhibitors
  • Antipsychotic medication
  • Aromatase inhibitors
  • Gonadotropin-releasing hormone inhibitors
  • Long-acting progesterone-only pill

Related Pearl: Treatment of fracture neck of femur

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about low glycemic index foods?

choices.text: They result in a rapid spike in insulin
They are not readily digestible and absorbable
They are helpful in the management of obesity
Whole grains have a low glycemic index

questions.solution:
Low glycemic index foods don't cause a rapid spike in insulin. Rather, they prevent insulin fluctuations.

The increase in the blood glucose levels after a test dose of a carbohydrate meal compared with that after an equivalent amount of glucose is termed as the glycemic index (GI). Graphically, it is represented by the area under the curve of the blood glucose-time graph. The given graph shows the glycemic index of test food versus the glucose as a reference.

 

Foods containing different proportions of insoluble fibers prolong digestion and absorption. Foods that are not readily hydrolyzed and absorbed from the small intestine have a lower GI (option B). On the other hand, starches that are easily digested have a higher GI. Since the blood glucose levels rise slowly, there is no rapid spike in insulin levels. 

Low GI foods include fruits and vegetables (except potatoes, sweet corn), whole grains (option D), brown rice, pasta, beans, and lentils, while high GI foods include white rice, potatoes, and white bread. Low GI foods are beneficial in patients with obesity and type 2 diabetes mellitus (option C).

questions.text: A 33-year-old pregnant woman at 20 weeks of gestation has the following finding on USG. Identify the defect.
questions.solution:
The given ultrasound image shows scalloping of the frontal bones known as the lemon sign. It is seen in meningoencephalocele. 

Encephalocele is caused due to defects in the skull through which the meninges and/or neural tissue herniate. The squamous part of the occipital bone is the most frequently affected bone. In meningoencephalocele or occult spina bifida with Chiari malformations, the scalloping of the frontal bones is observed in the ultrasound as the lemon sign while anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa forms the banana sign. 

 The image shows a newborn with encephalocele. 

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign on USG as seen below.

The scalloping of the frontal bones is observed in the ultrasound as the lemon sign as seen below.

Other options:

Option A: Anencephaly results from incomplete closure of the neural tube. It is one of the earliest detectable congenital defects that can be detected as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation. Screening can also be done by serum estimation of maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP). The following are the radiological signs seen in anencephaly - 

 Frog eye sign - Absence of cranial calvaria, prominent orbits thereby resembling the face of a frog. 

Option C: Acrania is the absence of the cranium, with protrusion of a disorganized mass of brain tissue. This anomaly is more prevalent in first birth and about 70% of fetuses are females. 

The USG shows characteristic triangular facial appearance and shower cap sign.

Option D: Omphalocele is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen. The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac. These are due to the persistence of physiological herniation of the gut or as a part of the OEIS complex (omphalocele, exstrophy, imperforate anus, and spinal abnormality) and cloacal exstrophy. 

The image below shows an omphalocele.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

Related Pearl: Fetal Monitoring using Ultrasound

  • The first definitive USG finding to suggest pregnancy is the visualization of the gestational sac.
  • The first sign of intrauterine pregnancy is the presence of yolk sac within the gestational sac.
  • Best time to assess gestational age by USG is 9-12 weeks(by CRL)
  • CRL(mm)+42 = Days of pregnancy
  • CRL(cm)+6.5 = Gestational age in weeks.
  • The best indicator of fetal growth is the abdominal circumference. Abdominal circumference is the transverse measurement at the level of the stomach with the confluence of the umbilical vein and right portal vein.

questions.text:
Data obtained from an RCT testing a new hypolipidemic drug is given below. How many patients need to be treated to prevent one death?
  Placebo group Hypolipidemic drug group
Number of patients who died due to cardiovascular causes 145 20
Total number of patients in each group 1250 1250
questions.solution:
10 patients need to be treated with the new hypolipidemic drug to prevent 1 death.
 
The number needed to treat (NNT) is defined as the number of individuals that need to be treated with the new drug to prevent 1 death (or to save 1 life).
 
NNT = 1/ARR or 100/ARR, if the absolute risk reduction is already in percentage.
 
Here, ARR is the absolute risk reduction. ARR is the difference in the incidence between the placebo and the drug group. This formula is the same as that for attributable risk. Note that in clinical epidemiology, absolute risk reduction/increase is used identically to attributable risk.
 
Calculation:

ARR = Incidence in the placebo group — Incidence in the drug group
ARR = 145/1250  — 20/1250
ARR = 125/1250 = 1/10
 
NNT = 1/ARR = 10
 
Thus, 10 patients need to be treated with the new hypolipidemic drug to prevent one death due to cardiovascular causes. 

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text:
While measuring the abdominal circumference to estimate the fetal weight, which of the following landmarks must be demonstrated on USG?
  1. Umbilical vein
  2. Fetal stomach
  3. Portal sinus
  4. Kidneys
  5. Cord insertion
questions.solution:
The abdominal circumference on USG is measured at the plane of the umbilical vein, fetal stomach, and portal sinus. The kidneys and cord insertion should not be visible.

  • Best time to assess gestational age by USG is 9-12 weeks(by CRL)

questions.text:
In which of the following situations is antibiotic prophylaxis required to prevent infective endocarditis?
  1. Patient with unrepaired tetralogy of Fallot undergoing a dental extraction
  2. Patient with a history of prior endocarditis undergoing upper GI endoscopy
  3. Patient with prosthetic heart valve undergoing cystoscopy
  4. Patient with atrial septal defect which was repaired 5 years ago undergoing a dental extraction
questions.solution:
Only the patient with unrepaired tetralogy of Fallot undergoing dental extraction requires antibiotic prophylaxis. While patients in statements 2 and 3 have high-risk cardiac lesions, they are undergoing procedures for which antibiotic prophylaxis is not needed. The patient in statement 4 has ASD which was repaired 5 years ago, and also does not need antibiotic prophylaxis.

The following cardiac lesions are considered high-risk and warrant antibiotic prophylaxis before a dental procedure:

  • Prosthetic heart valves or left ventricular assist devices
  • Prior endocarditis
  • Unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart diseases
  • Completely repaired congenital heart diseases during the first 6 months following repair
  • Repaired congenital heart diseases with residual defects adjacent to prosthetic material
  • Valvulopathy developing after cardiac transplantation

Prophylaxis is with oral Amoxicillin 1 hour before the procedure. In case the patient is unable to take oral medications, Ampicillin is given IV or IM 1 hour before the procedure. In patients allergic to Penicillins, Azithromycin, Cephalexin, and Doxycycline are alternatives. 

Prophylaxis is not advised for patients undergoing gastrointestinal or genitourinary tract procedures, such as transesophageal echocardiography, upper GI endoscopy, colonoscopy, or cystoscopy.

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

Related Pearl: Cardiac conditions requiring antibiotic prophylaxis for infective endocarditis

High risk cardiac conditions for development of Infective endocarditis and require antibiotic prophylaxis are:

  • Prosthetic valves
  • History of infective endocarditis
  • Few congenital heart diseases which include:
    • Unrepaired cyanotic CHD, including palliative shunts and conduit
    • Completely repaired congenital heart defect with prosthetic material or device, whether placed by surgery or by catheter intervention, during the first 6 months after the procedure
    • Repaired CHD with residual defects at the site or adjacent to the site of a prosthetic patch or prosthetic device
  • Cardiac transplantation recipients with cardiac valvular disease

questions.text:
A patient diagnosed with Hepatitis B infection is positive for IgG Anti HBc. In this patient, which of the following serological report indicates chronic HBV infection and recovery respectively?
  1. HBsAg -,  Anti HBs +
  2. HBsAg +,  Anti HBs -
  3. HBsAg -,  Anti HBs -
questions.solution:
In a patient with IgG Anti HBc,

  • Option 1: HBsAg -,  Anti HBs + would indicate recovery.
  • Option 2: HBsAg +,  Anti HBs - indicates chronic HBV infection. 
  • Option 3: HBsAg -,  Anti HBs - may be seen in HBV infection in the remote past and passive transfer of anti-HBc in an infant born to an HBsAg-positive gestational parent. 

Note: In this patient, HBsAg -,  Anti HBs - may also be seen in the recovery phase if the Anti HBs - levels have waned. But there is no option with the correct combination of reports 2, 3.

questions.text: A patient in the postoperative ward was given opioids to relieve pain. But within a few hours, his respiratory rate decreased and oxygen saturation dropped. Opioid-induced respiratory depression was suspected and he was managed with naloxone. What is the intrinsic activity of naloxone?
questions.solution:
Naloxone is a competitive antagonist of opioids and hence it is used in the reversal of opioid-induced respiratory depression. All the competitive antagonists have no intrinsic activity i.e Intrinsic activity=0

The capacity of a drug to induce a functional change in the receptor is called intrinsic activity.

Type of drugs

Intrinsic activity

Agonists

1

Partial agonists

0 to 1

Competitive antagonists

0

Inverse agonists

0 to -1

The image given below shows the action of various types of selective receptor modulators.

Graph 1 represents the agonist: An agonist is an agent which initiates the normal physiological response when combined with a receptor.

Example: Salbutamol is a beta-2 receptor agonist.

Graph 2 represents a partial agonist: An agent which produces a submaximal or partial effect when combined with a receptor.

Example: Buprenorphine and butorphanol are partial agonists at opioid receptors.

Graph 3 represents the antagonist: An agent which blocks or reduces the action of an agonist on a receptor, but does not have any effect of its own.

Example: Naltrexone and naloxone are antagonists at opioid receptors.

Graph 4 represents an inverse agonist: An agent which activates a receptor to produce an effect in the opposite direction to that of the agonist.

Example: β-Carboline is an inverse agonist at benzodiazepine site of GABA-A receptor.

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles are attached to the structure marked as 1?
  1. Gluteus maximus
  2. Gluteus medius
  3. Gluteus minimus
  4. Iliopsoas
  5. Piriformis
questions.solution:
The marked structure in the image is the greater trochanter.

The muscles that are attached to the greater trochanter are:

  • Gluteus medius
  • Gluteus minimus
  • Piriformis

Most part of the gluteus maximus muscle attaches to the iliotibial tract, while the deeper fibers of the lower portion of the muscle insert into the gluteal tuberosity.

Iliopsoas muscle inserts on the lesser trochanter of the femur.

questions.text: Which of the following is caused by a virus containing a single-stranded linear RNA having 8 segments?
questions.solution:
Orthomyxoviruses have a single-stranded linear RNA having 8 segments and can cause influenza.

The following viruses have segmented RNA and the number of segments in them is as follows:

Viruses Segments Diseases caused
Arenavirus 2

Lassa fever encephalitis
Bunyavirus 3

Rift Valley feversa
Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever
Hantavirus—hemorrhagic fever, pneumonia
Orthomyxovirus 8

Influenza
Reovirus  10-12

Rotavirus - gastroenteritis
  • All the viruses with segmented RNA are single-stranded except for Reovirus which is double-stranded.
  • Viruses with circular RNA are Arenavirus, Bunyavirus, and Delta virus.

Option D: Bronchiolitis is caused by Respiratory syncytial virus (Paramyxoviruses) which contains a single-stranded linear non-segmented RNA.

questions.text: A child with an accommodative squint develops strabismic amblyopia and is treated as shown in the image. Identify the affected eye and by what age should it be corrected?
questions.solution:
Occlusion of the normal (left) eye is the treatment of choice for amblyopia. Thus in the given case, the right eye has strabismic amblyopia and it should be corrected before 8 years of age.

Amblyopia is a decrease in vision in one or both eyes with no identifiable abnormality in the eye or the visual pathway to explain it. It may be of the following types:

  • Strabismic - monocular suppression of the deviating eye in case of abnormal binocular interaction and may develop in children with accommodative squint
  • Anisometropic - due to a difference in refractive error between the two eyes
  • Stimulus deprivation - in the case of vision deprivation
  • Bilateral ametropic - high but symmetrical refractive errors
  • Meridional - blurring of vision in one meridian
Treatment of choice:
  • Occlusion of the normal eye (4 to 6 hours/day) using patches.
  • Penalization: Blurring of vision using atropine.

The acuity of an amblyopic eye can be improved in the sensitive period which is usually up to 7–8 years in strabismic amblyopia and maybe longer (into the teens) for anisometropic amblyopia when a good binocular function is present.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy with sickle cell disease presents with dull pain in the right lower limb with a fever, for 2 weeks. Physical examination shows tenderness, swelling, and erythema in the anterior aspect of the right lower limb with overlying skin ulceration and a draining sinus. Investigations reveal a WBC count of 25,000 and grossly elevated ESR and CRP. Which of the following imaging tests has the highest specificity for his likely condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes the signs and symptoms of osteomyelitis. MRI has the highest sensitivity and specificity for detecting osteomyelitis in children. Patients with sickle cell anemia are more prone to developing osteomyelitis and Salmonella is a common causative organism.

After a conventional radiographic evaluation, MRI is considered the imaging study of choice for further evaluation. It is useful to obtain information on the extent of cortical destruction and to evaluate for the presence of bone marrow abnormalities, soft tissue inflammation, and ischemia

Both T1 and T2-weighted images should be obtained. An abnormal osseous signal on all sequences in the region of concern in the correct clinical setting confirms the diagnosis of osteomyelitis. A characteristic penumbra sign may be seen in subacute infection. There will be a peripheral relatively high-signal ring of granulation tissue surrounding a low-signal central zone which is the abscess cavity

X-Ray (Option 1) may be done as the first step in the evaluation of a suspected case of osteomyelitis. But, it is not as sensitive or specific as MRI. CT scan (Option 2) is more sensitive than X-Ray and may be used for evaluating cortical and trabecular integrity, periosteal reaction, intraosseous gas, soft tissue gas, and the extent of sinus tracts. It is the most useful for evaluating involucrum and osseus debris. Nuclear imaging studies (Option 4) such as the triple-phase bone scan, tagged WBC scan, and Gallium scan may be used in the presence of metal hardware that precludes the use of CT or MRI. It is better at evaluating acute rather than chronic cases.

The leading symptoms are usually pain and low-grade fever. Infection may manifest as clinical sepsis and local signs of inflammation (erythema and swelling). Long-bone osteomyelitis may also present as septic arthritis of the surrounding joints.

Sub-acute osteomyelitis may present as a Brodie's abscess - this is a region of suppuration and necrosis encapsulated by granulation tissue within a rim of sclerotic bone. It usually occurs in patients <25 years of age. The most common sites are the distal tibia, femur, fibula, radius, and ulna. 

Complications of osteomyelitis include:

  • Sinus tract formation
  • Contiguous soft tissue infection
  • Abscess
  • Septic arthritis
  • Systemic infection
  • Bony deformity
  • Fracture 
  • Malignancy

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with dark-colored urine, bilateral sensorineural hearing loss, and anterior lenticonus. His father suffered a similar condition and passed away last year. What is the most likely electron microscopic picture of his renal biopsy?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette with a positive family history is suggestive of Alport Syndrome. The most likely electron microscopy of his renal biopsy is the basket-weave appearance of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM). 

Alport syndrome or hereditary nephritis is a genetic disease caused by mutations in the genes coding for type IV collagen. This is a major component of the basement membranes. The majority of the patients have an X-linked inheritance. Clinical features include hematuria, proteinuria, and sensorineural hearing loss. Ocular manifestations include anterior lenticonus, macular flecks, and corneal dystrophy.

Light microscopy appears normal during the first decade of life. Later glomeruli may have mesangial proliferation and capillary wall thickening. This may lead to progressive sclerosis of the glomerulus. Electron microscopy shows diffuse thickening and thinning along with splitting of glomerular and tubular basement membranes. It is seen as a characteristic basket weaving appearance of lamina densa as shown below.

No specific therapy is recommended to treat Alport syndrome. Proteinuria can be treated with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors or angiotensin 2 receptor blockers.

Other options:

Option A: Subepithelial deposits are seen on electron microscopy in cases of membranous nephropathy. It typically has a noninflammatory pathology. It presents as a nephrotic syndrome in most patients. Non-nephrotic proteinuria, hematuria, and mild hypertension can be seen in some cases. 

Option C: Epithelial crescent formation is seen in crescentic RPGN (rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis). Examples include Goodpasture syndrome, IgA nephropathy, lupus nephritis etc. Features include oliguria and other signs of nephritic syndrome.

Option D: Subepithelial humps are seen in post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. It is caused due to immune complex deposition of streptococcal antigens and specific antibodies. Clinical features include malaise, oliguria, and hematuria around 1-2 weeks after a streptococcal infection. The urine is typically described as smoky or cola-colored urine.

Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (crescentic)

IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

Alport syndrome

These syndromes, however, are not mutually exclusive. Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythematosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: A child with bilateral cataracts was brought to the ophthalmology department. Systemic examination reveals hearing loss, a congenital heart defect along with the following lesions that have been present since birth. All of the following are the ocular findings associated with this condition except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing blueberry muffin lesions is suggestive of Congenital rubella syndrome and microphthalmos is seen in this condition (not megalophthalmos).

Congenital rubella cataract may occur alone or as part of the classical rubella syndrome which consists of:

  • Ocular defects: Congenital cataract, salt and pepper chorioretinopathy, microphthalmos, Glaucoma, and anterior uveitis
  • Sensorineural hearing loss
  • Heart defects: Patent ductus arteriosus, pulmonary stenosis, and ventricular septal defects.

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown below and the procedure it is used for.
questions.solution:
The given instrument shows the Jamshidi needle. It is used for bone marrow biopsy. 

Jamshidi needles have a t-bar at the end for easier maneuvering. Jamshidi needle has a tapering end to reduce the crush artifacts in the sample.

Indications of bone marrow biopsy:

  • Evaluation of unexplained anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, pancytopenia.
  • Evaluation of polycythemia, thrombocytosis, leukocytosis.
  • Diagnosis and staging of lymphoma or solid tumors.
  • Diagnosis and evaluation of plasma cell disorders and leukemias.
  • Evaluation of suspected infiltrative and storage diseases.
  • Evaluation of fever of unknown origin suspected mycobacterial, fungal, or parasitic infections or granulomatous diseases.

Contraindications of bone marrow biopsy: 

  • Severe hemophilia.
  • Severe disseminated intravascular coagulopathy.
  • Severe bleeding disorders.

Other options:

Option B: The image below shows a cutting-type vim Silverman liver biopsy needle.

Option C: Veress Needle is used to produce a pneumoperitoneum in direct puncture laparoscopy.

Insufflation of the abdomen is accomplished with a Veress needle held at its serrated collar with the thumb and forefinger. Because the linea alba is fused to the umbilicus, the abdominal wall is grasped with fingers or penetrating a towel clip to elevate the abdominal wall away from the underlying structures.

Option D: Salah's needles are reusable bone marrow biopsy needles, made up of stainless steel.

questions.text:
Match the following shapes of RBCs with the conditions they are associated with.
1. Acanthocytes a. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia 
2. Degmacytes b. Myelofibrosis
3. Dacrocytes c. Uremia
4. Echinocytes d. Post splenectomy
5. Schistocytes  e. G6PD deficiency
questions.solution:
The correct match is as follows:

1. Acanthocytes d. Post splenectomy
2. Degmacytes e. G6PD deficiency
3. Dacrocytes b. Myelofibrosis
4. Echinocytes c. Uremia
5. Schistocytes  a. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia 

 

Acanthocyte or spur cells are characterized by only a few spicules of varying size that project from the cell surface at irregular intervals. 

Conditions with acanthocytes include-

  • Renal disease
  • Abetalipoproteinemia
  • Post splenectomy/ hyposplenism.

 

Degmacytes or bite cells or blister cells are seen in G6PD deficiency. In G6PD deficiency, uncontrolled oxidative stress causes hemoglobin to denature and form Heinz bodies. Bite cells result from the removal of Heinz bodies by macrophages in the spleen. Heinz bodies can be appreciated by Supravital staining – crystal violet

Dacrocytes or tear-drop cells are seen in myelofibrosis, myelodysplastic syndromes, hemolytic anemias, and thalassemias.  

 

Echinocyte or Burr cells are characterized by projections of the red cell membrane that are smaller, regularly spaced, smoothly rounded crenulations, and much more uniform in shape and distribution in contrast to the acanthocytes. They also tend to be reversible, unlike acanthocytes. They are seen in anemia of renal disease (uremia), in premature infants, after exchange transfusion, and may sometimes be seen as storage artifacts.

 

Schistocytes or helmet cells are fragmented RBCs that are seen in microangiopathic hemolytic anemias and mechanical valves.

questions.text: A patient has recurrent bouts of infections and all the causative organisms show a positive reaction for the biochemical test shown below. Nitroblue tetrazolium dye reduction test shows yellow color. What is the most likely cause of infections in this case?
questions.solution:
The image given shows a slide with a positive catalase test. Recurrent infections with catalase-positive organisms with a negative (yellow) nitroblue tetrazolium dye reduction test is seen in chronic granulomatous disease.

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is an inherited defect in microbiocidal activity. In this condition, there is a failure in the formation of reactive oxygen species due to defective phagocytes NADPH oxidase. This leads to the phagocytic inability to kill specific microbes.

Catalase is an enzyme that inactivates hydrogen peroxide. When these patients are infected with catalase-negative organisms, the patient's immune system can use hydrogen peroxide produced by the organism to create reactive oxygen species. However, in catalase-positive organisms, the hydrogen peroxide produced is rapidly destroyed by catalase, and therefore, the patient's immune response cannot use it to produce reactive oxygen species. Thus, most patients present with pneumonia due to catalase-positive organisms like Staphylococcus aureus, Burkholderia cepacia, Serratia marcescens, Nocardia, and Aspergillus species. 

The catalase test is demonstrated by placing a microbial colony in hydrogen peroxide (H2O2). The catalase enzyme degrades hydrogen peroxide to water and oxygen. The liberated O2 is seen as gas bubbles and is a positive test.

Patients have recurrent bacterial and fungal infections. The symptoms begin within the first two years of life, affecting the pulmonary, gastrointestinal, skin, and lymphatic drainage of these organs. Nitroblue tetrazolium is used as a diagnostic test. The yellow-colored Nitroblue tetrazolium dye is converted to a purple insoluble substance (positive) in the presence of oxidative burst by the free oxygen radicals so formed. A negative test (yellow color remains) is seen in CGD.

Other options:

Option A: Deficiency of terminal complement components (C5-C8) leads to recurrent infections with gram-negative cocci such as with Neisseria. 

Options B and C: Asplenia and Wiskott Aldrich Syndrome have increased susceptibility to infection with encapsulated organisms like pneumococci, meningococci, and Haemophilus influenzae.

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presents for advice regarding obesity. On multiple occasions over the past 4 months, she has eaten large amounts of food at night and felt disgusted, and guilty after. She is distressed about overeating but states that she can not control it. There is no history of vomiting. Her BMI is 35. Which of the following disorders is responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with a patient having recurrent episodes of uncontrollable binge eating for over 3 months, associated with distress and feelings of guilt in the absence of inappropriate compensatory behavior such as vomiting, is suggestive of binge-eating disorder. It is described as the consumption of unusually large amounts of food over a short period. People with this condition feel that they have no control over their eating. They are also concerned about their weight and eating habits. It is the most common eating disorder.

DSM-5 diagnostic criteria for Binge-eating disorder:

A. Recurrent episodes of binge eating. An episode of binge eating is characterized by both the following:

1. Eating, in a discrete period, an amount of food that is larger than what most people would eat in a similar period under similar circumstances.

2. A sense of lack of control over eating during the episode (e.g., a feeling that one cannot stop eating or control what or how much one is eating).

B. The binge-eating episodes are associated with

1. Eating much more rapidly than normal.

2. Eating until feeling uncomfortably full.

3. Eating large amounts of food when not feeling physically hungry.

4. Eating alone because of feeling embarrassed by how much one is eating.

5. Feeling disgusted with oneself, depressed, or very guilty afterward.

C. Marked distress regarding binge eating is present.

D. The binge-eating occurs, on average, at least once a week for 3 months.

E. Binge eating is not associated with the recurrent use of inappropriate compensatory behavior as in bulimia nervosa and does not occur exclusively during bulimia nervosa or anorexia nervosa.

 

Other options:

Bulimia nervosa: People with bulimia nervosa perform compensatory behavior such as vomiting, laxative abuse, or excessive dieting after binge eating. The person maintains a normal BMI.

Night eating disorder: It is characterized by a large amount of food consumption after an evening meal. They generally have a little appetite during the day and suffer from insomnia. They are not overly concerned with their body image and weight and the amount of food consumed is lower than binge eating done in bulimia and binge eating disorders.

Anorexia nervosa: People with Anorexia nervosa are underweight and have an excessive drive for thinness and intense fear of gaining weight.

Related Pearl: Eating Disorders

 

Anorexia nervosa

Bulimia nervosa

Binge-eating disorder

(calorie deficit)

+/-

(purge/vomit)
