 *In atypical anorexia nervosa, all the features of anorexia nervosa will be present, but the patient will have normal BMI.

questions.text: What would you expect to see on the instillation of 1% hydroxyamphetamine into both the eyes of a patient with right-sided postganglionic Horner syndrome?

choices.text: No change observed in both eyes

questions.solution:
Following the hydroxyamphetamine test, only the normal left eye dilates in the case of postganglionic Horner syndrome on right side.

Sympathetic supply to the dilator pupillae muscle is as follows:

  • The first-order neuron (central) extends from the posterior hypothalamus to the ciliospinal center in the intermediolateral horn of the spinal cord.
  • The second-order preganglionic neuron extends from the ciliospinal center in the spinal cord to the superior cervical ganglion in the neck.
  • The third-order postganglionic neuron reaches the dilator pupillae muscle through the nasociliary and long ciliary nerves.

Pharmacological tests with hydroxyamphetamine, phenylephrine, and adrenaline may be used to differentiate a preganglionic from a postganglionic lesion in Horner's syndrome. Hydroxyamphetamine acts by potentiating the release of noradrenaline from postganglionic nerve endings. Thus in a lesion of the third-order neuron (postganglionic), there is no release of noradrenaline from the dysfunctional nerve. Two drops of Hydroxyamphetamine 1% eyedrops are instilled in each eye and then observed. The result is interpreted as follows:

  • Normal or preganglionic Horner pupils will dilate 
  • Postganglionic Horner pupil does not dilate

In the given case, the right postganglionic Horner pupil does not dilate while the left normal pupil dilates. If the cause was preganglionic then both pupils will dilate. (Option A)

When phenylephrine 1% is used for testing, the result is interpreted as follows:

  • Normal or preganglionic Horner pupils will not dilate
  • Postganglionic Horner pupil dilates

This occurs due to denervation hypersensitivity of the dilator pupillae muscle to adrenergic neurotransmitters in the dysfunctional third-order neuron. In the given case, if phenylephrine was used, only the right pupil will dilate (Option D) and if the cause was preganglionic then no change is observed in both pupils. (Option B)

Related Pearl: Horner's syndrome

Horner's Syndrome:

Horner's syndrome occurring due to occulo-sympathetic paresis is characterized by the classic triad of:

  • Mild ptosis (due to paralysis of Muller's muscle).
  • Miosis (due to paralysis of dilator pupillae).
  • Reduced ipsilateral sweating (anhydrosis).

Other features include:

  • Mild enophthalmos,
  • Loss of cilio-spinal reflex,
  • Heterochromia, i.e., the ipsilateral iris is lighter in colour,
  • Pupil is slow to dilate, and there occurs slight elevation of lower eyelid.

Cocaine test (2% to 4%): Small pupils fail to dilate in Horner's syndrome.

In congenital Horner's syndrome, the additional features seen are heterochromia iridis and unilateral straight hair.

questions.text: The type of taste evoked by monosodium glutamate is sensed via which type of receptor?
questions.solution:
The type of taste evoked by monosodium glutamate is Umami. Umami tastes are sensed by the activation of G-protein coupled receptors.

Taste Receptors: Humans have five established basic tastes: sweet, salt, sour, bitter, and umami. The taste receptors for these five basic tastes are of two major types:

  • Ligand-gated channels (ionotropic receptors): Salt and sour taste are mediated through epithelial sodium channels (ENaC)
    • Na+ movement through ENaC →salt taste
    • H+ movement through ENaC → sour taste
  • G-Protein Coupled Receptors (metabotropic receptors): Sweet, bitter, and umami are sensed via GPCRs
    • T1R2, T1R3 families→ sweet taste
    • T2R family → bitter taste
    • Metabotropic glutamate receptor (mGluR4) or T1R1, T1R3 families → Umami

L-glutamate was identified as having a unique taste, that cannot be categorized as bitter, sweet, salty, and sour. Therefore, it was called umami, with the Japanese word "umai" meaning "delicious". Ribonucleotides such as inosine 5′-monophosphate (IMP) and guanosine-5'-monophosphate (GMP), elicit umami taste on their own. It wasn't until the identification of G protein-coupled receptors specific for glutamate taste, that umami was completely accepted as a unique taste.

Related Pearl: Taste sensations and their mediators

Taste Sensations Mediated by
Salt Na+ movement in ENaC
Sweet G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) T1R family
Umami Glutamate receptor family (mGluR4) and G-protein coulped receptors (GPCRs) T1R family
Bitter G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) T2R family
Sour H+ movement through ENaC

questions.text:
For the detection of a disease, three tests are done one after another. The patient is said to be positive for the disease only if all three tests are positive. Which of the following statements are true regarding this method of testing?
  1. Increased sensitivity
  2. Increased specificity
  3. Increased positive predictive value
  4. Increased negative predictive value
questions.solution:
When multiple tests are done in series, the specificity is increased. This means there is a reduction in the false positive error rate, leading to improved positive predictive value.

Screening tests are said to have been done in series when a number of tests are performed sequentially, but the next test is done only if the previous test was found to be positive. For example, testing for HIV by serial ELISA.

Screening tests are said to have been done in parallel when the second test is independently performed — regardless of what the first test result was. Both tests are done at the same time to evaluate the same disease. For example, using fasting, post-prandial and HbA1C testing at the same time for a patient suspected to be diabetic.

When tests are done in parallel, the sensitivity increases. This causes a reduction in the false negative error rate, and thus increases the negative predictive value of the combination of tests.

questions.text: A microbiologist is studying the various growth phases of a bacterium. The findings are plotted in the image below. In phase 3, which of the following is correct about the total cell count and the viable cell count respectively?
questions.solution:
In the stationary phase (3) of the bacterial growth curve, the total cell count increases while the viable cell count remains constant.

In the stationary phase of the bacterial growth curve, growth ceases completely due to exhaustion of nutrients and accumulation of toxic products. However, cell turnover continues to take place in this phase. The slow loss of cells occurring due to death is balanced by the formation of new cells through division. Thus the viable count stays constant as viable cells that die are replaced by new cells. The total cell count of viable and dead cells however increases as the number of dead cells keeps increasing.

The image given below shows a graph plotting the log of the number of bacteria against time in a population of cells termed batch culture denoting the bacterial growth curve.

Phases of bacterial growth curve:

Lag phase: It is the initial period of time required for adaptation of the cells to the new environment during which necessary enzymes and metabolic intermediates are built up in adequate quantities for multiplication. Hence, there is no increase in cell number but cell size increases and maximum cell size is obtained towards the end of this phase.

Log phase: Cells start dividing exponentially or by geometric progression with time. Cells are smaller and stain uniformly. One of two things limits this exponential growth:

  • Exhaustion of nutrients in the medium required for growth
  • Accumulation of toxic metabolites that inhibits growth

Stationary phase: When the exponential growth of cells is limited, the cells enter a stationary phase where cell growth ceases completely. Cell turnover is seen where the rate at which cells die is equally balanced with the rate of formation of new cells through growth and division. In this phase, a bacterial culture phenomenon is noted where bacterial cells become viable but non-culturable (VBNC). This is thought to be triggered by starvation where the bacterial cells enter into a dormant state resulting in no morphological changes. When appropriate conditions are met, VNBC microbes resume growth.

Phase of decline: Cell viability begins to decrease at a defined rate from nutritional exhaustion, toxin accumulation, and the action of autolytic enzymes. The death rate increases until it reaches a steady level and as a result the cell population decreases in this phase. Involution forms are common.

questions.text: A stain present on the clothes of a murder victim is being examined. The benzidine test is positive. Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: The stain is confirmed as a blood stain
The presence of blood is ruled out

questions.solution:
Since the preliminary benzidine test for blood stains is positive, the next step is to do a definitive spectroscopic test to confirm the presence of blood in the stain.

Benzidine test is the best preliminary test for blood and it detects blood when present in a dilution of one part of blood in three lakhs. This test uses the peroxidase activity of the blood to change the colour of the reagent. A dark blue colour is produced by adding a drop of a saturated solution of benzidine in glacial acetic acid and then a drop of hydrogen peroxide. A positive reaction is given by recent, old blood stains, blood that has been exposed to heat or cold, and blood stains treated with cleaning agents. A positive reaction is not proof of the presence of blood (Option A), but a negative reaction rules out the presence of blood (Option B). A False positive reaction is obtained from substances like pus, saliva, milk, rust, bacteria, etc. 

The phenolphthalein test or Kastle–Meyer test (Option D) is also a preliminary test that works on the same principle as the benzidine test. Here the colour changes to pink in a positive reaction.

The spectroscopic test is the most definitive test for detecting the presence of blood in both recent and old stains. It is based on the property of blood pigments to absorb rays from the spectrum. Less than 0.1 mg of blood is sufficient for this test. The blood stain is dissolved in water, normal saline, or diluted ammonia, and placed in a small glass tube, which is then kept between the spectroscope and the light source. The extract of the blood must be diluted and filtered if it is turbid. The solution of the blood has the property of absorbing some of the rays from the spectrum, producing characteristic dark absorption bands, which vary with the type of blood pigment present. 

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

Tests for seminal stains

  • Barberio's test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient had 6 attacks of migraine in the last month and was treated for the same. She is not able to tolerate the pain during attacks and came to the hospital asking for medication that can prevent these attacks in the future. Which of the following drugs can be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Topiramate can be used in this patient to prevent migraine attacks.

In patients with ≥4 attacks of migraine in a month, prophylactic medications can be used. The various FDA-approved drugs include propranolol, timolol, rimegepant, sodium valproate, topiramate, eptinezumab, erenumab, fremanezumab, and galcanezumab.

Drugs used for prophylaxis of migraine:

  • Beta blockers: Propranolol, metoprolol, timolol, atenolol
  • Antidepressants: Amitriptyline, nortriptyline, imipramine
  • Anticonvulsants: Valproate, topiramate
  • Serotonin antagonist: Methysergide
  • Angiotensin II receptor blocker: Candesartan
  • Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor: Lisinopril
  • Calcium channel blockers: Flunarizine

Other modalities of preventive treatment:

  • Onabotulinum toxin type A is used in the prevention of chronic migraine
  • Neuromodulation: A single-pulse transcranial magnetic stimulation (sTMS) is delivered with a hand-held device (FDA approved) that creates a fluctuating magnetic field which triggers an electric current that modifies cortical excitability.

No role in prophylaxis :

  • Calcium channel blockers: Verapamil, nimodipine, diltiazem. 
  • α2 adrenergic agonist: Clonidine. 
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors: Fluoxetine.

Related Pearl: Simplified diagnostic criteria for migraine

Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4-72 h in patients with a normal physical examination with no other reasonable cause for the headache, and

At least 2 of the following features:

  • Unilateral pain
  • Throbbing pain
  • Aggravation by movement
  • Moderate or severe intensity

Plus at least 1 of the following features:

  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Photophobia and phonophobia

questions.text: A 75 year old man, who was on a tapering dose of methylprednisolone presented with complaints of non productive cough and chest pain. A chest CT scan revealed heterogeneous consolidation in the left upper lobe with cavitation. A biopsy showed the presence of a fungus, as seen in the image below. Voriconazole was started empirically for the infection. Identify the fungus based on its microscopic appearance:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a fungal respiratory infection in a patient taking corticosteroids along with the biopsy findings is suggestive of invasive aspergillosis caused by Aspergillus niger.

The microscopic appearance of Aspergillus niger is characterized by:

  • The vesicle is globular shaped
  • Phialides are in two rows
  • Conidia arise from the entire vesicle and are black

Invasive disease may develop as an acute pneumonic process following the inhalation and germination of these conidia. Patients at risk for invasive aspergillosis are

  • lymphocytic or myelogenous leukemia and lymphoma
  • stem cell transplant recipients
  • individuals taking corticosteroids
  • AIDS patients with CD4 cell counts less than 50 CD4 cells/μL

Patients may present with fever, cough, dyspnea, and hemoptysis. Hyphae may invade the lumens and walls of blood vessels leading to thrombosis, infarction, and necrosis. Rapid administration of native or lipid formulation of amphotericin B or voriconazole is indicated in these cases.

Other options:

Option A: Aspergillus fumigatus

  • Vesicle is conical or flask shaped.
  • Phialides are arranged in a single row.
  • Conidia arise from upper third of the vesicle, and are hyaline.

Option B: Aspergillus Flavus 

  • Vesicle is globular shaped.
  • Phialides are arranged in one or two rows.
  • Conidia arise from the entire vesicle and are hyaline.

Option D: Penicillium spp has septate hyphae with branched conidiophores. Chains of conidia are produced by 2 rows of sterigmata/phialides and give it a brush or broom appearance.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient is brought with 2nd degree burns involving the anterior aspect of both his lower limbs and the perineal region. According to the rule of 9, what is the BSA involved in this patient?
questions.solution:
19% of the body surface area (BSA) is involved in this patient. The anterior part of each lower limb, according to Wallace’s rule of 9, would be 9% each, and the perineum is considered to be 1% of the total BSA.

Rule of nines (Wallace): It divides the body into segments that are approximately 9% or multiples of 9%, with the perineum forming the remaining 1%. Because of the proportionately larger heads and smaller legs of infants and children, this method must be modified in a pediatric burn injury.

Note: Although Wallace’s rule of nines is more commonly used, the Lund and Browder chart is the most accurate in measuring the percentage of BSA affected in children and overall.

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

Category of burn Age Amount of Ringer’s Lactate given for 24 hours (ml) Target urine output (ml/kg/hour)
2nd/3rd-degree burns Adults  2 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 0.5
<14 years 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1
< 1 year or <30kgs 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA + 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
4th-degree burns / Electrical burns All ages 4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

  • 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2
  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text: As part of the damage control or hemostatic resuscitation for a patient with extensive trauma, you would perform all of the following except:

choices.text: Maintain permissive hypotension until definitive surgical control
Use crystalloid liberally for volume resuscitation
Administer Tranexamic acid to treat coagulopathy
Initiate early use of blood products

questions.solution:
Liberal crystalloid use is not a component of damage control or hemostatic resuscitation.

Damage control resuscitation (DCR) i.e. balanced resuscitation is used in the settings of major trauma. It aims to control hemorrhage and prevent coagulopathy prior to the development of the trauma triad of death (hypothermia, acidosis, and coagulopathy). The components of DCR include:

  • Permissive hypotension until definitive surgical control 
  • Minimize crystalloid use
  • Initial use of 5% hypertonic saline
  • Early use of blood products (PRBCs, FFP, platelets, cryoprecipitate) in the ratio of 1:1:1
  • Consider drugs to treat coagulopathy(rFVIIa, prothrombin complex concentrate, Tranexamic acid)

Related Pearl: ATLS Primary Survey

The steps in the ATLS (Advanced Trauma Life Support) include:

  • Primary survey with simultaneous resuscitation – identify and treat what is killing the patient
  • Secondary survey – proceed to identify all other injuries
  • Definitive care – develop a definitive management plan

Primary Survey: ABCDEs of trauma care:

  • Airway assessment and protection (maintain cervical spine stabilization when appropriate) - If airway obstruction is identified, jaw thrust in cervical injury patients or chin lift is performed.
  • Breathing and ventilation assessment - maintain adequate oxygenation, consider non-invasive or invasive ventilation when indicated
  • Circulation assessment (control hemorrhage, maintain circulating volume and adequate end-organ perfusion) - Two wide-bore (14G to 16G) cannulae are inserted for intravenous fluid resuscitation.
  • Disability assessment - perform a basic neurologic evaluation (AVPU/GCS-P), blood glucose levels
  • Exposure with environmental control - undress the patient and examine thoroughly for possible injuries, prevent hypothermia

Adjuncts to the primary survey:

  • Blood collection - CBC, urea and electrolytes, clotting screen, glucose, toxicology, cross-match
  • ECG, pulse oximetry, ventilatory rate, capnography, ABG analysis
  • Urinary and gastric catheters
  • Radiographs of the chest and pelvis are done as a part of the primary survey preferably with a portable x-ray unit. When required, all these x-rays must also be done on pregnant women.
  • (e)FAST

Other more specialized forms of imaging, such as ultrasound, computerized tomography, angiography, and diagnostic peritoneal lavage, should be considered after the secondary survey and only when the patient is stable after initial resuscitation.

questions.text:
Match the following levels of prevention with their most appropriate examples.
1. Primordial a. Screening children from economically weaker families for malnutrition.
2. Primary b. Reconstructive surgery for patients with residual deformities due to leprosy.
3. Secondary c. Educating children about the harmful effects of smoking.
4. Tertiary d. Use of helmets and eye protection in factories.
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b.

1. Primordial C. Educating children about the harmful effects of smoking.
2. Primary D. Use of helmets and eye protection in factories.
3. Secondary A. Screening children from economically weaker families for malnutrition.
4. Tertiary B. Reconstructive surgery for patients with residual deformities due to leprosy.

Primordial prevention prevents the emergence of risk factors themselves. The interventions revolve around trying to encourage children to adopt healthy lifestyles to prevent health issues in adulthood. Thus, educating children about the harmful effects of smoking is an example of primordial prevention. 

The use of helmets and eye protection in factories is an example of specific protection against industrial hazards. While the risk factors have emerged (working around dangerous machinery), the intervention is to prevent any injury. Thus, it comes under primary prevention. 

Screening children from economically weaker families is an example of early diagnosis. This intervention identifies the children who have malnutrition as soon as possible, to begin treatment. Thus, it comes under secondary prevention.

Reconstruction surgery for leprosy patients is an intervention to rehabilitate patients and bring some extent of physical function back. It comes under disability limitation and rehabilitation, and thus, is a tertiary level of prevention.

Related Pearl: Levels of Prevention

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the management steps in a case of variceal bleeding
  1. Resuscitation and IV Terlipressin/ Octreotide
  2. TIPSS
  3. Balloon tamponade
  4. Endoscopic banding
  5. Shunt surgery
questions.solution:
The correct sequence in the management of variceal bleeding is Resuscitation and IV Terlipressin/ Octreotide -> Endoscopic banding -> Balloon tamponade -> TIPSS -> Shunt surgery.

 Initial management of variceal bleeding involves the following: 

  • Admission to the intensive care unit
  • Placement of two large-bore peripheral cannulae
  • Blood transfusion
  • Correction of coagulopathy with fresh frozen plasma, vitamin K, and tranexamic acid
  • Terlipressin, a splanchnic vasoconstrictor
  • Prophylactic antibiotic
  • Endotracheal intubation for airway protection if bleeding is uncontrolled
  • Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy

TIPSS or Transjugular Intrahepatic Portosystemic Stent Shunt placement involves the placement of a shunt to redirect blood flow and reduce portal pressure. It is very effective but requires analgesia, sedation, and fluoroscopic guidance. It is done if medical and endoscopic measures fail to control bleeding.

Related Pearl: Common sites of porto-systemic anastomosis in portal hypertension

  • Left gastric vein [portal] to Distal oesophageal [systemic] veins: Presents with oesophageal and gastric variceal bleeding
  • Superior rectal veins to Middle and inferior rectal veins: Presents with rectal varices and lower GI tract bleeding
  • Tributaries of left branch of portal vein in ligamentum teres to Periumbilical branches of epigastric and intercostal veins: Forms caput medusae
  • Tributaries of right branch of portal vein overlying ‘bare area’ of liver to Retroperitoneal veins draining into azygos, hemiazygos, lumbar, intercostal and phrenic veins
  • Omental and colonic veins near hepatic and splenic ﬂexures to Retroperitoneal veins near hepatic and splenic ﬂexures

Related Pearl: Causes of Portal Hypertension

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the emergency room after she sustained a fall on the outstretched hand. Examination reveals a supracondylar fracture of the humerus with injury to the structure marked as '?' in the given image. Which of the following muscle actions is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
The muscle action most likely to be affected is the abduction of the thumb.

The structure marked as '?' in the given image is the median nerve in the cubital fossa which is very commonly injured in a supracondylar fracture. Injury to the median nerve affects the abduction of the thumb as this action is carried out by the abductor pollicis brevis muscle, which is innervated by the median nerve.

Identification of the median nerve:

  • In the cubital fossa and forearm- the median nerve is found medial to the brachial artery
  • In the hand- it passes through the carpal tunnel underneath the flexor retinaculum to innervate the muscles of the thenar eminence

Flexor pollicis brevis Median nerve, Ulnar nerve Flexion of MCP joint of the thumb
Opponens pollicis Median nerve Thumb-finger opposition
II. Adductor of thumb    
Adductor pollicis Deep branch of ulnar nerve Thumb adduction
III. Hypothenar eminence    
Abductor digiti minimi Deep branch of ulnar nerve Little finger abduction
Flexor digiti minimi Deep branch of ulnar nerve Little finger flexion
Opponens digiti minimi Deep branch of ulnar nerve Brings 5th metacarpal anteriorly to oppose the thumb

questions.text: A father reports to a pediatrician with his daughter saying that she has episodes of lethargy, irritability, and vomiting right after she drinks fruit juice. Investigations show a deficiency of aldolase B enzyme. Which of the following need not be restricted in the patient's diet?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario with symptoms occurring after ingesting fruit juices (containing fructose) and the absence of aldolase B enzyme point to a diagnosis of hereditary fructose intolerance. While fructose, sucrose, and sorbitol should be restricted in this patient, there is no rationale for restricting galactose.

Fructose 1-phosphate aldolase/aldolase B hydrolyzes fructose-1-phosphate into dihydroxyacetone phosphate and glyceraldehyde. Aldolase B is present in liver, kidneys, and small intestine. Note that while fructose 1-phosphate can be broken down only by aldolase B, fructose 1,6-bisphosphate hydrolysis (during glycolysis) can be undertaken by both aldolase A and aldolase B.

Hereditary fructose intolerance is an autosomal recessive condition due to aldolase B deficiency. Patients are asymptomatic until fructose or sucrose is ingested (usually from fruit, fruit juice, sweetened cereal, or table sugar). It usually presents during infancy when sugar-containing feeds are introduced, but some patients (who are less sensitive) can present at older ages as well. Clinical features include jaundice, hepatomegaly, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, and convulsions. Hereditary fructose intolerance can lead to hypoglycemia despite adequate glycogen reserves because fructose 1-phosphate is an inhibitor of liver glycogen phosphorylase.

Benedict's test is positive as fructose is present in the urine and it is a reducing sugar. Reduced levels of aldolase B activity in the liver and demonstration of pathogenic variants in ALDOB gene on molecular genetic testing give a definitive diagnosis. Treatment involves complete cessation of fructose, sucrose (glucose + fructose), and sorbitol (metabolized to fructose) from the diet.

The image below summarizes the metabolic pathway of fructose:

questions.text: Which of the following describes Brown's sign seen in a case of glomus tumor?

choices.text: Red reflex through the intact tympanic membrane
Erosion of the spine of the carotico-jugular crest
Pulsation and blanching with increased ear canal pressure
Tumor appearing to arise from the floor of the middle ear

questions.solution:
Pulsation and blanching of the tumour on increasing ear canal pressure using Siegel's speculum is known as Brown's sign. This is seen in intratympanic glomus tumours.

Glomus tumours are the most common benign tumours of the middle ear. The tumours comprise paraganglionic cells and arise from glomus bodies, which resemble carotid bodies. Glomus bodies are present in the dome of the jugular bulb and on the promontory along the course of the tympanic branch of the IX cranial nerve. 

Depending on the area from which it arises, they are classified as Glomus jugulare (dome of the jugular bulb) and Glomus tympanicum (promontory of the middle ear). The presentation of glomus tumours is as follows:

Intratympanic presentation

  • Progressive hearing loss
  • Pulsatile tinnitus is synchronous with pulse and can be stopped by carotid pressure
  • Otoscopy: Red reflex through the intact tympanic membrane 
  • Rising sign when tumour arises from the floor of the middle ear
  • Pulsation or Brown sign: the tumour pulsates and blanches when the ear canal pressure is raised with Siegel's speculum. This reverses when pressure is released.

Polyp presentation

  • Profuse bleeding
  • Otorrhea if there is a secondary infection
  • Red vascular polyp filling the meatus that bleeds easily

Cranial nerve palsies

  • Dysphagia and hoarseness with unilateral paralysis of the soft palate and pharynx (CN IX and X)
  • Vocal cord paralysis  (CN X)
  • Weakness of the trapezius and sternomastoid muscles (CN XI)
  • Atrophy of half of the tongue (CN XII)

The audible may be bruit over the mastoid. The Phelp sign on CT is the erosion of the spine of the carotico-jugular crest, seen in glomus jugulare tumours. It is intact in glomus tympanicum.

Related Pearl: Signs in Glomus Tumors

Sign
Seen on
What is seen

Otoscopy
Tumor arising from floor
Brown sign
Otoscopy
On increasing the ear canal pressure, tumor pulsates and then blanches

CT

questions.text: Which of the following processes show physiological necroptosis?
questions.solution:
The formation of the mammalian bone growth plate shows physiological necroptosis. 

Necroptosis is programmed cell death without caspase activation. As there is no caspase activation, only one pathway is seen in necroptosis. The process of necroptosis starts in a manner similar to that of the extrinsic form of apoptosis by ligation of a receptor by its ligand. It can be both physiological and pathological. 

Examples

  • Pathological: Cell death in steatohepatitis, acute pancreatitis, ischemia-reperfusion injury, neurodegenerative diseases like Parkinson's disease, and viral infections
  • Physiological: Formation of the mammalian bone growth plate

Mechanism:

  • TNF-α activates TNFR1 and, in turn, induces the recruitment of RIP1 and RIP3 kinase and other proteins to form a complex.
  • This complex includes caspase 8. But, caspase 8 is not activated in this pathway.
  • This leads to the formation of a necrosome which causes metabolic alterations leading to a loss of ATP and generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and nitrogen species.
  • Acute ischemia causes intracellular and mitochondrial calcium overload that worsens during reperfusion. Reperfusion results in cell membrane damage that allows a further influx of calcium into the cell. The calcium overload increases the permeability of mitochondria with resultant ATP depletion.
  • There is the disintegration of the cell membrane, which causes the cell contents to leak out of the cell leading to an acute inflammatory response.
  • There is a loss of cell and organelle integrity leading to cell death by necroptosis.

Apoptosis is a pathway of cell death that is induced by a closely regulated suicide program in which cells destined to die, activate intrinsic enzymes that degrade the cells nuclear and cytoplasmic proteins. Physiological apoptosis is seen in the following situations:

  • Removal of cells that are in excess during development
  • Involution of hormone-dependent tissues on hormone withdrawal such as endometrial cell breakdown during the menstrual cycle(Option D), ovarian follicular atresia in menopause(Option A), and regression of the lactating breast after weaning.
  • Cell turnover in proliferating cell populations
  • Elimination of potentially harmful self-reactive lymphocytes(Option B)
  • Death of host cells that have served their useful purpose

questions.text: A 42-year-old diabetic male has been in the post-operative surgery ward with a central line inserted for the past 8 days. He develops a high-grade fever, cough, confusion and his respiratory rate is 32/minute and BP is 100/70 mm Hg. Laboratory results show raised blood counts and 1,3 Beta D Glucan levels of ≥80 pg/mL. Which of the following organisms is not a likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
In the given diagnostic assay 1,3 beta D Glucan assay levels of ≥80 pg/mL is considered positive. Invasive cryptococcosis is not detected by this assay.  

The given scenario can be a case of invasive fungal infection (candida, aspergillus ) which can occur in post-operative cases through contaminated central lines.

1,3-β-d-glucan (BDG) is a cell wall polysaccharide found in most fungi, more commonly in candida, aspergillus and pneumocystis jiroveci.  

However, it is not used in the diagnosis of cryptococci, the zygomycetes, and Blastomyces dermatitidis, which either lack the glucan entirely or produce it at minimal levels.  

This assay is a chromogenic, quantitative enzyme immunoassay (EIA) designed to detect beta D Glucan by using purified, lysed horseshoe crab (Limulus polyphemus) amebocytes. These cells contain components of the Limulus clotting cascade, including factors C and G, which initiate coagulation in the presence of bacterial liposaccharide and Beta D Glucan, respectively. By eliminating factor C from the lysate, the manufacturers limit activation of the cascade to BDG alone.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male comes with pain in the knee joint. The radiograph is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette of a patient presenting with knee pain and a soap bubble appearance on the radiograph points to a diagnosis of a giant cell tumor or osteoclastoma.

It is a locally aggressive tumor affecting the epiphyses of the long bones especially the distal femur, proximal tibia, distal radius, and proximal humerus.

It is seen in patients of the age group 20 to 45 years. Patients can present with pain, increasing mass, and pathological fractures. It can extend into the soft tissue and present as a soft tissue mass.

The gross specimen of GCT appears as meaty, purplish tissue with soft yellow areas. Histopathology shows osteoclast-like giant cells along with scattered round and spindle-shaped mononuclear cells with bands of cellular and collagenous fibrous tissue.

Radiological findings are eccentric, expansile, lobulated lytic lesions with a narrow zone of transition giving it a soap bubble appearance.

Treatment consists of intralesional curettage or a thorough curettage for advanced lesions. Anti-RANKL antibodies such as denosumab can be used to treat advanced stage 3 lesions.

Other options: 

Option A: Ewing's sarcoma more commonly occurs in males between the ages of 10-20 years in the diaphyseal region. Onion-peel appearance due to the deposition of periosteal reaction in layers is seen in the radiograph image below: 

Option B: Adamantinoma is a low-grade malignant tumor arising in patients of age 20-40 years. It presents with pre-tibial pain and swelling since it commonly affects the tibial diaphysis. Radiographs reveal expansion and lobulated cystic lesion with cortical disruption.

Option C: Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignancy of bone that produces osteoid matrix or mineralized bone. It has a bimodal age distribution. X-ray shows periosteal reaction and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance as shown below.

Related Pearl: Most common sites of primary bone tumors

EPIPHYSEAL :

  • Chondroblastoma 
  • Giant cell tumor in adults
  • Articular osteochondroma (trevor’s disease)
  • Clear cell chondrosarcoma 

DIAPHYSEAL:

  • Round cell lesions-Ewing’s sarcoma 
  • Lymphoma
  • Multiple myeloma
  • Adamantinoma
  • Osteoid osteoma
  • Fibrous dysplasia
  • Histiocytosis
  • Osteoblastoma

METAPHYSEAL:

  • Chondrosarcoma (Note:Clear cell chondrosarcoma is epiphyseal)
  • Enchondroma
  • Osteochondroma
  • Bone cyst
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Giant cell tumor in children

questions.text:
A researcher is preparing to do a cohort study in the gastroenterology wards to determine the association of H. pylori with inflammatory bowel disease. Which of the following are true regarding the advantages of this study?
  1. Attrition is low
  2. Incidence can be calculated
  3. Provides a direct estimate of relative risk
  4. Allows study of multiple outcomes from the same exposure
  5. Hawthorne effect is reduced
questions.solution:
Among the given statements, the true statements regarding the advantages of cohort studies are 2, 3, and 4 only.

The advantages of cohort study are the following:

  • The incidence can be calculated.
  • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied simultaneously
  • Provides a direct estimate of relative risk
  • Dose-response ratios can be calculated
  • Bias like misclassification can be minimized

The disadvantages of cohort study are the following:

  • The study of rare diseases is not possible
  • Takes a longer time to complete the study and obtain results
  • Attrition is high. It refers to a reduction in the number of participants in the study. A substantial proportion of the original cohort may be lost due to migration, loss of interest, or non-cooperation.
  • The selection of comparison groups that are representative of the exposed and unexposed segments of the population is a limiting factor
  • Changes in the standard methods or diagnostic criteria of the disease
  • High costs to conduct the study
  • Ethical problems
  • The study tends to alter the behavior of subjects. For example, a study on the association of smoking with lung cancer may lead the study subjects to reduce or quit smoking. This is known as the Hawthorne effect.

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the chlorine demand of water?

choices.text: Chlorine which appears after the break point has been reached
Chlorine required to oxidize all organic matter and destroy the bacteria
Chlorine which prevents subsequent microbial contamination during storage

questions.solution:
Chlorine demand is the amount of chlorine required to destroy the bacteria and oxidize all the organic material present in the water. 

The chlorine demand of water is measured using Horrock's apparatus. The point at which the chlorine demand of the water is met is referred to as the break-point. Any chlorine added after the break-point will lead to the appearance of free residual chlorine in the water (option A). This free chlorine prevents further contamination of water during storage and distribution (option C).

Orthotolidine test (option D) is used to measure the free and combined chlorines present in the water. A reading within the first 10 seconds signifies free chlorine, while a reading taken after 15 minutes signifies the total amount of chlorines in the water (free and combined). Orthotolidine-arsenite test is able to measure the free and combined chlorines separately in the water.

Related Pearl: Chlorination of Water

  • Chlorination is widely used for the large-scale purification of drinking water.
  • It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.
  • It oxidizes iron, manganese, and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odour producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.
  • The action of chlorine:
    • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
      HOCl → H + OCl
    • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
    • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
  • Principles of chlorination:
    • The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
    • The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.
    • Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.
    •  Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.
    • The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.
  • Methods of chlorination:
    • Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action, and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for the application of chlorine gas.
    • Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.
    • Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.
  • Break point chlorination:
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.
    • Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.
    • In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines would have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.
    • This corresponding dosage to achieve the appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.
    • It is also called controlled superchlorination
    • Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.
  • Orthotolidine (OT) test:
    • It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.
    • The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in a 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.
    • When added to water that contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorine.
  • Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:
    • This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.
    • It determines free and combined chlorine separately.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with a history of weakness and fatigue for the past three months. There is no history of alcohol consumption or intake of any drugs. A complete blood count and peripheral smear show evidence of megaloblastic anemia and a normal reticulocyte count. He is found to have vitamin B12 deficiency on further laboratory testing. What is the most likely cause of anemia in this patient?
questions.solution:
Autoimmune gastritis refers to a chronic, diffuse inflammatory disease of the stomach that is restricted to the body and fundus. This disorder typically features diffuse atrophic gastritis, antibodies to parietal cells and the intrinsic factor, and increased serum gastrin due to G-cell hyperplasia. Due to the neutralization of the intrinsic factor, there is decreased absorption of vitamin B12. As a result, all lineages of bone marrow precursors show asynchronous maturation between the nucleus and cytoplasm (megaloblastic cells), and the peripheral blood displays megaloblastic anemia.

Megaloblastic anemia that is caused by malabsorption of vitamin B12, due to deficiency of the intrinsic factor, is called pernicious anemia. Circulating antibodies to parietal cells occur in 90% of patients with pernicious anemia. Two-thirds of patients display an antibody to the intrinsic factor that prevents its combination with vitamin B12, thereby preventing the formation of the complex that is later absorbed in the ileum.

The other options are not the causes of pernicious anemia.

Related Pearl: Causes of Megaloblastic Anemia

Vitamin B12 Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Vegetarianism
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Intrinsic factor deficiency
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Gastrectomy
    • Malabsorption states
    • Diffuse intestinal disease (e.g., lymphoma, systemic sclerosis)
    • Ileal resection
    • Ileitis
  • Competitive parasitic uptake
    • Fish tapeworm infestation
    • Bacterial overgrowth in blind loops and diverticula of bowel

Folic Acid Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Alcoholism
    • Infancy
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Malabsorption states
    • Intrinsic intestinal disease
    • Anticonvulsants
    • Oral contraceptives
  • Increased Loss
    • Hemodialysis
  • Increased Requirement
    • Pregnancy, infancy
    • Disseminated cancer
    • Markedly increased hematopoiesis
  • Impaired Utilization
    • Folic acid antagonists
    • Unresponsive to vitamin B12 or folic acid therapy
    • Metabolic inhibitors of DNA synthesis and/or folate metabolism

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of congestive heart failure is brought to casualty with complaints of sudden onset dyspnea. Bilateral fine basal crackles can be heard on auscultation. A bolus dose of injection furosemide was given.  Which of the following principles apply to the use of loop diuretics in this patient?
questions.solution:
Furosemide (which was given to the patient) acts on the principle of reduction of preload.

It comes under a class of drugs known as loop diuretics (high ceiling diuretics) and they are the diuretic of choice for reducing edema in heart failure. They act by inhibiting the Na+/K+/2Cl- symporter in the ascending limb of the loop of Henle.

This leads to a decrease in preload by increasing sodium and water excretion and improves ventricular function by reducing the circulatory volume. Intravenous furosemide also increases systemic venous capacitance.

The history of a patient who is known to have congestive heart failure being brought with complaints of sudden onset dyspnoea and bilateral fine basal crackles is suggestive of pulmonary edema. Heart failure is the inability of the heart to pump an adequate cardiac output for meeting physiological demands and can occur due to systolic/diastolic dysfunction. There is an elevation of filling pressure to compensate for the reduced cardiac output, but such an increase in stroke volume can produce congestive features similar to the scenario mentioned above. The main goal of drug therapy would be to relieve the congestive symptoms and restore cardiac function.

Other options:

Option B: In heart failure, low cardiac output causes activation of the neurohumoral regulation (renin-angiotensin-aldosterone-system and sympathetic nervous system) that leads to an increase in sodium and water reabsorption as well as elevation of blood pressure (causing an increase in afterload). Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers, and mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists act by the principle of reducing neurohumoral modulation.

Option C: Hydralazine act on the principle of reducing afterload by dilating resistance vessels. Reduction of afterload is beneficial in heart failure as it allows the heart to pump out blood against a lower resistance. 

Option D: Positive inotropic agents such as cardiac glycosides (Na+/K+ATPase inhibition - digoxin) and cAMP-dependant drugs (epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dobutamine) act on the principle of increasing cardiac contractility. This is beneficial as it allows to produce enough force for adequate organ perfusion.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in heart failure

Bumetanide

questions.text: Which of the following is the cellular receptor for the RNA virus shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image showing a bullet-shaped virus, with nonsegmented single-stranded RNA is characteristic of rabies viruses belonging to the family Rhabdoviridae. The cellular receptor for the rabies virus is the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor.

Rabies is a fatal infection of the central nervous system transmitted by the bite of a rabid animal. It is caused by rhabdoviruses. These viruses are enveloped, rod or bullet shaped and contain single-stranded RNA. This virus attaches to the cells via its glycoprotein spikes and the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor acts as the cellular receptor.

Other options:

Option A: CR2 or CD21 is the receptor for the C3d component of complement. It also acts as the viral receptor for EBV.

Option A: CD4 is expressed on macrophages and T lymphocytes are the viral receptor for HIV. Chemokine receptors CXCR4 and CCR5 act as coreceptors.

Option A: SARS-CoV-2 enters the host cell via the ACE2 receptor.

questions.text: Sexual gratification obtained by merely feeling female body parts or articles belonging to a woman is known as ______
questions.solution:
Sexual gratification obtained by merely seeing or feeling female body parts /articles belonging to women is known as fetishism.

Fetishism is a type of paraphilia where the sexual focus is on a particular object which is associated with the human body (a shoe for example). This is found mostly in men. The object of desire usually plays a part during masturbation or sexual intercourse.

Types of Sexual perversions:

  • Eonism/Transvestism: Sexual gratification is achieved by wearing the dress of the opposite sex.
  • Fetishism: Gets sexual gratification by merely seeing or feeling female body parts, certain articles belonging to a woman, such as a sari, footwear, stockings, undergarments, hankies, hairpins, etc.
  • Masochism: Sexual gratification is obtained by being tortured by the sex partner. (opposite of Sadism)
  • Sadism: Sexual gratification is achieved by inducing pain in the sex partner.
  • Voyeurism/Peeping Tom or Scotophilia: Sexual gratification by secretly watching others getting undressed, taking a bath, or performing sexual intercourse, etc.
  • Troilism: Gets sexual gratification by watching his own wife performing, sexual intercourse with another man.
  • Nymphomaniac: A type of perversion of excessive sexual desire in a woman
  • Satyriasis: Excessive sexual desire, arousal, and drive in men.
  • Frotteurism: Gets sexual gratification by pressing/rubbing his genital part through the dresses worn, against the body parts of a female in front of him.
  • Undinism: Gets sexual gratification by watching the act of passing urine or defecating by a woman.

Related Pearl: Paraphilic disorders

DSM-5 includes eight specific paraphilic disorders:

Disorder Description
Exhibitionistic disorder Sexual arousal from exposing their genitals to a stranger
Pedophilic disorder Sexual arousal to a prepubescent individual, generally 13 years of age or younger
Voyeuristic disorder Sexual arousal from observing other's sexual activities
Sexual sadism disorder Sexual arousal upon inflicting suffering or humiliation  
Frotteuristic disorder Sexual arousal by touching or rubbing against a non-consenting person
Fetishistic disorder Sexual arousal from the use of inert objects, such as female
undergarments
Transvestic disorder Sexual arousal from cross-dressing
Sexual masochism Sexual arousal from being humiliated, beaten, bound, or made to suffer

As per ICD-11, the first five are included under paraphilic disorders. Two other subclasses in addition to this are:

  • Other paraphilic disorders involving non-consenting individuals (e.g., arousal patterns involving corpses or animals)
  • Paraphilic disorders involving solitary behaviour or consenting individuals (e.g., asphyxophilia, fetishism, fetishistic transvestism).

questions.text: An 18-year-old patient presents with a contaminated wound on his right leg following a road traffic accident. He has received complete tetanus immunization and the last dose was 2 years ago. Which of the following should be done in the management of this patient?

choices.text: One dose of Td + tetanus immunoglobulin

questions.solution:
Even though this patient has a contaminated wound, the last dose of his tetanus immunization was 2 years ago (≤5 years ago). Thus, nothing further is required to be done for this patient. 

Related Pearl: Post exposure prophylaxis for tetanus

Prophylaxis is given based on patient category:

A. Full immunization or a booster dose within the past 5 years.

B. Full immunization or a booster dose > 5 years ago but < 10 years.

C. Full immunization or a booster dose > 10 years ago.

D. Unknown or never taken immunization

Category Clean wound Unclean wound
A Only wound care Only wound care
B Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose
C Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose + Human tetanus immunoglobulin 
D Wound care + TT complete course Wound care + TT complete course + Human tetanus immunoglobulin

questions.text: All of the following anti-retroviral drugs are given orally except______
questions.solution:
Enfuvirtide is an entry (fusion) inhibitor. It is the only approved parenteral antiretroviral drug and therefore, injection-site reactions like pain, erythema, and induration are most frequently seen.

Didanosine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI). Peripheral neuropathy characterized by pain, numbness, and tingling in glove and stock pattern, and pancreatitis are the most adverse effects of this drug.

Abacavir is also an NRTI. The most serious adverse effect is a hypersensitivity syndrome characterized by fever, maculopapular rash, abdominal pain, gastrointestinal upset, malaise, and fatigue.

Efavirenz is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI). Adverse effects are dizziness, impaired concentration, dysphoria, disturbing or vivid dreams, and insomnia.

questions.text: “Pie in the sky” field defects are seen in ______.
questions.solution:
The term "pie in the sky" defects refers to superior quadrantic hemianopia. They are produced when the inferior fibres of the optic radiations in the temporal lobe (Meyer’s loop) are involved.

"Pie in the floor" defects

  • Refer to inferior quadrantic hemianopia
  • Involvement of the superior fibres of optic radiations in the parietal lobe (Baum's loop)

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with type 2 neurofibromatosis was referred for hearing rehabilitation after excision of bilateral acoustic neuromas. The surgery notes mention that the bilateral 8th cranial nerves were severed during the surgery. Which of the following can be considered for further management?
questions.solution:
Auditory brainstem implant (ABI) is considered for management when bilateral 8th cranial nerves are severed as it directly stimulates the cochlear nuclear complex in the brainstem.

Auditory brainstem implants are modified cochlear implants designed to bypass the 8th nerve and directly stimulate the cochlear nuclear complex. Such damage to the 8th cranial nerve can occur during surgery for bilateral vestibular schwannomas. In the case of unilateral acoustic neuromas and subsequent nerve damage, ABI is not necessary as hearing is possible from the contralateral side. 

Other options: All the other options bypass different parts of the external and middle ear to reach the cochlea and require an intact 8th nerve for further transmitting signals. Thus they are not useful in this case.

Option A: Vibrant Soundbridge Device is a semi-implantable hearing aid that picks up sound from the environment and transmits it to the ossicles of the middle ear and then the cochlea. It is used in patients older than 18 years with moderate-to-severe sensorineural hearing loss.

Option B: A cochlear implant is an electronic device that replaces the organ of Corti. When the hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve. Thus, an intact vestibulocochlear (CN VIII) nerve is a prerequisite for cochlear implant surgery and cannot be used in this case.

Option C: Bone-anchored hearing aid (BAHA) works through bone conduction to bypass the external and middle ear and transmit signals directly to the cochlea. It is primarily used for cases of conductive hearing loss.

Related Pearl: Cochlear implant

A cochlear implant replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve.

Indication: Bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss i.e. > 70 dB.

Components:

Preoperative investigation: Complete audiological evaluation and HRCT and MRI (to detect the structure of cochlea, cochlear nerve and CNS abnormalities).

Surgical approach: Two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation are the facial recess approach (via facial recess) and the pericanal technique (via EAC).

Postoperatively: Activation of the device after 3-4 weeks and evaluation is by HRCT (MRI is contraindicated).

Contraindications:

  • Absence of cochlea (Michel aplasia)
  • Deafness due to absent cochlear nerve, lesions of cochlear nerve or lesions of the central auditory pathway

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding Miller-Fisher syndrome?
  1. Associated with ophthalmoplegia
  2. Associated with ataxia due to limb weakness
  3. Type of axonal neuropathy
  4. Associated with anti-GQ1b antibodies
  5. Associated with areflexia of the limbs
questions.solution:
Miller-Fisher syndrome (MFS) is a variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS). Like Guillain-Barré syndrome, symptoms may be preceded by an acute infectious process, usually involving the respiratory or the gastrointestinal tract. It is a demyelinating type of neuropathy, not axonal (statement 3). It classically presents as a triad of:

  • Ataxia
  • Areflexia, without limb weakness
  • Ophthalmoplegia

The condition is usually not associated with limb weakness in most patients (statement 2). Furthermore, the ataxia is due to the demyelination of Ib nerve fibers coming from the muscle spindle, and is thus sensory ataxia. MFS is strongly associated with anti-GQ1b antibodies.

questions.text:
Match the curves in the given graph with the changes occurring after death.
  1. Lividity
  2. Rigor
  3. Cooling
  4. Decomposition
questions.solution:
The graph with the changes occurring after death plotted against time is as follows:

Algor mortis/postmortem cooling is one of the early changes occurring after death. After death, the body loses heat mainly by conduction and convection. Up to the first hour, a temperature plateau may be seen due to the heat generated by residual metabolic activities of dying tissues. This is followed by a linear rate of cooling over the next 12 to 16 hours. The temperature rarely reaches the ambient temperature, most likely due to bacterial action with decomposition setting in. The curve is sigmoid or inverted S-shaped. 

Rigor mortis/cadaveric rigidity/death stiffening refers to the stiffening and shortening of muscles following death. It begins 1 to 2 hours after death and lasts for 24 to 48 hours in total. It starts disappearing after 12 hours.

Postmortem lividity/livor mortis develops in the dependent portions of the body due to engorged vessels showing through the skin. It develops shortly after death and may not be visible for up to 1 hour. It deepens in intensity between 1 to 4 hours and reaches a maximum by 6 to 12 hours. Lividity persists until putrefaction sets in.

Decomposition or putrefaction refers to the disintegration of the body tissues after death. Multiplication of the bacteria begins within 4 hours after death and by 18 to 36 hours gases collect in the body causing bloating and distortion. The body then undergoes putrefaction and liquefaction of the tissues 5 to 10 days after death.

questions.text: A patient complains of dysphagia and cough for the past 6 months and also has a history of atopy. You notice the following finding during endoscopy and advice biopsy. To make a definitive diagnosis of the likely condition, considering the clinical picture, the biopsy specimen should reveal a minimum of ___________
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the endoscopic findings is suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis and to make a definitive diagnosis the biopsy specimen should reveal a minimum of 15 eosinophils per high-power field

Eosinophilic esophagitis shows the presence of a series of rings in the esophagus. This appearance is called as the feline esophagus or ringed esophagus.

It is characterized by eosinophilic infiltration of the oesophageal wall, presumably of allergic or idiopathic origin. The most common presenting symptom is dysphagia, and more than half have some history of atopy. 

Dysphagia may occur with liquids or solids, but solid food dysphagia is most common.

The treatment of eosinophilic esophagitis is largely symptomatic and includes testing for food allergies and the elimination of identified food items from the diet. Second-line therapy includes inhaled or ingested corticosteroids. If dysphagia is not relieved with steroids, it may be necessary to dilate the  esophagus.

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of base excision repair in order.
  1. Endonuclease excises the sugar backbone
  2. Glycosylase removes the altered base
  3. DNA-polymerase adds a nucleotide
  4. Creation of apurinic/apyrimidinic site
  5. DNA-ligase seals the nick
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of steps in base excision repair is: 

  • Glycosylase removes the altered base
  • Creation of apurinic/apyrimidinic site
  • Endonuclease excises the sugar backbone
  • DNA-polymerase adds a nucleotide
  • DNA-ligase seals the nick

Deamination reactions occur in the DNA either spontaneously or because of toxins. They lead to the formation of uracil (from cytosine), xanthine (from guanine), and hypoxanthine (from adenine). Uracil, xanthine, and hypoxanthine are not normal constituents of the DNA, and thus need to be removed. This is done by base excision repair. Base-specific glycosylase first removes the altered base to create an apurinic/apyramidinic site. After this, endonuclease and lyase enzymes remove the deoxyribose backbone of the DNA. DNA polymerase adds a nucleotide to fill in the gap, and DNA ligase seals the nick.

Related Pearl: Human Diseases of DNA Damage Repair

questions.text:
A sputum sample shows gram-positive cocci on microscopy. The organism is catalase-negative and shows partial hemolysis on blood agar. Which of the following tests can be performed to differentiate between Streptococcus pneumoniae and viridans streptococci?
  1. Optochin sensitivity
  2. Bacitracin sensitivity
  3. Growth in 6.5% NaCl
  4. Bile solubility
  5. Novobiocin sensitivity
questions.solution:
Gram-positive cocci with catalase negative test and partial α hemolysisis suggestive of Streptococcus. Optochin sensitivity and bile solubility tests can be done to further differentiate between Streptococcus pneumoniae and viridans streptococci.

Gram-positive cocci are differentiated based on the catalase test. Staphylococci are catalase-positive while streptococci are catalase negative. Streptococci are further differentiated based on hemolysis on blood agar. Partial α hemolysis can be seen in cases of Streptococcus pneumoniae and viridans streptococci. These are differentiated based on optochin sensitivity and bile solubility tests which are both positive in Streptococcus pneumonia.

Other options:

Option 2: Bacitracin sensitivity is a characteristic of Streptococcus pyogenes

Option 3: Enterococcus species (S.faecalis and other enterococci) show growth in 6.5% NaCl.

Option 5: Novobiocin sensitivity is seen in Staphylococcus epidermidis.

questions.text:
Which of the following vaccines are indicated in elderly patients with no other risk factors?
  1. Influenza
  2. Haemophilus influenzae
  3. Recombinant zoster
  4. Pneumococcal
  5. Meningococcal
questions.solution:
In otherwise healthy elderly patients, the recommended vaccines are:

  • Inactivated or recombinant influenza vaccine, 1 dose annually
  • Td or Tdap booster, every 10 years
  • Zoster recombinant vaccine
  • Pneumococcal vaccine
  • COVID-19 vaccine

The zoster recombinant vaccine is not indicated for the prevention of varicella. This vaccine is given to prevent episodes of herpes zoster and post-herpetic neuralgia. It is indicated regardless of a previous episode of zoster.

All adults ≥65 years of age should also receive pneumococcal vaccination. This is in the form of pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV) first, followed by pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23) after an interval.

questions.text: On performing the test shown below the patient is able to breathe better. Which of the following conditions may falsely produce this result?
questions.solution:
The test shown in the image is the Cottle test. It is positive since the patient is able to breathe better. A false positive result is seen in the collapse of nasal ala when the ala opens up to allow better breathing and is not related to the nasal valve.

In this test, the cheek is drawn laterally while the patient breathes quietly. If the nasal airway improves on the test side, the test is positive and indicates an abnormality of the vestibular component of the nasal valve. The nasal airway improves as the nasal valve opens upon performing this maneuver. This helps us in finding the site of obstruction.

The narrowest portion of the nasal passage is known as the nasal valve area. The nasal valve is the specific slit-like segment present between the caudal margin of the upper lateral cartilage and the septum. A positive Cottle test can be seen in deviated nasal septum (Option B), collapsed nasal valve (Option A), and valve stenosis where the nasal valve is affected. Scars/ webs in the valve (Option D) prevent the valve from opening up when the Cottle test is performed and thus, give a false negative result.

Related Pearl: Boundaries of the nasal valve

  • Laterally: Lower border of upper lateral cartilage and fibrofatty tissue and anterior end of inferior turbinate
  • Medially: Cartilaginous nasal septum
  • Caudally: Floor of the pyriform aperture

The nasal valve is the narrowest part and offers maximum resistance to airflow

The correct match is

Posterior & Lateral Control symphathetic system
