Posterior Regulate temperature(response to cold)
Lateral

Initiate eating and increase food intake (Hunger center)
Increase water intake (Thirst center)
Medial

Inhibit eating and reduce food intake (satiety center)

Suprachiasmatic

 Controls circadian rhythm

questions.text: A sugarcane farmer presents with dyspnea and cough for the last 3 weeks. HRCT shows bilateral ground glass opacities. Bronchoalveolar lavage is done and the CD4+/CD8+ ratio is found to be < 1. Lung biopsy shows poorly formed noncaseating granulomas. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In a patient with cough and dyspnea for the last 3 weeks, with ground glass opacities on HRCT, CD4+/CD8+ ratio < 1, and poorly formed granulomas on lung biopsy, the most likely diagnosis is hypersensitivity pneumonitis. 

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP) occurs due to inhalational exposure to a number of antigens, causing inflammation of the alveoli and the small airways. The cause of the inflammation is dysregulated Th1 and Th17 immune response (type IV hypersensitivity). 

HP has been divided into 3 forms depending on the clinical manifestations:

  1. Acute HP manifests within 8 hours of exposure to the antigen. The symptoms include fever with chills, malaise, and dyspnea. There is complete resolution of the symptoms within hours to days if there is no further exposure to the antigen. 
  2. In subacute HP, the systemic and pulmonary symptoms develop insidiously over a few weeks, like in this patient. Complete resolution of symptoms is seen here as well, but it takes a longer time. 
  3. Chronic HP presents with an even slower course — with cough, dyspnea, weight loss, and clubbing of digits. Unlike other forms, there is permanent impairment of the airways to some extent in chronic HP. This is irreversible and does not respond to the removal of inciting agents from the patient's environment. 

In subacute HP, HRCT shows ground glass opacities and centrilobular nodules. In chronic HP, subpleural honeycombing is seen, but unlike idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, there is sparing of the base of the lungs. Either obstructive or restrictive patterns may be seen on pulmonary function testing. Detection of IgG antibodies against specific antigens is an adjunctive investigation in the diagnosis of HP.

Bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage shows a CD4+/CD8+ lymphocyte ratio < 1 in most cases of HP. Lung biopsy shows the formation of noncaseating granulomas, but they are poorly defined.

The mainstay of treatment of HP is avoidance of the offending antigen. However, in subacute and chronic forms of the disease, there is a role of steroids as well. 

Other options:

Option A: A close differential in this case can be sarcoidosis. However, sarcoidosis is characterized by well-defined noncaseating granulomas, and CD4+/CD8+ ratio of >1 in BAL. Furthermore, the presence of a clear-cut risk factor in this patient makes the diagnosis more likely to be HP.

Option B: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis will not show granulomatous inflammation on lung biopsy. Furthermore, the HRCT findings in IPF include honeycombing and traction bronchiectasis. The presence of ground glass opacities is only transient, and extensive ground glass opacities should prompt an alternative diagnosis.

Option D: Tuberculosis will present as upper lobe infiltrates with cavitation on CT scan. The sputum smear microscopy will be positive for acid-fast bacilli and nucleic acid amplification test.

questions.text: What is the size of the given blade used for minor surgical procedures?
questions.solution:
The blade shown in the image is of size 15 and is used for minor surgical procedures.

The 11-blade is used for skin incisions (eg. incision and drainage) and arteriotomy.

The 22-blade is often used for abdominal incisions.

questions.text: A patient with diabetes mellitus and hypertension comes to the OPD. Physical examination findings are given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate screening test?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with hypertension and diabetes, and having frontal bossing and a protruding lower jaw as shown in the image is suggestive of acromegaly. The screening test for acromegaly is serum IGF-1 levels.

Pituitary tumours are mainly classified as functioning and non-functioning tumours. Functioning tumours secrete hormones and thus lead to specific endocrine syndromes such as:

  • Acromegaly in growth hormone-secreting tumours
  • Cushing syndrome in ACTH secreting tumours
  • Galactorrhea, amenorrhea, and infertility in prolactin-secreting tumours

Non-functioning tumours produce symptoms due to mass effects. The symptoms include headaches, and visual impairment such as bitemporal hemianopia, and hypopituitarism.

The physiological actions of the growth hormone are mostly mediated through IGF-1, which is synthesized in the liver. Since the growth hormone is released in a pulsatile manner, serum IGF-1 levels are usually measured in order to assess growth hormone activity. Serum IGF-1 level is decreased in pituitary failure, defect or blockade of GH receptor. Since the low-calorie state is associated with growth hormone resistance, IGF-1 is also decreased in conditions such as cachexia, malnutrition, and sepsis. Serum IGF-1 level is increased in acromegaly.

The diagnosis of acromegaly is confirmed by demonstrating non-suppression of GH after 2 hours of an oral glucose load.

Other options:

Option A: Overnight dexamethasone suppression test is done for confirming the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome.

Option B: Since the growth hormone is released in a pulsatile manner, it is not possible to test for growth hormone levels directly in cases of acromegaly.

Option D: Short synacthen test is done to confirm the diagnosis of primary adrenal insufficiency or Addison's disease.

Related Pearl: Tests for Acromegaly

Screening test:

The single best test for the diagnosis of acromegaly is the measurement of serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1). A normal serum IGF-1 concentration is strong evidence that the patient does not have acromegaly.

Confirmatory test:

GH suppression test: 75 g of oral glucose (OGTT- oral glucose tolerance test) is administered to the patient. Blood GH levels are checked at 30, 60, 90, 120 min (i.e over 2 hours) after the glucose load. Normally, glucose suppresses GH and it falls to <1 ng/mL. If GH >1 ng/mL, it is diagnostic of acromegaly.

 

Related Pearl: Classification of Pituitary Adenomas with Associated Syndromes

The various types of pituitary tumors are listed in decreasing order of frequency:

Adenoma cell origin

Hormone

Clinical features

Lactotroph

Prolactin

Galactorrhea and amenorrhea (in females)

Sexual dysfunction, infertility

Gonadotroph

 FSH, LH subunits

Hypogonadism, mass effects, and hypopituitarism

Somatotroph 

GH

Gigantism (children)

Acromegaly (adults)

Corticotroph

 ACTH

Cushing's disease

Nelson's syndrome

Mammosomatotroph

Prolactin, GH

Hypogonadism, galactorrhea, acromegaly

Thyrotroph 

TSH

Hyperthyroidism

 

GH: Growth hormone

ACTH: Adrenocorticotropic hormone

TSH: Thyroid-stimulating hormone

FSH: Follicle-stimulating hormone

LH: Luteinizing hormone

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy who is a known case of asthma is rushed to the casualty because of breathlessness for the last 3 hours. The patient is conscious and alert. Physical examination shows tachypnea and tachycardia. There is no fever or sputum production. Which of the following are the most appropriate steps for the management of this patient?
  1. Supplemental oxygen
  2. Immediate intubation
  3. Antibiotics
  4. Nebulized salbutamol
  5. Systemic steroids
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute severe asthma. While supplemental oxygen, nebulized salbutamol, and systemic steroids are appropriate, there is no role of antibiotics or intubation in the management of this patient.

Patients with asthma can present with an acute attack of bronchoconstriction, presenting as acute onset breathlessness accompanied by tachypnea and tachycardia. The peak expiratory flow rate during acute severe asthma is often <200 mL/min (between 33-50% of predicted). An arterial blood gas analysis should be mandatorily obtained in such patients. A normal or elevated PaCO2 on ABG indicates respiratory fatigue setting in, and indicates a dangerous situation.

The treatment of acute severe asthma includes:

  • Supplemental oxygen
  • Inhaled bronchodilators such as short-acting β2 agonists like salbutamol. Inhaled ipratropium can also be used as an add-on drug.
  • Systemic glucocorticoids reduce the inflammatory response and enhance the recovery of the patient from the acute exacerbation episode.
  • IV magnesium may provide some additional bronchodilation in some patients.

PEFR should be recorded every 15-30 minutes initially and SpO2 should be maintained above 92%. 

Endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation (statement 2) should be considered only if the patient has features of impending respiratory failure. These include:

  • PEFR <100 mL/min
  • SpO2 < 92% or PaO2 < 60 mmHg, despite the patient being treated with supplemental oxygen
  • Normal or raised PaCO2
  • Silent chest or feeble respiratory efforts
  • Hypotension, bradycardia, or arrhythmias
  • Exhaustion
  • Cyanosis

Antibiotics (statement 3) are not used routinely in the management of acute severe asthma. They are given only if there are signs of infection such as fever and sputum production.

questions.text: A physician believes that the nursing staff is uncomfortable talking to him, when in fact, he is uncomfortable talking with them. The defense mechanism used is
questions.solution:
Projection is a defense mechanism that involves taking our own unacceptable qualities or feelings and ascribing them to other people.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: A newborn infant presents with micrognathia, glossoptosis, and cleft palate. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An infant presenting with micrognathia, glossoptosis, and cleft palate points to the diagnosis of the Pierre Robin sequence.

Micrognathia refers to an abnormally small lower jaw. It can occur at birth (congenital) and may occur alone or be associated with a condition called Pierre Robin sequence, which includes a cleft palate and glossoptosis(a condition where the tongue is positioned further back in the mouth). Micrognathia can lead to difficulties with feeding, overcrowding of teeth, and in severe cases where the tongue is displaced backward, it can cause breathing difficulty. Newborns experiencing breathing difficulties may need to be positioned on their stomach or require assistance with maintaining an open airway through the mouth and throat (oropharyngeal airway). For severely symptomatic infants, surgical interventions such as tongue advancement, mandibular distraction osteogenesis, or tracheotomy may be necessary.

 

Option B: A newborn infant with anuria, renal agenesis, and pulmonary hypoplasia, with a history of oligohydramnios, is charectaristic of Potter's sequence.

Option C: Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is an example of a disorder of genomic imprinting. The genetic locus that is involved in these patients is in chromosome 11 (band p15.5) distal to the WT1 locus. It is characterized by-

  • Neonatal hypoglycemia
  • Macrosomia
  • Macroglossia
  • Hemihyperplasia
  • Omphalocele
  • Visceromegaly
  • Embryonal tumors such as Wilms tumor, hepatoblastoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, and neuroblastoma.

Option D: Prune Belly Syndrome also known as Eagle-Barrett Syndrome is characterized by cryptorchidism, abdominal wall defects, and genitourinary Defects

  • Flabby, Hypotonic & Thin Abdominal Wall - Due to deficient abdominal wall muscles
  • Urethral Obstruction in fetal life.
  • Predominantly seen in males

Associated defects:

  • Posterior urethral valve
  • Vesicoureteric Reflux
  • Limb Anomalies and scoliosis

Treatment :

  • Ureteric dilatation - not until an obstruction occurs
  • Bilateral orchidopexy - for cryptorchidism.
  • Abdominal wall reconstruction - performed in conjugation with orchidopexy at 6-12 months of age through abdominoplasty.

questions.text:
Which of the following diseases show early onset of symptoms in successive generations?
  1. Huntington disease
  2. Phenylketonuria
  3. Myotonic dystrophy
  4. Cystic fibrosis
  5. Fragile X syndrome
questions.solution:
The genetic phenomenon described here is anticipation. Anticipation refers to an earlier onset of disease in successive generations in a pedigree. It is seen in Huntington's disease, myotonic dystrophy, and fragile X syndrome. 

Huntington's disease (HD) is a degenerative disease of the striate neurons. It is caused by an autosomal dominant inheritance of a trinucleotide repeat (CAG) in the HTT gene located on chromosome 4. This results in jerky, hyperkinetic movements called chorea and dementia. It is commonly seen in the 4th and 5th decades of life. Motor problems (the characteristic chorea) precede dementia.

Myotonic dystrophy is caused by expansions of CTG triplet repeats in the noncoding region of the myotonic dystrophy protein kinase (DMPK) gene.  It is associated with skeletal muscle weakness, cataracts, endocrinopathy, and cardiomyopathy. 

Fragile X syndrome is the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability in males. It occurs due to trinucleotide expansion mutations in the FMR1 gene on the long arm of the X chromosome. The affected males are intellectually disabled. Neuropsychiatric features include aggressive behavior, autism spectrum disorder, epilepsy, and anxiety/hyperactivity disorders.

questions.text: Identify the knot given in the image below.
questions.solution:
The knot given in the image is a reef/square knot.

An image showing standard knotting formations is given below.

The surgeon's knot is a square knot that contains a double turn in the first throw. A "throw" is a complete twist of two strands in the square knot. The double turn makes the first throw of the surgeon's knot less likely to slip while the second throw is being tied. It is used when added security is required. A two-throw technique prevents slippage.

A granny knot is a slip knot which is two throws of the same type. It is used to achieve the right tension and is followed by the reef knot for security. An Aberdeen knot is used for the final knot during continuous sutures.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presented with low backache for the past 6 months. The pain improves on exercise but not on rest. Clinical examination shows the presence of enthesitis and anterior uveitis. He is positive for HLA-B27, but pelvic radiograph does not show sacroiliitis. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of low backache which improves on activity but not on rest, along with enthesitis and uveitis, but the absence of sacroiliitis on pelvic radiograph favors the diagnosis of axial spondyloarthritis.

While ankylosing spondylitis shows definite sacroiliitis on a radiograph, axial spondyloarthritis does not have sacroiliitis on preliminary radiological investigations. However, axial spondyloarthritis otherwise presents with similar features, such as positivity for HLA-B27, enthesitis, uveitis, and elevated inflammatory markers. 

The diagnosis of axial spondyloarthritis is based on positive MRI findings, or the compelling symptomatology associated with spondyloarthritis, as described above.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joint. It is more common in young males and has a strong association with HLAB27. Clinically, patients present with recurring backache which worsens in the early morning or with inactivity and improves with exercise. Later they develop fatigue, pain, joint swellings, and heel pain.

Extra-articular manifestations include anterior uveitis, aortic valve insufficiency, heart blocks, and pulmonary fibrosis. Examination findings include loss of lumbar lordosis, increased thoracic kyphosis, diminished spinal movements, and decreased chest expansion.

Radiographic findings include:

  • erosion of sacroiliac joints
  • periarticular sclerosis
  • squaring of vertebrae due to the flattening of normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body
  • bamboo spine appearance due to bridging of adjacent vertebrae
  • wedging of the vertebra leading to hyperkyphosis

The image below shows the bamboo spine appearance of the lumbar vertebrae:

Related Pearl: Joint Involvement in Various Arthritis

 Joint Disorders Joints Commonly Involved

Joints Commonly Spared

 Osteoarthritis

Cervical and lumbosacral spine, PIP, DIP, 1st CMC, hip, knee, 1st MTP, 

 Elbow, Wrist, Ankle, MCP 
Rheumatoid Arthritis Shoulder, Wrist, MCP, PIP, Knee, MTP  DIP 
Ankylosing Spondylitis Sacroiliac joint, intervertebral joints  
Psoriatic Arthritis PIP, DIP Ray distribution* 

*Ray distribution: Joint involvement tends to follow a pattern with all of the joints of one finger involved sparing the adjacent finger completely.

questions.text: Which of the following would you not expect on administering etomidate to a patient?
questions.solution:
Etomidate does not cause hemodynamic instability due to the lack of influence on the sympathetic nervous system and on baroreceptor functions. Due to this characteristic, etomidate is a useful anesthetic agent for patients with poor cardiac function and/or hemorrhagic shock. 

Etomidate is an intravenous anesthetic agent. Etomidate depresses the reticular activating system and mimics the inhibitory effects of GABA. It has a rapid onset with a shorter duration of action. 

Adverse effects include post-operative nausea and vomiting, myoclonus, pain at the injection site, and transient acute adrenal insufficiency.

Option A: Adrenocortical suppression is caused by inhibition of the enzyme 11β-hydroxylase resulting in decreased biosynthesis of cortisol.

Option C: Thrombophlebitis, a side effect of etomidate, may be avoided by the use of the anesthetic's lipid formulation.

Option D: The incidence of myoclonus may be reduced by premedication with a hypnotic agent such as midazolam.

questions.text: A patient presents with salmon-pink, well-demarcated, scaling plaques which on scratching produce tiny bleeding points as shown in the image given below. Which of the following nail changes would you expect to see in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the image showing Auspitz's sign are characteristic of psoriasis. A subungual oil drop sign or salmon patch is a specific sign seen in nail psoriasis.

Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the skin with systemic manifestations. Plaque psoriasis is the most common type.

The nails are frequently involved, and pitting is the most common finding seen. Nail beds can also be affected, giving rise to the oil-drop sign—a highly specific sign seen in this condition. Other manifestations include subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

 The skin is involved in the form of red/ salmon pink, scaly, and well-demarcated lesions. A peripheral clearing (ring of Woronoff) may be present. It is usually seen on the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs. The lesions are surrounded by silvery-white scales. The appearance of a smooth, glossy red membrane with small bleeding points on the removal of the supra-papillary epidermis by gentle scraping (Auspitz's sign) is characteristic.
 
Other options: Dorsal nail pterygium, pup tent sign, and thinning of the nail plate are the nail findings seen in lichen planus.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

Related Pearl: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

Pup-tent sign - elevation of nail in shape of tent

Trachyonychia - 20 nail dystrophy

Subungual Hyperkeratosis and Onycholysis

Longitudinal Melanonychia in Lichen Planus of the nail bed

Permanent destruction of several toenails with ulceration of soles (rare variant)

Image shows  Nails in Lichen planus presented with irregular longitudinal grooves and ridges .

Image : Dorsal Nail Pterygium

Image : Pup-tent sign 

Image: Trachyonychia

questions.text: A paramedic in the ambulance examines a G2P1 lady, who is in labor. Her vitals are stable, her uterus is term-sized, and the fetus is in cephalic presentation. The cord is prolapsed outside the vulva. The paramedic places a Foley catheter to fill up the bladder with 500 mL of saline and then clamps it. This method of relief of pressure on the cord is known as ________.
questions.solution:
Vago's method is used in cord prolapse to alleviate pressure on the cord. Vagos method is also known as the bladder-filling method. Here, the bladder is distended with saline to push the presenting part higher up, thereby preventing compression in case of cord prolapse. The bladder is filled with 400–750 mL of normal saline with a Foley’s catheter. Then, the balloon is inflated and the catheter is clamped.

The management algorithm for cord prolapse is based on three important factors:

  • Living or dead baby
  • Maturity of the baby
  • Degree of cervical dilatation

The definitive treatment for cord prolapse is delivery by cesarean section when the baby is alive and mature as in this clinical scenario. Reconfirming if the baby is alive before the incision is important to prevent unnecessary trauma of surgery.

  • If the baby is dead - 
    • Reconfirmation with ultrasound
    • Spontaneous delivery when death is confirmed
    • Destructive operations are rarely needed
  • If immediate safe vaginal delivery is possible - 
    • When the fetal head is engaged - delivery by forceps. Ventouse is not ideal in such circumstances as it takes a longer time 
    • Breech presentation - the delivery is to be completed by breech extraction
    • Transverse lie - the internal podalic version, followed by breech extraction

  • When immediate safe vaginal delivery is not possible:

    • Oxytocin infusion is stopped
    • IV fluids, oxygen by face mask, and continuous fetal monitoring
    • Relieve pressure on the cord by:
      • Manual elevation of the fetal presenting part using two fingers or the whole hand through the vagina.
      • Positioning of the patient in a steep Trendelenburg position, exaggerated Sim’s position, or knee-chest position.
      • Vagos method: Foley catheter is placed and the bladder is filled with 500-750 mL of saline, and then clamped. The patient’s enlarging bladder provides upward pressure on the fetus and alleviates the compression of the cord.
    • Funic reduction(option B): Gentle manual repositioning of the cord into the uterus. It is not preferred nowadays.
    • Tocolysis can be considered if there is a prolonged interval before delivery

The management algorithm for cord prolapse is given below: 

Option C: Brandt Andrew's method is a maneuver of expressing the placenta from the uterus in the third stage of labor. 

Here, the palmar surface of the left hand is placed on the mother's abdomen approximately at the junction of the upper and lower uterine segment (above the symphysis pubis) and the umbilical cord is grasped with the other hand. While the hand on the abdomen is pressed backward and slightly upward, the other applies gentle traction on the cord in a downward and backward direction holding the clamp until the placenta comes outside the introitus.

Option D: Burns Marshall method: It is used in the delivery of the after-coming head in breech presentation.

questions.text:
Arrange in sequence the stages of fracture healing.
  1. Stage of granulation tissue
  2. Stage of haematoma
  3. Stage of modeling
  4. Stage of remodeling
  5. Stage of callus
questions.solution:
The stages of fracture healing are:

2. Stage of haematoma

1. Stage of granulation tissue

5. Stage of callus

4. Stage of remodeling

3. Stage of modeling

During the stage of hematoma formation, which can span up to 7 days, the periosteum and nearby soft tissues become detached from the fractured ends. This detachment leads to a lack of blood supply to the fracture ends, causing a condition known as ischemic necrosis. As a result, some osteocytes, die due to insufficient blood flow, while others become sensitized and undergo a transformation into daughter cells. These transformed cells play a role in the subsequent healing process.

The stage of granulation tissue formation occurs for approximately 2-3 weeks. During this stage, the previously sensitized daughter cells generate specialized cells that differentiate into blood vessels, fibroblasts, osteoblasts, and other components. These cells work together to form a soft granulation tissue that fills the gap between the fractured fragments.

The callus stage, which typically lasts for approximately 4-12 weeks, involves further differentiation of the granulation tissue into osteoblasts. These specialized cells produce an intercellular matrix that gradually becomes infused with calcium salts. As a result, a callus is formed, also known as woven bone. The callus serves as the initial indication of bone union, and it is usually visible on X-rays about 3 weeks after the fracture. At this stage, the fracture is clinically united, meaning it is no longer mobile.

During the stage of remodeling, previously referred to as the consolidation stage, the woven bone is gradually replaced by mature bone characterized by its lamellar structure. This transformation occurs through a multicellular process, where areas of callus are substituted with areas of lamellar bone. The remodeling stage typically spans a period of 1-2 years.

During the stage of modeling, previously known as the remodeling stage, the bone undergoes a gradual strengthening process. This involves the shaping of the bone's periosteal and endosteal surfaces. The primary driving force behind this process is the local strains experienced by the bone, which are caused by weight-bearing stresses and muscle forces when the individual resumes their normal activities. As a result, the bone adapts and strengthens to better withstand these mechanical forces.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions does the reflex elicited below persist in an infant more than 6 months of age?
questions.solution:
The reflex elicited is the Moro reflex. It disappears by 3-6 months of birth. Persistence of moro reflex at more than 6 months of age is associated with cerebral palsy.

Moro reflex is a primitive neonatal reflex. The infant's head is held in a semi-erect position and then allowed to fall backward onto the examiner's hand. As a response to this, there is initial extension and abduction of fingers and upper extremities. This is followed by flexion of the upper extremities and an audible cry. 

The reflex begins to develop at 28-32 weeks of gestation and is fully developed at 37 weeks. It may be present until 6 months after birth.

An asymmetric reflex can point to a fractured clavicle, brachial plexus injury, or hemiparesis. Absent Moro reflex is suggestive of central nervous system dysfunction as seen in hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy and kernicterus.

Related Pearl: Timeline for primitive reflexes

37 weeks of gestation
5-6 months postnatal

1 month postnatal

According to Ghai Essential Paediatrics, 9th edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 4 months of age. According to Nelson Paediatrics, 21st edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 6 months of age. Hence, the answer depends on the reference chosen by the examiner.

questions.text: During the examination of a patient diagnosed with heterotropia, you noticed an increased amount of deviation in upward gaze and a decreased amount of deviation in downward gaze as shown in the below image. The pattern of heterotropia seen in this patient is known as _________
questions.solution:
The given image shows a convergent squint or esotropia in the upward gaze. Since the deviation is more in the upward gaze it depicts an A pattern esotropia.

A or V pattern heterotropia:

The term A or V pattern heterotropia is used when there is a variation in the amount of deviation in the squinting eye between upward and downward gaze. This difference is considered significant when it is more than 10 degrees in the A pattern and more than 15 degrees in the V pattern. These conditions are assessed by measuring the horizontal deviations in the primary position, upgaze, and downgaze.

  • In esotropia, if the amount of deviation increases in upward gaze and decreases in downward gaze, it is known as "A" pattern esotropia. The reverse occurs in ‘V’ pattern esotropia.
  • In exotropia, if the amount of deviation decreases in upward gaze and increases in downward gaze, it is known as "A" pattern exotropia. The reverse occurs in ‘V’ pattern exotropia.

Image: A and V pattern heterotopia

    • Hypophoria: Deviation downwards

questions.text:
The graph below shows height-for-age curves of four general causes of proportional short stature. Match the following curves with the likely conditions that might correspond to them

 

  1. A child whose bone age is less than the chronological age and the growth velocity is normal.
  2. A child with a pituitary tumor presenting with growth hormone deficiency.
  3. A child diagnosed with Down's syndrome.
  4. A child with a family history of short stature.
questions.solution:
The given graph shows four height-for-age curves of different causes of short stature.

The correct match is:

Conditions Curve
1. A child whose bone age is less than the chronological age. Curve 2
2. A child with a pituitary tumor presenting with growth hormone deficiency Curve 1
3. A child diagnosed with Down's syndrome. Curve 4
4. A child with a family history of short stature. Curve 3

Short stature can be defined as growth below the expected genetic potential or below -2 SD for age and sex. If a child's stature is less than -3 SD below the average for their age and gender it is more likely to indicate pathological short stature. A child's height between -2 and -3 SD is more likely due to physiological, i.e. familial or constitutional short stature.

To assess children under 2 years old, supine length should be measured using an infantometer. For older children, height should be measured using a stadiometer.

Curve 4 shows that the growth is decreased since birth and remains below the mean curve. The growth is less than -2 SD while reaching adulthood. This represents the prenatal onset of pathological short stature. In congenital pathologic short stature, an infant may or may not be born small, but growth gradually tapers throughout infancy. Causes include chromosome or genetic abnormalities like Turner syndrome, skeletal dysplasia, trisomy 21, perinatal infection, extreme prematurity, and teratogens. 
 

Curve 2 shows that the growth decreases near the end of infancy, runs parallel through middle childhood, and accelerates toward the end of adulthood with the achievement of normal adult height. This represents the constitutional growth delay where the onset of puberty and adolescent growth spurt is also delayed. Bone age is lower than chronological age and corresponds to the height age

Curve 3 shows that the growth runs parallel to and just below the mean curve from early childhood till adulthood. The child has a family history of short stature. Familial short stature is characterized by both the infant and the parents being small in stature. In this case, the bone age aligns with the chronological age, and the projected adult height is below average. The height of the parents has a significant impact on the child's height. Mid-parental height (MPH) provides a rough estimation of the child's genetically determined potential height.

Curve 1 shows that the growth curve initially follows the average pattern but then deviates below the mean curve and gradually tapers off. This represents postnatal onset pathologic short stature. The onset of this condition can be due to factors like undernutrition, systemic illness, or endocrine issues such as growth hormone deficiency or hypothyroidism. 

Related Pearl: Short stature: Familial vs Constitutional

Feature Constitutional Delay Familial Short Stature  
Height Short Short
Final Height Normal Short  
Family history Delayed puberty Short stature  
Bone age Less than chronological age Normal  
Puberty Delayed Normal  
Height velocity Normal Normal

questions.text: Saw-tooth appearance on a barium enema X-ray is characteristic of
questions.solution:
Saw-tooth appearance is characteristic of colonic diverticulosis.

The segment of colon involved in extensive diverticulosis is often concentrically narrowed along with accompanying hypertrophy of the colonic muscle layers, thus producing an irregular appearance resembling a sawtooth.

Note: Saw-tooth appearance can also occur in Hirschsprung's disease.

Diverticulosis refers to the condition where multiple outpouchings occur along the gastrointestinal tract without any inflammation. Colonic diverticulosis is primarily false diverticula as only the mucosa and muscularis mucosa have herniated. They occur due to increased intraluminal pressure and thus are a pulsion type of diverticula. The sigmoid colon is the most common location.

The majority of patients with diverticulosis are usually asymptomatic or present with distension, flatulence, and a sensation of heaviness in the lower abdomen.

Diverticulosis can present with complications like:

  • Diverticulitis
  • Abscess
  • Peritonitis
  • Intestinal obstruction
  • Hemorrhage 
  • Fistula formation

The diagnosis is confirmed by a colonoscopy or an X-ray barium enema. Barium enema radiograph shows multiple barium-coated outpouchings from the colonic wall and gives the appearance of a saw-tooth. In cases of severe abdominal pain, a CT scan is preferred to avoid the risk of intestinal perforation.

Hinchey classification is used to describe the severity and complication of acute diverticulitis. It is used additionally to guide the overall management of acute diverticulitis. Hinchey classification of complicated diverticulitis:

Stage 1

 Mesenteric or pericolic abscess

Stage 2

 Pelvic abscess

Stage 3

 Purulent peritonitis

Stage 4

 Fecal peritonitis
 
Management of diverticulosis includes a high-fiber diet and bulk-forming laxatives. Antispasmodics for recurrent pain.
Acute diverticulitis has been treated with intravenous antibiotics and bowel rest.
Localized abscesses are managed with intravenous antibiotics and image-guided drainage.
Stages 3 and 4 are considered an emergency and a laparotomy with a thorough washout of contamination is performed followed by Hartmann's procedure or resection with primary anastomosis.

questions.text:
A patient complains of difficulty in maintaining balance while walking at night for the past 2 months. On examination, he has spastic weakness in both lower limbs, a positive Babinski sign, and an absent ankle jerk. Laboratory results are given below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?

Hemoglobin: 13 g/dL

MCV: within normal limits
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of sensory ataxia (patient is unable to maintain balance without visual input), UMN signs (spasticity and positive Babinski sign), and absence of ankle jerk due to peripheral neuropathy point to a diagnosis of subacute combined degeneration of cord (SACD). Note that neurological symptoms of vitamin B12 deficiency can occur without anemia and macrocytosis.

SACD is a degeneration of the dorsal and lateral columns of the spinal cord, which occurs as a result of vitamin B12 deficiency. Patients present with sensory ataxia (involvement of the dorsal column) and UMN type of motor symptoms such as spasticity and positive Babinski sign (involvement of corticospinal tract). Because of coexisting peripheral neuropathy, deep tendon reflexes can be absent. Some patients also develop cortical defects such as dementia.

The treatment of vitamin B12 deficiency when the patient has neurological symptoms is with cyanocobalamine 1000 mcg given intramuscularly, first daily for 1 week → then weekly for 1 month → then monthly for the rest of the patient's life.

Other options:

Option A: Although UMN type of motor symptoms are seen in ischemic stroke as well, they are unilateral. Furthermore, stroke is an acute onset clinical syndrome, while this patient has had these complaints for the past 2 months.

Option B: Patients with syringomyelia present with weakness in arms more than legs and loss of pain and temperature sensation over the shoulders, upper back, and nape of the neck (cape-like distribution). Fine touch, vibration, and joint position sense remain preserved.

Option C: Tabes dorsalis primarily affects the dorsal columns, leading to sensory ataxia and absent reflexes, it does not cause spasticity or a positive Babinski sign, as it spares the corticospinal tracts. 

Related Pearl: Difference between various causes of ataxia

questions.text: A newborn baby born to a mother with Grave's disease who is on antithyroid drugs had the finding shown in the image below. How could have this condition been avoided?

choices.text: Propylthiouracil in the 1st trimester and methimazole in 2nd and 3rd trimester
Methimazole in the 1st trimester and propylthiouracil in 2nd and 3rd trimester

questions.solution:
The given image shows aplasia cutis congenita of the newborn depicting the absence of scalp hair and skin along with calvarial defects. This is commonly associated with methimazole. Hence could have this condition been avoided with propylthiouracil in the 1st trimester and methimazole in 2nd and 3rd trimester. 

Methimazole crosses the placenta to a greater degree than propylthiouracil and has been associated with fetal aplasia cutis. It is also associated with methimazole embryopathy, which includes esophageal or choanal atresia. Thus, when available, propylthiouracil should be used in the first trimester followed by the usage of methimazole during the second trimester. 

Propylthiouracil throughout pregnancy can lead to maternal hepatotoxicity. 

 

Related Pearl: Drug of choice for hyperthyroidism/thyrotoxicosis in pregnancy

In the 1st trimester: Propylthiouracil

In the 2nd and 3rd trimester: Methimazole

questions.text: The ponderal index of an infant with intrauterine growth restriction was less than 2. All of the following can lead to this condition except_____
questions.solution:
The ponderal index of less than 2 in an infant points to asymmetrical IUGR. It is mainly caused by maternal and placental conditions, that cause an insult during late gestation. TORCH infections typically lead to symmetric IUGR.

The Ponderal index can also be used to determine the degree of fetal malnutrition. It is calculated as the ratio of body weight in grams to length in cm expressed as PI = [weight {in gram} × 100] ÷ (length {in cm})3. The normal value of the ponderal index is 2-2.5. Ponderal index > 2 is suggestive of symmetrical IUGR whereas value < 2 is suggestive of asymmetrical IUGR.

Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) refers to a fetal growth deficiency and an abnormal fetal growth trajectory. It is often classified as follows: 

Symmetric IUGR - Insult on fetal growth occurs early. As a result, head circumference, length, and weight are equally affected. It can be due to genetic causes, chromosomal disorders, or TORCH infections in the fetus.

Asymmetric IUGR - Insult occurs in late gestation, producing a relative brain-sparing effect. The head circumference is relatively preserved compared to weight and length. It is caused by placental insufficiency, pregnancy-induced hypertension(PIH), poor maternal nutrition, or maternal medical diseases.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man came with complaints of long-standing arthralgia in the knee. On examination, the following finding was noted. On further inquiry, he says that the urine turns black on exposure to air. Which of the following enzyme defects is likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is strongly suggestive of alkaptonuria and the pathological discoloration of sclera shown in the image is known as ochronosis. There is a defect in the enzyme homogentisate oxidase in this condition.

Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder of tyrosine metabolism, that develops due to the defect in homogentisate oxidase, the enzyme which oxidizes homogentisate to maleylacetoacetate. The defect in this enzyme will lead to the accumulation of homogentisic acid which gets oxidized into benzoquinone acetate.

Later, benzoquinone acetate polymerizes and binds to tissues, especially collagen fibers. This manifests as arthritis and pigmentation of cartilage and sclera (ochronosis). Further, there is urinary excretion of homogentisate, which gets oxidized. This leads to black discoloration of the urine on prolonged exposure to air.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about histones?

choices.text: Histones are synthesized during G1 phase of the cell cycle`
H1 histone does not contribute to formation of nucleosome
Mitochondrial DNA does not have histone proteins
Histones are rich in arginine and lysine

questions.solution:
Histones are synthesized in the S-phase of the cell cycle, not in G1 phase.

Histones are proteins that help in the condensation of DNA. They contain a high concentration of basic amino acids such as arginine and lysine (option D). H2A, H2B, H3, and H4 types of histones form an octameric complex, around which DNA is wrapped. This structure is called a nucleosome. H1 histone does not contribute to the formation of nucleosomes, but binds to them and to the linker DNA, thus stabilizing the entire condensed DNA structure. Mitochondrial DNA, like prokaryotic DNA, lacks histone proteins and thus the DNA is not organized into nucleosomes. 

The structure of a nucleosome is shown below:

H3 histones

(H3–H4)2 tetramer has a central role in the formation

of the nucleosome

questions.text: Calculate the driving force for Cl- ion if the membrane potential is -60mV, considering that the equilibrium potential of Cl- ion is -70mV?
questions.solution:
The driving force for Cl- ion if the membrane potential is -60mV is +10mV

Driving force = Membrane potential - Equilibrium potential

Membrane potential is given as -60mV. The equilibrium potential of Cl- is -70mV

Driving force = -60mV -(-70mV) = +10mV

  • When the driving force is positive a cation will leave the cell and anion will enter the cell.
  • When the driving force is negative a cation will enter the cell and an anion will leave the cell.

questions.text: A villager presents to you saying that his friends have been telling him to not eat the dal in the picture below, because it will cause paralysis. He is economically weak and wants to continue eating it. Which of the following methods will you not recommend to prevent the complication caused by this dal?

choices.text: Good amount of ascorbic acid in the diet
Removing the husk of the dal
Soaking the dal in limewater overnight and then boiling
Limiting the amount of dal to a quarter of the total cereals and pulses consumed per day

questions.solution:
The given history and the image showing triangular and greyish dal are suggestive of khesari dal – Lathyrus sativus. Removing the husk of the dal is not a method used to remove the toxin present in it.

Khesari dal has a toxin known as beta oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA). This toxin is water soluble. The dal must be consumed in large quantities for a period of 2-3 months before the toxin starts having any clinical effect.

Long-term consumption of khesari dal leads to neurolathyrism. It is characterized by gradual spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. The patient is initially able to walk with short jerky steps without any aids, but the progressive spastic paralysis causes a crossed gait, and the patient has to use sticks to maintain his balance. Eventually, the knee joints are unable to support the weight of the body and the patient cannot stand erect at all.

The interventions that can be used to prevent lathyrism include:
  • Vitamin C prophylaxis (option A)
  • Limiting the proportion of the dal to less than a quarter of the total cereals and pulses consumed in a day (option D)
  • Removal of the toxin by:
    • Parboiling: this involves soaking the dal in limewater overnight and then boiling it (option C).
    • Steeping method: this involves soaking the dal in hot water for a period of 2 hours. The dal is then washed with cleaned water and dried before consumption.

questions.text: A forensic pathologist is examining a venous specimen. Microscopy reveals laminations with alternating light and dark bands as shown below. What are the dark bands composed of?
questions.solution:
The specimen shows a thrombus and the laminations are called lines of Zahn. The dark bands are composed of erythrocytes.

Lines of Zahn are characteristic of thrombi that appear in blood vessels, very commonly in veins. These laminations or striae can be seen either macroscopically, in large vessels or microscopically in smaller ones, as they form alternating light and dark bands.

The light bands are composed of platelets and fibrin (Option D) while the darker bands are referred to as red-cell rich because they are composed of erythrocytes.

Lines of Zahn help to determine whether a thrombus has developed before death and was, therefore, a possible contributing factor or if it is a postmortem clot. That is because lines of Zahn indicate that a thrombus has formed in flowing blood.

Postmortem clots are usually bland and nonlaminated clots. They are gelatinous and have a lower dark red portion which is erythrocyte rich, formed as a result of gravitation of these erythrocytes and a yellow chicken fat upper portion, that is not attached to the vessel wall.

The following image shows the lines of Zahn.

 

Other options:

Option A: Psammoma bodies are round microscopic collections of calcium and are called so because they resemble grains of sand. They are representative of dystrophic calcification. Necrotic cells form the focus for surrounding calcific deposition. They have a lamellated concentric calcified structure. Psammoma bodies are found in a diverse group of tumours which include papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, meningioma, and serous cystadenoma of the ovary.

 


Option B: Hemosiderin is a hemoglobin-derived, yellowish-brown granular or crystalline pigment. In the body, iron is stored along with apoferritin to form ferritin micelles. However, when there is excessive iron present, ferritin forms hemosiderin granules, which may be observed in the mononuclear phagocytes of bone marrow, spleen, and liver. The image below shows macrophages containing phagocytized brownish granular hemosiderin.

The image below shows hemosiderin pigment within the alveolar macrophages in the lung. 

 

Related Pearl: Arterial and Venous Thrombi

Pathogenesis Endothelial injury or site of turbulence Stasis of blood

Propagation Grows in a retrograde manner from point of attachment Grows in an antegrade manner from point of attachment

questions.text: During highly selective vagotomy, the surgeon should take additional care to ensure complete division of which of the following branches of the posterior trunk, in order to avoid the risk of ulcer recurrence?

choices.text: The whole of the posterior trunk must be divided

questions.solution:
The nerve of Grassi which is a branch of the posterior vagus nerve if left undivided can result in the recurrence of ulcers following highly selective vagotomy.

There are 3 types of vagotomy

  1. Highly selective vagotomy
  2. Truncal vagotomy + gastrojejunostomy 
  3. Truncal vagotomy + antrectomy.

Highly selective vagotomy

  • Acid reduction is minimum.
  • Highest ulcer recurrence rate.
  • Minimum postoperative complications.

Truncal vagotomy + antrectomy

  • Acid reduction is maximum.
  • Least ulcer recurrence rate.
  • Maximum postoperative complications.

 

The anterior vagus sends a branch to the liver in the gastrohepatic ligament and continues along the lesser curvature as the anterior nerve of Latarjet. The posterior nerve of Latarjet is a branch of the posterior vagus. The nerves of Latarjet send segmental branches to the body of the stomach before they terminate near the angularis incisura as the “crow’s foot” sending branches to the antro-pyloric region. 

The crow’s feet innervating the fundus and body of the stomach are divided up until a point approximately 7 cm proximal to the pylorus, the area in the vicinity of the gastric antrum. Superiorly, the division of these nerves is carried to a point at least 5 cm proximal to the GE junction on the esophagus. Ideally, two or three branches
to the antrum and pylorus should be preserved.

questions.text:
Match the following diuretics with their best suited uses.
Diuretics Uses
1. Acetazolamide a. Cerebral edema
2. Furosemide b. Acute mountain sickness
3. Spironolactone c. Pulmonary edema
4. Mannitol d. Cirrhotic edema
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

Diuretics Uses
1. Acetazolamide b. Acute mountain sickness
2. Furosemide c. Pulmonary edema
3. Spironolactone d. Cirrhotic edema
4. Mannitol a. Cerebral edema

Acetazolamide, a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, acts on the enzyme in epithelial cells of the proximal convoluted tubule. Acetazolamide is mainly used in patients with secondary glaucoma to reduce intra-ocular pressure, provide symptomatic relief in acute mountain sickness, and as a treatment for absence seizures.

Furosemide is a loop diuretic. It acts by inhibiting the Na+-K+-2Cl- symporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle resulting in increased excretion of sodium, potassium, and chloride. Hypokalemia, hyperuricemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia are the important side effects.

Spironolactone is a competitive inhibitor of the mineralocorticoid receptor in the late distal tubule and collecting duct of the kidneys. It causes a decrease in sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion in the distal tubule. As a result, spironolactone promotes sodium diuresis but maintains body potassium levels. Spironolactone is particularly helpful in edematous states caused or exacerbated by hyperaldosteronism such as in cirrhotic ascites.

Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic. It acts by extracting water from the intracellular compartments, which results in the expansion of the extracellular fluid. This results in volume overload and frank pulmonary edema in patients with cardiac failure. Therapeutic use of mannitol:

1. Reduction of intracranial pressure and brain mass
2. Reduction of high intraocular pressure when the pressure cannot be lowered by other means

questions.text: Which of the following histopathological findings is characteristic of acute eczema?
questions.solution:
Spongiosis is the characteristic histopathological feature of acute eczema. It refers to intercellular epidermal edema that leads to the rupture of the intercellular attachments, with the formation of vesicles.

Eczema is inflammation of the skin seen in a variety of skin conditions. Dermatitis is used to include all types of cutaneous inflammation.

The histopathological features of eczema depend on the phase of inflammation

Acute phase: The histological hallmark is intercellular epidermal edema known as spongiosis. This leads to the formation of with the formation of vesicles in discrete foci which may coalesce and become large. There is variable lymphocytic infiltration and acanthosis due to increased epidermal mitotic activity.

Subacute stage: This is diminished spongiosis and vesiculation and an increase in acanthosis. A parakeratotic horny layer (Option A) is formed. Coagulated plasma and pyknotic nuclei of inflammatory cells may be present here.

Chronic eczema:  Acanthosis is more prominent and parakeratosis is gradually replaced by hyperkeratosis (Option B). Inflammatory cells become less evident and lichenification (Option D) occurs with elongated and broadened rete ridges.

The image below shows eczema.

questions.text: A 47-year-old patient presents with 1 hypopigmented and anesthetic skin patch on his right upper limb, along with thickening of the right median and ulnar nerve. Which of the following treatment regimens should be prescribed to this patient?

choices.text: Rifampin 600 mg daily, Clofazimine 300 mg once/month and 50 mg daily, Dapsone 100 mg daily x 12 months
Rifampin 600 mg daily, Clofazimine 300 mg once/month and 50 mg daily, Dapsone 100 mg daily x 6 months
Rifampin 600 mg once/month, Clofazimine 300 mg once/month and 50 mg daily, Dapsone 100 mg daily x 6 months
Rifampin 600 mg once/month, Clofazimine 300 mg once/month and 50 mg daily, Dapsone 100 mg daily x 12 months

questions.solution:
The given patient has 1 hypopigmented, anesthetic patch, but has the involvement of 2 nerves. Thus, he has multibacillary (MB) leprosy. The following drugs are given for a period of 12 months for the treatment of multibacillary leprosy:

  • Rifampin 600 mg once/month
  • Clofazimine 300 mg once/month and 50 mg daily
  • Dapsone 100 mg daily

Management of leprosy is based on the bacterial load. WHO defines paucibacillary (PB) disease as the presence of no bacilli on smears or biopsy and less than or equal to 5 skin lesions with no or only one peripheral nerve involved. MB leprosy is characterized by bacilli on smears or biopsies of more than 5 skin lesions and more than 1 peripheral nerve involvement.

The current recommendation by WHO is to treat PB leprosy with a combination of 3 drugs - rifampicin, dapsone, and clofazimine (maroon blister pack) for 6 months. Meanwhile, multibacillary (MB) leprosy is treated using the same 3 drugs for a duration of 12 months. While the NLEP guidelines earlier mentioned a 2-drug MDT for PB leprosy, the National Strategic Plan and Roadmap for Leprosy (2023-2027) now recommends a uniform MDT of 3 drugs for both PB and MB leprosy.

Chemoprophylaxis for leprosy should be given in:

  • Contacts who are aged more than 2 years
  • Those with close contact with the patient for more than 20 hours per week for more than 3 months

A single dose of rifampicin is recommended for the close contact of a patient with leprosy provided they do not develop any signs or symptoms pertaining to leprosy.

questions.text: The epithelium lining the gall bladder is_______
questions.solution:
The epithelium lining the gall bladder is columnar epithelium with brush-border microvilli.

Cilia are minute hair-like projections, while stereocilia are very long, thick microvilli measuring about 5–10 μm in length.

Ciliated epithelia bear cilia, which move in a coordinated fashion, and help in the movement of the mucus, or propel the movement of any other structures such as ova or spermatozoa.

The ciliated columnar epithelium is found in most of the respiratory tract, the uterus, and the uterine tube (oviduct), efferent ductules of the testis, parts of the middle ear and auditory tube; the ependyma lining the central canal of the spinal cord and the ventricles of the brain.

The pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium is seen in the trachea and in large bronchi.

questions.text:
All of the following ACE inhibitors are prodrugs except______
  1. Captopril
  2. Enalapril
  3. Lisinopril
  4. Perindopril
  5. Ramipril
questions.solution:
All of the given ACE inhibitors are prodrugs except captopril and lisinopril. They are given in their active forms.

There are certain drugs that are not inherently active and require conversion within the body into one or more active metabolites. These drugs are referred to as prodrugs. Prodrugs can offer several advantages compared to the active form of the drug, such as increased stability, improved bioavailability, favorable pharmacokinetic properties, reduced side effects, and decreased toxicity. In some cases, prodrugs are selectively activated at the specific site of action.

Examples of prodrugs:

  • Prednisone
  • Levodopa
  • ACE inhibitors (except lisinopril and captopril)
  • Sulfasalazine
  • Methyldopa
  • Cyclophosphamide
  • Clopidogrel

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is being evaluated for the following deformity of his left elbow. Three years ago, he suffered a fracture of his left humerus following a fall on his outstretched hand. Which of the following types does the fracture leading to this complication belong to, as per the Salter-Harris classification?
questions.solution:
The image shows the cubitus valgus deformity of the left elbow, which is usually a complication of lateral condyle fracture of the humerus. It belongs to type IV of the Salter-Harris classification.

Fracture of the lateral condyle of the humerus is most likely to be seen in a child with a fall on an outstretched hand in a varus position. 

A large fragment of bone including the lateral condyle breaks off and is pulled away by the attached wrist extensors. The normal 3-point bony relationship at the elbow is lost. It is a Salter-Harris type IV injury. 

These fractures are managed surgically (fracture of necessity) with open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) using either screws or K-wire. 

Non-union is commonly seen in these fractures. If left untreated, the lateral growth plate fails to grow, while the medial one continues to grow, resulting in a cubitus valgus deformity. 

Related Pearl: Types of Salter–Harris fractures- Mnemonic

There are nine types of Salter-Harris fractures. Among these, types I to V are more common.

The mnemonic "SALTER" can be used to help remember the first five types.

TYPE  MNEMONIC DESCRIPTION
Type I S = Slip/straight across Transverse fracture through the growth plate
Type II A = Away The fracture lies away from the joint. A fracture through the growth plate and the metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis
Type III L = Lower The fracture is below the physis in the epiphysis.
Type IV TE = Through Everything  A fracture through all three elements of the bone, the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis
Type V R = Rammed (crushed)  A compression fracture of the growth plate

Rarer types VI to IX have been added subsequently.

  • Type VI - Injury to the perichondral structures
  • Type VII - Isolated injury to the epiphyseal plate
  • Type VIII - Isolated injury to the metaphysis, with a potential injury related to endochondral ossification
  • Type IX - Injury to the periosteum that may interfere with membranous growth

questions.text: The autopsy of a 60-year-old man who died of a respiratory illness revealed the following findings on the pleura. What was the most likely occupation of this man?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing pleural plaques are suggestive of asbestosis. Asbestosis develops due to prolonged inhalation of asbestos, which is common in the insulation industry. 

Pleural plaques are the most common manifestation of asbestos exposure. They are well-circumscribed plaques of dense collagen, often containing calcium. They develop most frequently on the parietal pleura and over the domes of the diaphragm. They do not contain asbestos bodies, and only rarely occur in persons without prior asbestos exposure.

Asbestos occurs in two distinct forms - serpentine chrysotile (more common) and amphibole (more pathogenic). Exposure may result in the following conditions:

  • Localized fibrous plaques or, rarely, diffuse pleural fibrosis
  • Pleural effusions
  • Parenchymal interstitial fibrosis (asbestosis)
  • Lung carcinoma
  • Mesotheliomas
  • Extrapulmonary neoplasms including laryngeal, ovarian, and colon carcinomas

The image below shows fibrous pleural plaques seen on the diaphragmatic pleural surface in asbestosis.

Other options-

Option B: Anthracosis/coal workers' pneumoconiosis is a pulmonary condition seen in coal miners. The inhaled carbon pigment is engulfed by alveolar or interstitial macrophages, which accumulate in the connective tissue. On prolonged exposure, lung tissue undergoes progressive massive fibrosis, which is called complicated coal workers' pneumoconiosis. The upper lobes of the lungs are commonly involved.

Microscopic features consist of coal-laden macrophages, black pigment, and dense collagenous interstitial fibrosis. 

The image below shows anthracosis—black pigment engulfed within macrophages as well as in the form of deposits.

Option C: Silicosis is due to the inhalation of crystalline silicon dioxide (silica) as seen in individuals employed in sandblasting or rock mining. Macrophages phagocytose inhaled silica particles, thereby activating and releasing inflammatory mediators, like IL-1 and IL-8.

Histopathology reveals coalescent nodules of whorled collagen fibers surrounded by a peripheral zone of dust-laden macrophages. Radiologically, egg-shell calcification of the lymph nodes is seen.

Shown below is an image of a silicotic nodule with collagen whorls as seen in this condition.

Option D: Bagassosis is an occupational lung disease caused by the inhalation of bagasse or sugarcane dust. A thermophilic actinomycete, Thermoactinomyces sacchari is the causative organism/ The symptoms are breathlessness, cough, hemoptysis, and fever. Initially, it can result in acute diffuse bronchiolitis. If left untreated it can progress to diffuse fibrosis, emphysema, and bronchiectasis.

questions.text:
For which of the following patients can the pills shown below be advised as a method of contraception?
  1. A 40-year-old woman with breast cancer
  2. A 25-year-old lactating mother 
  3. A 30-year-old woman who has diabetes and hypertension
  4. A 22-year-old with abnormal uterine bleeding
  5. A 35-year-old woman who is a smoker
questions.solution:
The given image is desogestrel pills (synthetic progesterone-only pills) which can be taken by lactating women, women who have diabetes and hypertension, and women who are smokers.

Progesterone-only pills are also known as minipills. They are started 21 days postpartum and soon after an abortion. The woman needs to take precautions in the first 48 hours of the first cycle.

The mechanism of action of progesterone-only pills involves thickening of the cervical mucus that inhibits penetration of sperms (mainly), atrophy of the endometrium, and inhibition of ovulation.

Advantages of progesterone-only pills include:

  • Minimal or no effects on carbohydrate and lipid metabolism
  • Do not cause or exacerbate hypertension 
  • Do not impair milk production, therefore suitable during lactation
  • Safe for women with a history of migraine headaches
  • Safe for smokers who are older than 35 years

Contraindications include abnormal uterine bleeding, breast cancer, hepatic cancer, pregnancy, and active severe liver disease. Additionally, synthetic progestogens like desogestrel are associated with a higher incidence of thromboembolism.

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

Related Pearl: Classification Of Contraceptives Based On Effectiveness

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes will show reduced activity in a person who is fasting?
questions.solution:
During fasting, there is increased glucagon release. This causes the production of cAMP, and subsequent activation of cAMP-dependent protein kinase. This protein kinase has two functions:

  • Activation of fructose 2,6 bisphosphatase
  • Inactivation of phosphofructokinase-2

Both these actions reduce the amount of fructose 2,6 bisphosphate and thus inhibit glycolysis and move the needle of glucose metabolism toward gluconeogenesis. Pyruvate carboxylase and fructose 1,6 bisphosphatase are enzymes catalyzing steps of gluconeogenesis, and are thus stimulated during fasting state.

Glycolysis and gluconeogenesis and the key enzymes involved in these processes are shown below:

questions.text:
During the examination of which of the following swellings would you expect to see transillumination?
  1. Epididymal cyst
  2. Spermatocoele
  3. Ranula
  4. Cystic hygroma
  5. Lipoma
questions.solution:
Epididymal cyst, ranula, spermatocele, and cystic hygroma show transillumination. Lipoma, due to its lipid content not allowing light to pass through, is not transilluminant. 

Transillumination is a technique where a light source is used to shine light through a body part/ swelling to assess the characteristics of the tissue or fluid inside. 

An epididymal cyst is a multilocular cyst formed due to the cystic degeneration of the epididymis. Multiple cysts formed posterior to the epididymis can feel like a bunch of grapes on palpation. Due to the presence of crystal clear fluid, an epididymal cyst brilliantly transilluminates and has a Chinese lantern appearance.


Spermatocele is a unilocular retention cyst formed at the epididymal head. Due to the presence of spermatozoa, barley-water fluid is seen. It shows transillumination.

Ranula is a benign cystic lesion formed by extravasation of mucus, involving the sublingual gland. Clinically present as cystic swelling in the floor of the mouth. On examination, the fluctuation test and transillumination test are positive. It is managed by marsupialization. 

Cystic hygroma is a brilliantly transilluminant cystic swelling containing clear lymph due to the sequestration of a portion of the jugular lymph sac. It usually presents in early infancy or at be present at birth, in which case it may even obstruct labor.

Lipomas present as a painless, slow-growing, soft, and mobile subcutaneous tissue mass. They do not transilluminate. The swelling is non-fluctuant and when palpated, the edge slips under the finger. This is known as the slip sign.

Related Pearl: Brilliantly Transilluminating Swellings

  • Vaginal hydrocele
  • Epididymal cyst
  • Cystic hygroma
  • Ranula
  • Meningocele

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient in her second trimester came with complaints of bleeding. She had a prior Cesarean section. Ultrasound showed a placental abnormality that corresponds to the illustration given below. The following placental abnormality is due to the absence or improper development of ____.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of placenta percreta. The abnormality is due to the partial or total absence of decidua basalis.

Decidua is the modified endometrium of pregnancy. It is classified into three parts as follows:

  • Decidua basalis is the part deeper into the developing blastocyst.
  • Decidua capsularis: part surrounding enlarging blastocyst and separating the conceptus and the uterine cavity.
  • Decidua parietalis: part lining the rest of the uterine cavity.

The below image shows the parts of the decidua.

The pathology in this condition is that the decidua basalis is absent and the Nitabuch layer is imperfectly developed.

When the villi are attached to the myometrium, it is known as placenta accreta whereas, in placenta increta, the myometrium is invaded by the villi. In placenta percreta, there is the penetration of villi through the serosa and the myometrium.

Risk factors include a co-existing previa and previous history of Cesarean section. Hemorrhage is the most common presentation in the first and second trimesters.

Treatment is a Cesarian section followed by hysterectomy.

The below image shows the placenta accreta, increta and percreta.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man working in a loud machinery unit came to the OPD complaining of hearing loss for the past 3 months. He also complains of high-pitched tinnitus and is unable to hear in noisy environments. On pure tone audiometry, a downsloping audiogram is seen. Which of the following ions is responsible for the depolarisation of hair cells in the affected structure?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 30-year-old man with hearing loss and pure tone audiometry showing a downsloping audiogram is suggestive of noise-induced hearing loss. K+ ion is responsible for depolarising hair cells in the cochlea.

Noise-induced hearing loss is a sensorineural hearing loss and is seen in chronic exposure to loud sounds in occupation. It is caused by irreversible damage to the outer hair cells in the organ of Corti. As the duration of noise exposure increases, the notch becomes deeper and wider, involving lower and higher frequencies.

PTA showing noise-induced hearing loss as downsloping audiogram:

The hair cells are located in the following six patches and correspond to the respective signals.

  • Organ of Corti - hearing
  • Utricle - horizontal acceleration
  • Saccule - vertical acceleration
  • Three semicircular canals - rotational acceleration

The hair cell has a resting potential of -60 mV. When all the stereocilia bend towards kinocilium there is an influx of K+ resulting in depolarization. Depolarization in turn opens voltage-gated calcium channels in the hair cell membrane, and the resultant Ca2+ influx causes transmitter release from the basal end of the cell onto the auditory nerve endings. If the movement of the stereocilia is in the opposite direction, it leads to hyperpolarisation.

questions.text: Weakness of which of the following muscles gives rise to the given appearance of glottis in a case of phonasthenia ?
questions.solution:
The image shows a triangular space, which is seen in phonasthenia, when the inter-arytenoid muscles alone are involved.

Phonasthenia is the weakness of voice due to fatigue of the laryngeal muscles. This leads to a gap between the vocal cords that can be visualized on indirect laryngoscopy. The shape of the gap depends on the muscles involved:

  • Thyroarytenoid alone: elliptical space
  • Interarytenoid alone: triangular space
  • Both thyroarytenoid & inter arytenoid: Keyhole appearance

This condition is treated with voice rest, especially after excessive use of voice and vocal hygiene.

Spasms of the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle cause abductor dysphonia.

Related Pearl: Muscles of larynx

Remember 2 exceptions:

  • All muscles are adductors, except PCA (an abductor)
  • All muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, except cricothyroid (superior laryngeal nerve)
Action
Muscle
Opening of the inlet of larynx
Thyroepiglotticus
Closing of the inlet of larynx
Aryepiglotticus, Interarytenoids
Abductor of vocal cords
Posterior cricoarytenoid
Adductor of vocal cords
Lateral cricoarytenoid
Tensor of vocal cords
Cricothyroid
Relaxer of vocal cord
Thyroarytenoid
Modulator of larynx
Vocalis

Safety muscle of larynx: Posterior cricoarytenoid

Safety muscle of tongue: Genioglossus

The muscle of whispering: Lateral cricoarytenoid

Vocalis is known as the modulator of larynx because, the anterior part of the vocalis muscle can tense the vocal cord, and its posterior part can relax the vocal cord.

questions.text: A senior resident during his ward rounds advises the intern to replace the cannula of a patient. The intern uses the cannula as shown in the image below. What is the gauge of this cannula?
questions.solution:
The given cannula is 17 gauge IV cannula as its color code is white.

The flow rate in cannula of this gauge is 125mL/minute.
