questions.text:
A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a high-speed two-wheeler motor vehicle accident. Blood-tinged fluid spontaneously drips from both nostrils which increases on leaning forward. A CT scan reveals a fracture line passing through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, the floor of the orbit, the upper part of the maxillary sinus, and the pterygoid plate. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?

CT: Computed tomography
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of a Le-Fort II fracture of the maxilla. 

Le-Fort II is a pyramidal fracture. It is characterized by a fracture line that passes through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, the floor of the orbit, the upper part of the maxillary sinus, and pterygoid plates.

Clinically, patients present after high-speed trauma to the face. They may present with a visible deformity or elongation of the midface. There is malocclusion of teeth on attempting to bite. Palpation may reveal an unusually mobile maxilla. It may be associated with CSF(cerebrospinal fluid) rhinorrhea due to injury to the cribriform plate. 

Diagnosis requires an X-ray or CT scan, wherein findings such as hanging maxilla are present. 

Treatment required fixation of the maxillary fractures which can be achieved by interdental wiring, intermaxillary wiring using arch bars. Open reduction and interosseous wiring may be required in zygomatic fractures.

Related Pearl: Le-Fort's classification of Maxillary Fracture

Le-Fort I is a transverse fracture of the maxilla
  • Fracture line passes through the lower part of nasal septum, maxillary antra and the pterygoid plates
  • It separates palate from the rest of the face leading to floating teeth or palate
  • Also called Guerin’s fracture. 
Le-Fort II is a pyramidal fracture
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, floor of the orbit, upper part of the maxillary sinus and pterygoid plates
  • X-ray or CT appears like hanging maxilla
  • It is associated with CSF rhinorrhea.
Le-Fort III is craniofacial dysjunction i.e., facial skeleton completely disconnected from its cranial attachment
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, ethmo-frontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral wall of the orbit, fronto-zygomatic and temporo-zygomatic sutures and the upper part of pterygoid plates
  • It is also associated with CSF rhinorrhea.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man drowns after diving into a lake, feet first. Which of the following is true about this case?

choices.text: It is known as secondary drowning
Nerve ending over the surface of the body are stimulated
Death occurs secondary to ventricular fibrillation

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of immersion syndrome/ hydrocution/ submersion inhibition. Stimulation of nerve endings on the surface of the body by cold water causes vasovagal inhibition followed by cardiac arrest.

Vagal inhibition in cases of immersion syndrome (hydrocution or submersion) occurs due to:

  • Stimulation of nerve endings on the surface of the body by cold water
  • Falling or diving into the water in a manner so that it suddenly strikes the abdomen, especially the epigastric region.
  • Stimulation of the nerve endings of the mucosa by the entry of cold water into the eardrums, nasal passages, pharynx, and larynx.

Immersion syndrome may occur in the following scenarios:

  • Diving/falling into the water, feet-first
  • Inexperienced "duck-diving"
  • Diving/falling into the water with a horizontal entry

People under the influence of alcohol or more likely affected due to the general vasodilation of skin vessels, consequently amplifying the effects of vasovagal inhibition. These effects are increased in people who are attempting suicide/anxious as they have a more active reflex arc.

Option A: Secondary drowning or near drowning refers to victims of submersion who have been resuscitated and survived for 24 hours.

Option B: In dry drowning death is due to sustained laryngeal spasm and subsequent airway closure. This occurs when there is sudden entry of water into the nasopharynx or larynx.

Option D: Wet drowning in freshwater is characterized by an altered sodium-potassium ratio which causes death secondary to ventricular tachycardia and fibrillation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient with a supracondylar fracture of the humerus is posted for open reduction and internal fixation under a brachial plexus block with a local anesthetic. He is a known case of alcoholic liver disease. Which of the following LA would not need dose readjustment in this case?
questions.solution:
In a patient with alcoholic liver disease, procaine does not require dose adjustment.

Procaine is an amino ester metabolized in the plasma by the cholinesterase enzyme. Lidocaine, bupivacaine, and ropivacaine are aminoamides and undergo enzymatic degradation in the liver.

Related Pearl: Classification of local anesthetics based on chemical structure

  Amino ester Amino amide

Exception: Cocaine - predominantly by hepatic carboxylesterase

Hepatic metabolism (amidase)

Exception: Articaine - plasma cholinesterase.

Exception: Tetracaine

Longer-acting

Exception: Articaine 
Allergic reaction High incidence due to metabolite PABA Rare

Examples

questions.text: Asthenospermia can result due to a defect in which of the following structure?
questions.solution:
Asthenospermia refers to diminished sperm motility. Defects in dynein can result in asthenospermia.

Defects in the dynein arm of cilia can result in primary ciliary dyskinesia (also called immotile cilia syndrome). It is an autosomal recessive disorder affecting ciliary motility. This causes the retention of secretions due to a failed mucociliary clearance mechanism. Clinically, this manifests as chronic sinusitis and recurrent infections that ultimately lead to bronchiectasis. As ciliary function is necessary to ensure proper rotation of the developing organs in the chest and abdomen, its absence will lead to situs inversus or a partial lateralizing abnormality. Male patients with this condition tend to be infertile, due to asthenospermia.

Other options

Option A: Kinesin is a molecular motor protein involved in anterograde (orthograde) transport, moving substances from the neuronal cell body to the axonal end.

Option C: Vimentin is an intermediate filament protein, which provides mechanical support and helps maintain cell shape.

Option D: Actin is a protein that forms microfilaments, a part of the cytoskeleton, and is involved in cell movement and muscle contraction.

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant is found to have a weak cry, paralysis, and loss of head control. On further workup, he was diagnosed to have botulism. The toxin blocks acetylcholine release by inhibiting which of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
Botulinum toxin blocks the release of acetylcholine by inhibiting synaptobrevin.

Botulinum toxin B cleaves synaptobrevin, a VAMP (vesicle-associated membrane protein). Botulinum toxins A and E act by cleaving synaptosome-associated protein-25 (SNAP-25), a presynaptic membrane protein needed for the fusion of synaptic vesicles containing acetylcholine to the terminal membrane.

The botulinum toxins block the release of acetylcholine in the neuromuscular junction and cause flaccid paralysis. Symptoms can include ptosis, diplopia, dysarthria, dysphonia, and dysphagia.

Other options:

Options A and B: Clathrin and Megalin are required for endocytosis.

Option D: Desmin is an intermediate filament. It is present in the sarcomeres in muscle cells.

Related Pearl: Agents affecting neuromuscular transmission

Example

Action

Effect on Neuromuscular Transmission

Botulinum toxin

Blocks release of ACh from presynaptic terminal

Total blockade of terminals

Curare

Competes with ACh for receptors on motor end plate

Decreases size of EPP; maximal doses produce end plate paralysis of respiratory muscles and death

Neostigmine

Inhibits acetylcholinesterase

Prolongs and enhances action of ACh at

muscle end plate

Hemicholinium

Blocks reuptake of choline

Depletes ACh stores from presynaptic terminal

questions.text: Which of the following areas is referred to as Sudeck's point?
questions.solution:
The rectosigmoid region is called Sudeck's point. This region receives its blood supply from the superior hemorrhoidal artery and distal sigmoid branches, both terminal branches of the IMA and prone to atherosclerotic changes.

Splenic flexure (also known as Griffith's point) is a watershed area between the superior and inferior mesenteric arteries.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely embryological defect causing tetralogy of Fallot?

choices.text: Failure in formation of conotruncal ridges

questions.solution:
The Tetralogy of Fallot is caused by the anterior displacement of the conotruncal septum. This condition is marked by four main characteristics: Pulmonary stenosis, ventricular septal defect, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy.

It is represented by the schematic image given below. 

Other options:

Option A: Abnormal spiraling of the conotruncal septum leads to the transposition of the great arteries (TGA). This leads to the aorta originating from the right ventricle, and the pulmonary artery from the left ventricle.

It is represented by the schematic image given below.

Option B: Persistent truncus arteriosus (PTA) is due to an embryological defect causing a failure in the formation of the conotruncal ridges. This leads to the absence of a conotruncal or aorticopulmonary septum which normally divides the outflow tract into the aorta and the pulmonary trunk.

Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection causes the drainage of oxygenated blood (brought in by pulmonary veins) into the systemic venous circulation.

It is represented by the schematic image given below.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in some congenital heart defects

Boot shaped heart - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Egg on string appearance - Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)

 

Snowman's heart appearance or figure of 8 appearance - Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Box Shaped Heart - Ebstein's Anomaly

questions.text: An 8-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of multiple episodes of seizures and hypoglycemia. On examination, there is growth retardation, hepatomegaly, and hypotonia. Lab workup reveals normal serum lactate, uric acid, and serum triglyceride levels. A liver biopsy demonstrates hepatocytes with large glycogen stores. Biochemical analysis reveals glycogen with short outer chains. Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of an infant presenting with hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, hypotonia, and growth retardation with normal blood lactate and uric acid levels, the most likely diagnosis is Cori disease. 

Cori disease (type III glycogen storage disorder) occurs due to a deficiency of the glycogen debranching enzyme. The features of Cori disease include hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and hyperlipidemia but with normal blood lactate and uric acid levels. Muscle weakness and atrophy can also occur in these patients. Liver biopsy shows the accumulation of glycogen in the form of limit-dextrins (glycogen with short outer chain) in hepatocyte cytosol and the presence of fibrous septa. Cori disease can be differentiated from Von Gierke disease on the basis of:

  Von Gierke Disease Cori Disease
Deficient enzyme Glucose-6-phosphatase Debranching enzyme
Hypoglycemia Present Present
Hepatomegaly Present Present
Renal disease Present (proteinuria, hypertension, renal stones) Absent
Blood lactate Elevated Normal
Blood uric acid Elevated Normal
Gluconeogenesis Impaired, since glucose-6-phosphatase is required in the final step of gluconeogenesis Intact

questions.text: All of the following are features of asteroid hyalosis except?

choices.text: Occurs due to a degenerative process
Seen as tiny round yellow–white opacities
Particles sediment inferiorly when the eye is immobile

questions.solution:
Particles of Asteroid hyalosis do not sediment when the eye is immobile while Synchysis scintillans are vitreous opacities that sediment in the lower part of the vitreous cavity when the eye is immobile. 

  Asteroid hyalosis Synchysis scintillans
Pathophysiology

Occurs due to a degenerative process, commonly seen in diabetes

 Consequence of chronic vitreous hemorrhage

Composition

Calcium pyrophosphate particles

 Cholesterol derived from plasma cells or degraded products of erythrocytes present freely or within foreign body giant cells
Appearance Numerous tiny round yellow-white opacities 

Numerous flat golden-brown refractile particles
Sedimentation Do not sediment inferiorly when the eye is immobile

Sediment in the lower part of the vitreous cavity due to gravity.

 

The below image shows Synchysis scintillans.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is a type of ring precipitation test?
questions.solution:
Ascoli's thermoprecipitin test is an example of a ring precipitation test.

The formation of an insoluble antigen-antibody complex when a soluble antigen combines with its antibody is known as precipitation. This occurs in the presence of electrolytes at a suitable temperature and pH. When the precipitate remains suspended instead of sedimenting it is known as flocculation. They may be of different types as follows:

  • Ring test: Antigen solution is layered over a column of antisera. A ring of precipitate is formed at the junction of the two liquids. Examples are 
    • Ascoli's thermoprecipitin test used for the diagnosis of anthrax
    • The Lancefield technique of grouping Streptococci
  • Slide test: Flocculation occurs when drops of the antigen and antiserum are placed on a slide and mixed. The VDRL test (Option A) used to diagnose syphilis is an example.
  • Tube test: Serial dilutions of the toxin are added to fixed quantities of antitoxin for quantitative standardization. Kahn test (Option B) is used to diagnose syphilis is an example.
  • Immunodiffusion or Precipitation in gel: Precipitation occurs in a gel such as soft agar by diffusion of the substances through it. It may be divided based on single or double diffusion in one or two dimensions. Elek's gel precipitation test (Option D) used to determine the toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria is an example of double diffusion in two dimensions.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman is diagnosed to have cervical cancer. IVP shows features suggestive of hydronephrosis. Which stage is it according to the FIGO staging of cervical cancer?

FIGO - International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics
questions.solution:
Cervical cancer with hydronephrosis is classified as Stage III B  according to FIGO staging.

Cervical cancer is the most common gynecological cancer. The FIGO staging uses clinical, radiological, or pathological findings to stage cervical cancer from Stage I to IV.

Stage III cervical carcinoma involves the lower 1/3rd of the vagina, with or without pelvic wall extension, hydronephrosis, and lymph node involvement. It is further staged as follows:

  • Stage III A: Lower 1/3rd of the vagina involvement, no pelvic wall extension
  • Stage III B: Pelvic wall involvement with or without hydronephrosis or a non-functioning kidney
  • Stage III C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or paraaortic lymph nodes
    • Stage III C1: Metastasis to pelvic lymph node only
    • Stage III C2: Metastasis to para-aortic lymph nodes

Note: If the carcinoma had extended beyond the true pelvis, involving adjacent pelvic organs like the bladder or rectum, it would've been classified as Stage IV A.

Related Pearl: Staging of Carcinoma Cervix

Stage I - limited to the cervix

  • A: Microscopic lesion
    • A1 - stromal invasion <3mm depth
    • A2 - a stromal invasion of ≥3 and <5mm depth
  • B: Macroscopic lesion
    • B1 - stromal invasion ≥5mm depth & tumor size <2cm 
    • B2 - tumor size ≥2cm to <4cm 
    • B3 - tumor size ≥4cm 

Stage II - involves upper 2/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement
    • A1 - tumor size <4cm 
    • A2 - tumor size ≥4cm 
  • B: Extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage III - spreads to lower 1/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina
  • B: Extends to the pelvic wall (hydronephrosis/non-functioning kidney)
  • C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent
    • C1: pelvic lymph node involved
    • C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

Stage IV - metastasis

  • A: Bladder/bowel involvement (adjacent pelvic organs)
  • B: Distant metastasis

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

Related Pearl: General treatment for primary invasive cervical carcinoma

Stages Fertility preserved Fertility not preserved
IA1 Cervical conization Simple hysterectomy
IA1 (LVSI) Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy Modified radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy
IA2

1. Cervical conization with extraperitoneal pelvic lymphadenectomy

2. Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

 Modified Radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

IB1

Some IB2, IIA1

 Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy (or)chemoradiation Radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy (or) chemoradiation
Bulky IB3, IIA2 Chemoradiation
IIB to IVA Chemoradiation or pelvic exenteration 
IVB Palliative chemotherapy or palliative radiotherapy or supportive care

questions.text: A 48-year-old male patient is undergoing surgery for intestinal obstruction under isoflurane. Suddenly the patient develops tachypnea, tachycardia, and hyperpyrexia. His capnograph is given below. Investigations reveal hyperkalemia and metabolic acidosis. What is the next best step in the management?

choices.text: Administer bicarbonate to correct metabolic acidosis
IV Paracetamol and cold tepid sponging to tackle the hyperpyrexia
Discontinue Isoflurane followed by IV dantrolene sodium

questions.solution:
Capnograph shows a sudden and progressive increase in ETCO2 which is typical of malignant hyperthermia. The next best step is to discontinue isoflurane followed by the administration of dantrolene sodium.

Protocol for immediate treatment of malignant hyperthermia

  1. Discontinue volatile anesthetic and succinylcholine. Notify the surgeon. Call for help.
  2. Mix dantrolene sodium with sterile distilled water, and administer 2.5 mg/kg intravenously as soon as possible.
  3. Administer bicarbonate for metabolic acidosis.
  4. Institute cooling measures (lavage, cooling blanket, cold intravenous solutions).
  5. Treat severe hyperkalemia with dextrose, 25–50 g intravenously, and regular insulin, 10–20 units intravenously (adult dose).
  6. Administer antiarrhythmic agents if needed despite correction of hyperkalemia and acidosis.
  7. Monitor end-tidal CO2 tension, electrolytes, blood gases, creatine kinase, serum myoglobin, core temperature, urinary output and color,and coagulation status.

Malignant hyperthermia is a condition in which the patient develops sustained muscle contraction and hyperthermia. It occurs following the administration of succinylcholine and other inhaled anesthetics like halothane, isoflurane, sevoflurane, desflurane, etc. It is due to the mutation of the gene for the ryanodine receptor (Ryr 1), located on chromosome 19.

Drugs known to trigger malignant hyperthermia include inhaled general anesthetics (Ether, Halothane, Methoxyflurane, Enflurane, Isoflurane, Desflurane, Sevoflurane) and succinylcholine.

Clinical features include muscle rigidity, tachycardia, unexplained hypercarbia, and increased temperature. Hypertension may be rapidly followed by hypotension and cardiac depression. Dark-colored urine typically identifies myoglobinuria.

Laboratory testing typically reveals mixed metabolic and respiratory acidosis with a marked base deficit, hyperkalemia, hypermagnesemia, and reduced mixed-venous oxygen saturation.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

Related Pearl: Malignant hyperthermia key features

Pathophysiology:

  • Prolonged opening of functionally altered ryanodine receptors, leading to uncontrolled release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction.

Drugs known to trigger malignant hyperthermia:

  • Inhaled anesthetics: Halothane, Isoflurane, Sevoflurane, Desflurane, Ether, Methoxyflurane
  • Depolarising muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine

Clinical signs:

  • Increased metabolism: Increased EtCO2, decreased SpO2, metabolic acidosis
  • Increased sympathetic activity: Tachycardia, hypertension, arrythmia
  • Muscle damage: Masseter spasm, generalised rigidity, hyperkalemia, rhabdomyolysis, myoglobinuria
  • Hyperthermia: Fever, sweating

 Treatment: 

  • Discontinuation of all anesthetic agents
  • Hyperventilation with 100% O2
  • Dantrolene: 2.5 mg/kg intravenously every 5 min until the episode is terminated (upper limit - 10 mg/kg).
  • Correction of acid-base, electrolyte abnormality 
  • Cooling the patient

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought with hypotonia and loss of motor milestones. On examination, hepatosplenomegaly and macular cherry-red spot are noted. Foam cells are seen on bone marrow biopsy. Which is the most likely deficient enzyme in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of progressive neurodegeneration (loss of motor milestones, hypotonia) along with hepatosplenomegaly, macular cherry-red spot, and foam cells on bone marrow biopsy point to a diagnosis of Niemann-Pick disease. The enzyme deficient in this disease is sphingomyelinase.

Niemann-Pick disease is disorder of infancy which is almost always fatal by 2-3 years of age. Although the affected infants are normal at birth, they soon present with failure to thrive, hepatosplenomegaly, and rapid psychomotor retardation. Over time, there is severe loss of motor function and deterioration of intellect and death occurs by 3 years of age.

Niemann-Pick disease occurs due to the deficient activity of acid sphingomyelinase enzyme. There is extensive accumulation of sphingomyelin in the monocyte-macrophage system. Lipid laden foam cells are observed in bone marrow and lymph nodes. The diagnosis is confirmed by measuring the sphingomyelinase levels in the peripheral leucocytes. 

The management of Niemann-Pick disease is mostly supportive, such as physical therapy and a feeding tube for nutrition. Olipudase alfa has been recently approved for non-CNS manifestations of Niemann-Pick disease. 

Other options:

Option B: Hexoseaminidase A deficiency is seen in Tay-Sachs disease. While it also presents with progressive neurodegeneration and macular cherry-red spot, there is no organomegaly and lysosomes with onion skin are seen. 

Option C: Glucocerebrosidase deficiency is seen in Gaucher disease. The patients present with hematological abnormalities, organomegaly, and skeletal manifestations in the form of bone pain and pathological fractures. Bone marrow examination shows macrophages with characteristic crumbled tissue paper appearance.

Option D: Galactocerebrosidase deficiency is seen in Krabbe disease. Both peripheral and central myelin is affected in this disease. The patients present with spasticity and intellectual impairment (destruction of central myelin) and peripheral neuropathy and absent deep tendon reflexes (destruction of peripheral myelin). Optic atrophy may also be seen.

Related Pearl: Important causes of cherry-red spots

  • Commotio retinae
  • Central retinal and cilioretinal artery occlusion
  • Metabolic storage diseases
    • GM1 gangliosidosis
    • Mucolipidosis type I (sialidosis)
    • GM2 gangliosidosis (Tay-Sachs disease and Sandhoff disease)
    • Farber disease
    • Niemann–Pick disease
  • Retinotoxicity due to specific agents, including quinine, dapsone, gentamicin, carbon monoxide, and methanol

Related Pearl: Examples of Sphingolipidoses (Lipids-Storage Disease)

S. No.

Disease

Enzyme Deficiency

Lipid

Accumulating

Clinical Symptoms

1

Tay–Sachs disease

Hexosaminidase A

Ganglioside

Mental retardation, blindness, muscular weakness

2

Sandhoff's disease

Hexosaminidase A and B

Globoside & Ganglioside

Similar to Tay–Sachs disease but also has hepatosplenomegaly and skeletal dysplasias

3

questions.text: A primigravida presents with active labor at 30 weeks of gestation. The baby is in breech presentation. The entrapment of the aftercoming head is managed as shown in the image below. Which of the following is true regarding this management?

choices.text: It is called the Duhrssen’s incision
It is done in a completely dilated cervix
Symphyseal carti­lage and ligamentous supports are cut to widen the symphysis pubis
It is done to enlarge the vaginal introitus

questions.solution:
The image depicts Duhrssen’s incision, 

  • Can be made at 2 and 10 O’ clock position on the cervix.
  • An additional incision at 6 o’clock position is sometimes needed.
  • Done for delivery of aftercoming head in breech or delivery of head through an incompletely dilated cervix.
  • There is a significant risk of haemorrhage; the cervical incision may extend upwards within the broad ligament causing broad ligament haematoma.

An episiotomy, on the other hand, begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline, which yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline. The objective is to enlarge the vaginal introitus so as to facilitate easy and safe delivery of the fetus and to minimize overstretching and rupture of the perineal muscles and fascia, which might end up in complete tears.

Other alternatives include intravenous nitroglycerin, typically 100 μg, to provide cervical relaxation. General anaesthesia with halogenated agents is another option.

As a last resort, the following methods are used:

  • Zavanelli manoeuvre: It involves the replacement of the fetal head into the pelvis followed by cesarean delivery. This is performed for the protruding head and intractable shoulder dystocia.
  • Symphysiotomy: The intervening symphyseal carti­lage and ligamentous supports are cut to widen the symphysis pubis. It is also used to aid the delivery of an entrapped aftercoming head.

questions.text: A male patient complains of fatigue, low self-esteem, feeling hopeless, and not being able to concentrate on work. A diagnosis of dysthymia is made. What is the minimum duration of the symptoms to arrive at this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The minimum duration that the symptoms should persist in order to make a diagnosis of dysthymia /persistent depressive disorder is two years. 

Dysthymia refers to a persistent depressive mood lasting for more than two years in adults (1 year in children and adolescents). It is not severe enough to be diagnosed as major depression and has an insidious onset. The low mood persists for most of the day. It is accompanied by low self-esteem, insomnia or hypersomnia, fatigue, poor appetite,  poor concentration, and hopelessness.

The onset can be either early (before the age of 21) which is more common or late. It affects both genders equally. It is frequently associated with depression, anxiety disorders, substance abuse, and borderline personality disorder.

The two important differential diagnoses are minor depressive disorder and recurrent brief depressive disorder. In the former, patients have episodic symptoms and euthymic moods in between. In the latter, the episodic nature of more severe symptoms is seen.

The most effective treatment involves a combination of psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy. Insight-oriented psychotherapy, cognitive therapy, and behavioral therapy are used. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) like escitalopram and sertraline are effective.

Hospitalization is usually not indicated in dysthymia. However, severe symptoms, marked impairment in social or occupational functioning, and suicidal ideation require hospitalization.

Related Pearl: Timeline in psychiatry

Maternal blues Starts 2–3 days after delivery and usually resolves within 10 days
Postpartum mood disturbances Onset within 4 weeks of delivery
Brief psychotic disorder Lasts < 1 month, usually stress-related
Schizophreniform disorder Lasts 1-6 months

questions.text: Which of the following DPP4 inhibitors can be given to a patient with renal failure without dose adjustment?
questions.solution:
Linagliptin can be given to a patient with renal failure without dose adjustment.

Linagliptin is a dipeptidyl-peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor. It is used in type 2 diabetes as monotherapy or in combination therapy when metformin is not tolerated or contraindicated. It binds extensively to plasma proteins and is cleared primarily by the hepatobiliary system. Hence, no dosage adjustment is needed in renal failure.

Other DPP-4 inhibitors (sitagliptin, vildagliptin, saxagliptin, alogliptin) show renal elimination and therefore require dose reduction in renal failure.

Dipeptidyl peptidase-4 inhibitors enhance the release of insulin postprandially, decrease glucagon, and thereby lower mealtime as well as fasting glucose. They are weight neutral.

questions.text:
Match the following syndromes and the most likely cardiac conditions associated with them.
Syndromes Cardiac conditions
1. Turner's syndrome a. Supravalvular aortic stenosis
2. Down's Syndrome b. Bicuspid aortic valve/ Coarctation of the aorta
3. Noonan syndrome c. Endocardial cushion defects
4. Williams syndrome d. Pulmonary stenosis
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

Syndromes Cardiac conditions
1. Turner's syndrome

b. Bicuspid aortic valve/ Coarctation of the aorta
2. Down's Syndrome

c. Endocardial cushion defects
3. Noonan syndrome

d. Pulmonary stenosis
4. Williams syndrome

a. Supravalvular aortic stenosis

 

Turner's syndrome is the most common sex chromosome abnormality in females. The classical karyotype is 45 XO.

Some patients may present during infancy. They mainly present with edema of the dorsum of the hand and foot due to lymphatic stasis. The most important cause of increased mortality in children with Turner's syndrome is cardiac abnormalities. Clinical features of Turner's syndrome include short stature, low posterior hairline, broad chest, widely spaced nipples, coarctation of the aorta, bicuspid aortic valve, cubitus valgus, and pigmented nevi. Turner's syndrome is a common cause of primary amenorrhea. The ovaries are reduced to atrophic fibrous bands without ova and follicles. These are called streak ovaries. At puberty, they fail to develop secondary sexual characteristics.

Down's Syndrome or Trisomy 21 is the most common chromosomal abnormality and a major cause of intellectual disability. Clinical features include prominent occiput, intellectual disability, micrognathia, low-set ears, overlapping fingers, simian palmar crease, and congenital heart defects like endocardial cushion defects.

The image below shows the facial features of Down's syndrome.

Noonan syndrome follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance. It involves mutations in the RAS-MAPK pathway. (Mitogen-activated protein kinase pathway). The most common of these is the PTPN11 which encodes a protein tyrosine phosphatase on chromosome 12. The clinical features include short stature, short, webbed neck, cystic hygroma, tall forehead, low posterior hairline, dental malocclusion. Although it shares many clinical features with Turner’s syndrome, Noonan syndrome affects both sexes. The common cardiac abnormality is pulmonary valve stenosis. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and ASD may also be seen.

William's syndrome is a developmental disorder caused by microdeletion in elastin. They present with elfin facies, mental retardation, short stature, hypersocial personality, and hypercalcemia. The cardiac condition that is associated most commonly is supravalvular aortic stenosis. 

Solving just "Down's Syndrome -> c. Endocardial cushion defects" could have helped narrow down the relevant answer.

questions.text: A psychotic patient developed voluntary purposeless movements and was once observed to be standing still for hours with waxy flexibility and negativism. Which of the following is likely to worsen her condition?
questions.solution:
Olanzapine is likely to worsen her condition.

The clinical features are suggestive of a catatonic disorder. Antipsychotics like olanzapine can worsen catatonia due to Parkinsonian side effects and can increase the risk for neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

Catatonia is a syndrome characterised by striking behav­ioral abnormalities such as motoric immobility or excite­ment, negativism, echolalia (mimicry of speech), or echopraxia (mimicry of movement).

The clinical picture may include three or more of the following features:

  1. Stupor: Absence of psychomotor activity and not actively relating to the environment.
  2. Catalepsy: Passive induction of a posture held against gravity.
  3. Waxy flexibility: Slight, even resistance to positioning by examiner.
  4. Negativism: Opposition or no response to instructions or external stimuli.
  5. Posturing: Spontaneous and active maintenance of a posture against gravity.
  6. Mannerism: Odd, circumstantial caricature of normal actions.
  7. Stereotypy: Repetitive, abnormally frequent, non-goal-directed movements
  8. Automatic obedience: Commands are followed automatically, irrespective of their nature.
  9. Grimacing
  10. Ambitendency: Due to ambivalence, opposing actions are carried out.
  11. Echopraxia: Mimicking another's movement.
  12. Echolalia: Mimicking another's speech.
  13. Mutism: Very little or no verbal response to instructions or external stimuli.
  14. Verbigeration: Incomprehensible speech.

The catatonic disorder may occur due to:

  • Advanced mood or psychotic illnesses
  • Neurologi­cal disorders (e.g., nonconvulsive status epilepticus and head trauma)
  • Infections (e.g., encephalitis)
  • Metabolic disturbances (e.g., hepatic encephalopathy, hyponatremia, and hypercalcemia)
  • Drugs induced- like corticoste­roids, immunosuppressants, and antipsychotics (i.e., neurolep­tic) agents.

Management: The primary treatment includes:

  • Identifying and treating underlying medical or pharmacological causes. Any offending substances should be removed.
  • Benzodiazepines, especially lorazepam, are effective in improving the symptoms. Zolpidem, a positive allosteric modulator of GABA-A receptors, is a safe and effective treatment alternative
  • Electroconvulsive therapy is the definitive treatment in cases of life-threatening catatonia (if the patient is unable to eat) or if the patient has developed malignant catatonia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with a 2-month history of cough and shortness of breath is found to have bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy on a chest X-ray. She also complains of dry eyes and nodules in the skin over her arms. Which of the following findings can be seen in the biopsy of her lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a woman with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, a history of cough, dry eyes, nodules in the skin over her arms, points to a diagnosis of sarcoidosis. In this condition, naked granuloma can be seen on lymph node biopsy.

Sarcoidosis is a systemic granulomatous disease that most commonly presents as bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Lesions of the eyes and skin are also very common in these patients. It is seen more in middle-aged women than in men.

Sarcoidosis results from an increase in CD4+ T-cells (increased CD4+:CD8+ ratio). As a result, cytokines like IL-2, TNF, IL-8, and IFN-gamma will increase. These cytokines are the cause of granuloma formation in this disorder.

It presents with granulomas in multiple organs. They are classically described as non-caseating granulomas composed of epithelioid macrophages with giant cells. There is no central necrosis as there would be in tubercular granulomas. Naked granulomas are non-caseating granulomas minimally surrounded by lymphocytes.

Laminated calcium and protein-containing bodies called Schaumann bodies (shown in the image below) and star-shaped inclusions called asteroid bodies are also found in the giant cells of most of these granulomas. These are not pathognomonic to sarcoidosis and can also be found in other granulomatous diseases like tuberculosis.

 

Other options:

Option A: Stellate granulomas are granulomas containing central granular debris and neutrophils. They are characteristically seen in cat-scratch disease caused by B. henselae.

The image below shows stellate granuloma

 

Option B: Foreign body granulomas are incited by relatively inert foreign bodies, such as talc, sutures. Epithelioid cells and giant cells are apposed to the surface of the foreign body. The foreign material can usually be identified in the center of the granuloma.

The given image shows suture granuloma. The suture material is surrounded by lymphocytic infiltration

Option C: Durck granulomas are seen in cerebral malaria.

The image below shows a Durck granuloma

questions.text: A student was asked to record ECG by using bipolar limb leads. The below image shows the arrangement of the bipolar electrodes and the potential recorded. What is the potential recorded across the third electrical meter?
questions.solution:
The potential recorded in the electrical meter that represents lead III is +0.5 mV, according to Einthoven’s Law.

Einthoven’s Law describes the principle behind Einthoven's triangle which is formed by the arrangement of three bipolar limb leads. Einthoven’s law states that if the ECGs are recorded simultaneously with the three limb leads, the sum of the potentials recorded in leads I and III will equal the potential in lead II.

In the given image, Lead I is represented by the electrodes connected to the left arm and right arm, and the potential recorded is +0.7 mV. Lead II is represented by the electrodes connected to the left leg and right arm and the potential recorded is +1.2 mV. According to Einthoven's law:

Lead I potential + Lead III potential = Lead II potential

Therefore, Lead III potential = Lead II potential – Lead I potential = (1.2 - 0.7) = +0.5 mV.

questions.text: How many healthcare providers are required to safely remove a helmet as per the ATLS guidelines?
questions.solution:
Removing a helmet properly is a procedure that requires two individuals as per ATLS 10th edition.

First-person restricts the cervical spine motion while the second person tries to expand the helmet laterally. Then, the second person gently removes the helmet, ensuring that the nose and occiput are cleared with ease. After the helmet is removed, the first person supports the weight of the patient’s head and the second person takes over cervical spine motion restriction.

questions.text: The stain used for melanin in the below image is
questions.solution:
The stain used for melanin in the above image is Masson Fontana stain. Other stains for melanin are Schmorl’s method and an enzyme histochemical method called DOPA oxidase method. This DOPA oxidase method is the most specific stain for melanin.

Other options:

  • Oil red stains neutral lipids and fatty acids
  • PAS stains glycogen, mucin, mucoprotein, glycoproteins and fungi
  • Gomori methamine stains fungi

questions.text: The initial RNA transcript is modified and now has AAAAA sequence on the 3' end. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this process?

choices.text: Poly-A tail protects the RNA from exonuclease attack
Poly-A polymerase is involved in the process

questions.solution:
The presence of poly-A sequence on the 3' end of the RNA transcript indicates polyadenylation of the 3' end. This process does not require a DNA template.

Polyadenylation is a posttranscriptional processing step. The mRNA is first cleaved downstream from AAUAAA recognition sequence — this is known as the polyadenylation sequence. Following this, a chain of adenylates (adenosine monophosphate) is added to the 3' tail. This poly-A tail is not transcribed from the DNA, and thus does not require a DNA template. Rather, an enzyme called poly-A polymerase (option D) is involved in polyadenylation using ATP as the substrate molecule.

Poly-A tail stabilizes the mRNA and prevents its degradation by exonucleases. It also enables its exit from the nucleus. Other posttranscriptional modifications include 5' capping and splicing. Note that all posttranscriptional modification steps occur in the nucleus (option A).

5' capping of the RNA refers to the attaching of 7-methylguanosine to the 5′ terminal end of the mRNA. This connection is resistant to nucleases. Note that while the addition of guanine monophosphate occurs in the nucleus, the methylation of the guanine occurs in the cytosol. The addition of the 5' cap also stabilizes the mRNA and enables translation.

Splicing refers to the process of removing introns (intervening sequences that do not code for proteins) and joining exons (the coding or expressed sequences), carried out by the spliceosome.

Related Pearl: Types of RNA

Protein coding RNA

Non Protein coding RNA

mRNA

Ribosomal RNAs (rRNA)

Long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs)

Transfer RNAs (tRNA)

Small nuclear RNAs (snRNAs)

Micro and silencing RNAs (miRNAs and siRNAs)

questions.text: A patient was brought to the casualty after sustaining an electric injury at home. All of the following lesions may be noted on the body during clinical examination except?
questions.solution:
Joule burns, spark lesions and crocodile skin effects can be seen clinically in cases of electric injury on examination. Bone pearls or wax drippings are a radiological finding.

The heat generated by the current in electrical injuries may melt the calcium phosphate in bones. This is radiologically seen as typical round dense foci known as bone pearls or wax drippings.

Other lesions seen in electrical burns or electrocution are:

  • Joule burns are specific and diagnostic of contact with electricity. These are found at the point of the entry of the current. They are round or oval shallow craters, one to three centimeters in diameter. The image given below shows a Joule burn.
  • Spark lesions are seen when contact is less firm or a narrow air gap exists between the skin and the conductor. They occur due to outer skin keratin melting over a small area which on cooling fuses into a hard brownish nodule, usually raised above the surrounding surface. 
  • The crocodile skin effect is caused by high-tension current burns causing multiple spark lesions. The image given below shows high voltage burns due to electrocution causing multiple spark lesions i.e. crocodile skin effect.

The image below shows the various electrical marks:

questions.text: A child presented with diarrhea, cough, and wheezing for the past 6 months. He is underweight and stunted for his age. Blood tests showed mild eosinophilia. The appearance of eggs in the stool specimen is shown below. The likely cause is?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing an oval egg with rhabditiform larvae indicate infection by Strongyloides stercoralis.

The worm is ovoviviparous. The eggs contain fully formed larvae that hatch out immediately.

 Characteristics of the egg of Strongyloides stercoralis:

  • Thin-walled
  • Transparent
  • Ovoid in shape
  • Contain the rhabditiform (first stage) larva.

It is unique among human nematodes as it has a parasitic cycle and a free-living soil cycle, during which it persists for a long duration in the soil. The image given below shows the life cycle of Strongyloides stercoralis.

The infective form of Strongyloides is the filariform larva. When a person walks barefoot on soil containing the infective filariform larvae, they penetrate the skin and enter the circulation. Then, they migrate to the small intestine.

Here, the larvae molt twice and become adult female worms. The eggs laid by the female in the intestinal mucosa hatch immediately releasing the rhabditiform larva (L1 stage). These rhabditiform larvae in the bowel can develop directly into filariform larvae that penetrate the colonic wall or perianal skin and enter the circulation to repeat the migration. This establishes ongoing internal reinfection.

This autoinfection is not seen in Ancylostoma or Necator life cycle.

Strongyloidiasis (infection caused by S. stercoralis) is generally benign and asymptomatic. The clinical disease may have cutaneous (dermatitis at the site of penetration, perianal pruritis, urticaria), pulmonary (bronchopneumonia, chronic bronchitis, asthma) and intestinal manifestations (mucus diarrhea, dysentery).

The rhabditiform larva (not the egg) in feces can be seen under a microscope, and eosinophilia in the blood is diagnostic of the disease.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: In order to diagnose deep vein thrombosis in a patient with varicose veins, the doctor after ruling out arterial occlusive disease wraps the patient's affected lower limb in an elastic bandage. The patient is then asked to walk around. The test performed here is?
questions.solution:
The test performed in the above clinical scenario is Perthe’s test.

In Perthe’s Test, the affected lower limb is wrapped in an elastic bandage, after ruling out arterial occlusive disease. The patient is then asked to walk around. Severe cramping pain arises if there is deep vein thrombosis. 

Other options:

Option A: Schwartz test - on tapping a long saphenous varicose vein in the lower part, the impulse can be felt at the saphenous opening with the other hand. 

Option B: Modified Perthe’s test - A tourniquet is tied around the upper part of the thigh to prevent reflux down the vein and the patient is asked to walk around. In the presence of normal communicating and deep veins, the varicose veins will shrink. If there is any block, the veins will get more distended. 

Option D: Morrissey’s cough impulse test - The limb is elevated to empty the varicose veins. Now it is put to bed and the patient is asked to cough forcibly. An expansile cough impulse is felt at the saphenous opening if the saphenofemoral valve is incompetent. Similarly, a bruit may be heard on auscultation.

questions.text: A  patient presented to the OPD with complaints of hematuria and flank pain. CT was performed and the patient was diagnosed to have a grade II renal cyst according to Bosniak classification. How would you manage the patient?

choices.text: Reassure and mention that there is no need for followup.
Counsel thoroughly about need for follow up imaging after 6 months
Radiofrequency ablation followed by 3 monthly followup
Partial nephrectomy followed by a 6 monthly followup

questions.solution:
Management of Renal cysts classified under Bosniak category II requires no follow-up as the risk of malignancy is very low. It is actually the Bosniak Category IIF cysts,  where ‘F’ indicates the need for follow-up, that require further imaging. 

The Bosniak classification system of renal cystic masses is helpful in predicting the risks of malignancy and identifying the appropriate choice of treatment. It includes,

Classification:

Bosniak 1

  • Simple cyst: Not malignant, imperceptible wall, rounded.
  • No further workup is required

Bosniak 2

  • Minimally complex: Not malignant, septa <1mm, thin calcifications, renal lesions <3 cm.
  • No further workup is required.

Bosniak 2F

  • Percentage malignant: ~ 5% 
  • Minimally complex: increased number of septa, minimally thickened with nodular or thick calcifications
  • Follow-up: Needs ultrasound/CT follow-up - in about 3/6/9 months(duration is uncertain)

Bosniak 3

  • Indeterminate
  • Percentage malignant: ~30-100%
  • Thick, nodular multiple septa or wall with measurable enhancement, hyperdense on CT.
  • Should undergo a biopsy to identify those patients requiring surgery
  • Treatment/work-up: Partial nephrectomy or radiofrequency ablation in elderly or poor surgical candidates.

Bosniak 4

  • Clearly malignant (67-100%)
  • Solid mass with a large cystic or necrotic component
  • Treatment: Partial or total nephrectomy

questions.text:
You are asked to conduct an autopsy of a person who was found dead at his home and notice multiple areas of discoloration on the body on examination. Which of the following features may be in favor of antemortem bruise?
  1. Discoloration predominantly over the dependent parts.
  2. Ill-defined margins that merge with the surrounding.
  3. Deep reddish-black discoloration of subcutaneous tissues.
  4. No discoloration in areas under pressure.
  5. The surface appears swollen.
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, discoloration with a swollen surface, ill-defined margins, and reddish-black discoloration of subcutaneous tissues are suggestive of antemortem bruise and must be differentiated from postmortem hypostasis which is a normal postmortem change.

Postmortem hypostasis occurs due to the distension of vessels with blood in the dependant parts of the body while bruises occur due to the rupture of vessels and extravasation of blood.

Feature Postmortem hypostasis Bruise
Site Over the most dependent parts (Option 1) Occurs at and surrounding the injury. May be anywhere over the body.
Appearance No swelling or abrasions present Swollen surface. Abrasions may be present.
Margins Clearly defined Ill-defined and merge with surroundings
Color Uniform bluish-purple Varied colors based on the different ages of the bruise
Incision Blood in the vessels is easily washed away Blood in the subcutaneous tissue cannot be easily washed away
Subcutaneous tissue Pale

Deep reddish-black
 Effect of pressure Absent in areas of pressure (Option 4) Appear lighter in color over areas of pressure

questions.text: Which of the following features goes against the diagnosis of essential tremors?
questions.solution:
The presence of bradykinesia with tremors is likely to point to a diagnosis of Parkinson's disease, not essential tremors.

Essential tremor (ET) is the most prevalent movement disorder. Although it can appear in children, its prevalence increases in people aged over 70 years. It is characterized by high-frequency tremors, most commonly involving the upper extremities. These tremors are usually symmetrical and bilateral (option A). These tremors manifest when the person is trying to do some activity (action tremors, option B) and are typically made worse by stress and improved by alcohol (option D). Approximately half the patients with ET have a positive family history.

A close differential diagnosis of ET is Parkinson's disease. However, the tremor in PD is mainly resting tremor – although there can be significant overlap. Patients with PD also have bradykinesia, and the tremor usually begins unilaterally. Further, patients with PD have micrographia, while those with ET have large handwriting as an effect of the tremors.

The standard drugs used to treat essential tremors are beta blockers and primidone. Some benefit has also been seen with gabapentin and topiramate, but they are not widely used.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman diagnosed with tubercular meningitis has a peculiar breathing pattern as shown in the image below. What is the pattern of breathing?
questions.solution:
The pattern of breathing in the case presented is Biot's breathing.

Biot's breathing is a variant of Cheyne-Stokes breathing. It is characterized by periods of apnea that alternate irregularly with a series of breaths of equal depth that terminate abruptly. It is seen in meningitis.

Other Options:

Option B: Cheyne-Stokes Breathing: It is the period of apnea alternating with hyperapnea.It is seen in patients with cardiac failure, raised intracranial pressure, and brainstem lesions.

Option C: Kussmaul’s Breathing: It is a type of rapid, deep breathing. It is seen in cases of metabolic acidosis.

Option D: Pursed lip breathing is seen in COPD patients. The purpose of this breathing is to slow down the airflow during the exhalation to build up back pressure in the airway to avoid a sudden drop in intrapulmonary pressure resulting in alveolar and airway collapse.

questions.text: The posture shown in image is seen in :
questions.solution:
The given image shows decorticate posturing. It is caused due to upper midbrain damage.

Decorticate posture is caused due to damage to the upper midbrain. The upper limbs are flexed, the lower limbs are extended with toes pointed slightly inward, and the head is extended. Decorticate posturing is given a score of 3 in best motor response on the Glasgow Coma Scale.

Decerebrate posture is caused by damage to the lower midbrain and upper pons. Here, lower extremities are extended with toes pointed inward and upper extremities extended with fingers flexed and forearms pronated. The neck and head are extended. Decerebrate posture has a score of 2 in best motor response on the Glasgow Coma Scale.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A patient presents with the findings shown in the image below. He also has angular stomatitis and cheilosis. Which of the following vitamins is deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with mucocutaneous lesions (angular stomatitis and cheilosis) along with the image showing corneal vascularization points to a diagnosis of riboflavin deficiency.

Riboflavin is a vital factor in the metabolism of fat, carbohydrates, and proteins. FAD and FMN are derivatives of riboflavin. Riboflavin thus indirectly acts as an electron donor during the electron transport chain, leading to ATP generation. FAD is also involved in homocysteine metabolism. 

The deficiency of riboflavin presents as nonspecific mucocutaneous lesions, corneal vascularization, and anemia. The diagnosis is established by measuring RBC glutathione reductase activity.

questions.text: Identify the instrument in the given image that is used in spinal fusion surgery.
questions.solution:
The instrument in the given image, used in spinal fusion surgery is a polyaxial pedicle screw. 

Pedicle screws are used in a spinal fusion to add extra support and strength to the fusion while it heals. They are placed above and below the vertebrae that were fused. Rods are used to connect the screws which prevent the movement and allows the bone to heal. The Xray below shows a pedicle screw 

Other options: 

Option A- Herbert screw is a headless screw often used for the fixation of unstable scaphoid fractures. It is cannulated and threaded at both ends.  The proximal portion has a wider pitch to its thread. This screw is used where a standard screw would impinge on adjacent tissues. It is designed to fix fractures of small articular bones such as the carpals and the scaphoid.

Option B: The Kuntscher's cloverleaf intra-medullary nail (K-nail) is used for internal fixation of femoral fractures. The eye at the end of the nail is useful during its removal and the cloverleaf shape on the cross-section provides good rotational stability.

Option D: Acutrax screw is used for the treatment of most scaphoid fractures.  It is a cannulated, headless, and fully threaded screw.

questions.text: The image below shows a clinical finding on the skin of a patient with a particular condition. What is its first-line treatment?
questions.solution:
The given image shows burrows that are found in scabies. The first-line treatment for scabies is topical permethrin.

Scabies is an ectoparasitic infection caused in humans by the Sarcoptes scabiei. Allergic sensitivity to the mite or its products appears to play an important role in determining the development of lesions other than burrows, and in producing pruritus.

  • A single overnight application of 5% permethrin cream from neck to toe in adults and from head to toe in children is the drug of choice for the treatment of scabies in all ages including infants (at least 2 months old) and pregnant women.
  • Topical sulfur applications can be safely used in infants less than 2 months of age, as well as in breastfeeding and pregnant mothers.
  • Topical 1% lindane cream is contraindicated in children, pregnant ladies, and seizure disorders as it is known to cause neurotoxicity.
  • All family members, even if asymptomatic, need to be treated simultaneously for this condition to prevent reinfection.
  • Clothing needs to be disinfected simultaneously.

Related Pearl: Difference between classic and neonatal scabies

  Classic scabies Neonatal scabies
Site of involvement Interdigital webs, trunk, genitals, flexors, sparing of palms and soles, and skin above neck Face, scalp, palm, and soles
Morphology of Lesion Papules, pustules, excoriation, eczematization, burrow Vesicles, pustules, bullae, erosions, and ulcerations
Burrows Present Usually absent

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the four symptoms screening for TB in children with HIV?

choices.text: History of contact with a TB case

questions.solution:
The four symptoms (4S) screening for children with HIV includes:

  1. Current cough
  2. Fever
  3. Weight loss or failure to gain weight
  4. History of contact with a TB case

Night sweats are not a part of the symptoms used for screening children with HIV for TB.

Intensified case finding is done at ART centers for active TB amongst patients with HIV. This enables early diagnosis and treatment of TB, and also reduces transmission from one patient to another. People living with HIV (PLHIV) are screened for TB during their visits to the ART center using the four symptoms (4S) screening. The symptoms considered differ between children (given above) and adults. For adults, the following symptoms are considered:

  1. Current cough
  2. Fever
  3. Weight loss
  4. Night sweats

If the PLHIV is found to be positive for any of these symptoms, they are referred for CB-NAAT for the microbiological confirmation of TB.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male who is a smoker presents with complaints of gastric reflux for the past 3 months. Endoscopy and biopsy results are as shown in the images given below. Which among the following histopathological images correctly represent the carcinoma which this patient would most likely develop?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is characteristic of Barrett’s esophagus which has the potential to transform into an adenocarcinoma in the future. The slide B correctly represents an adenocarcinoma of esophagus showing tubular glands infiltrating the lamina propria and the squamous epithelium.

The given endoscopy reveals patches of red, velvety mucosa extending upward from the gastroesophageal junction.
The histopathological slide shows the intestinal type mucosa (left) replacing the normal squamous esophageal mucosa.
Hence a diagnosis of Barrett’s esophagus can be confirmed.

Other options:

  • Slide A – Represents a normal squamous esophageal epithelium
  • Slide C – Represents a squamous cell carcinoma of esophagus. On high power, keratin pearls are characteristically seen in SCC.
  • Slide D – Represents a squamous papilloma of the esophagus which is a benign entity.

questions.text: All of the following conditions may present with the given immunofluorescence pattern in the skin sample except?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a linear pattern of immunofluorescence and can be seen in Bullous Pemphigoid, Cicatricial Pemphigoid, Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita. Dermatitis herpetiformis shows a pattern of focal granular deposits.

Linear fluorescence pattern as shown below occurs due to deposits along the dermo-epidermal junctions (DEJ). This is seen in the following conditions:

  • Due to linear IgG and C3 deposits in Bullous Pemphigoid, Cicatricial Pemphigoid (10% of the cases show this pattern), and Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita
  • Due to linear deposits of IgA at DEJ in Linear IgA dermatosis

Focal granular deposits of IgA at papillary tips seen in Dermatitis herpetiformis.

Fish-net appearance on immunofluorescence is seen in pemphigus vulgaris. It is due to anti-desmoglein IgG antibodies deposited on the desmosomes (Dsg3 > Dsg1), which are present inter-cellularly.

Pemphigus foliaceus       Crusts and shallow erosions on the scalp, central face, upper chest, and back Acantholytic blister formed in superficial layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG onkeratinocytes Dsg1

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady undergoes a screening test for cervical cancer. Which of the following is correct with respect to the usage of the given instrument?

choices.text: Five rotations in the same direction

questions.solution:
The given image shows a broom that is used to sample both endo- and ectocervix. Five rotations in the same direction are recommended. 

Pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer. Cervical cancer screening should start at age 21. Women aged 21-29 should have a Pap smear every 3 years, while women aged 30-65 should have both HPV and Pap co-test every 5 years.

Before the Pap test:

  • The Pap test should not be deferred due to unexplained discharge or unscheduled bleeding as they may be signs of cervical or other genital tract cancers.
  • Ideally scheduled to avoid menstruation. It is best performed around the time of ovulation.
  • Patients should abstain from vaginal intercourse, douching, tampon use, and intravaginal medications for a minimum of 24 to 48 hours prior to the test.
  • Avoid touching the cervix before performing the Pap test, as dysplastic epithelium may get removed.
  • Ideally, confirmed cervicitis or vaginitis should be treated prior to the test

Procedure:

  • The patient is put in a dorsal position, and Cusco’s self-retaining speculum is introduced.
  • The squamocolumnar junction is scraped with Ayre’s spatula, completing at least one full rotation (Option A). It predominantly samples the ectocervix. 
  • The endocervix is scraped with a cytobrush, which is rotated only one-quarter to one-half turn after the ectocervix has been sampled (Option B).
  • A broom simultaneously samples both endo- and ectocervix. Five rotations in the same direction are recommended since reversing direction may cause loss of cellular material. (Option D)
  • Samples are spread separately on 2 different glass slides and fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol.
  • Stained with Pap stain or Short stain.

The image below shows the instruments used in cervical sampling: The broom, spatula, and cytobrush in order.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman is currently on oral levothyroxine supplementation. Co-administration of all of the following would require an increase in the dose of her levothyroxine, except:
questions.solution:
Androgen therapy in women, decrease levothyroxine dosage requirements. 

Drugs and other factors that may increase levothyroxine dosage requirements:

  • Impaired levothyroxine absorption
    • Aluminum-containing antacids
    • Proton pump inhibitors
    • Sucralfate
    • Bile acid sequestrants (cholestyramine, colestipol, colesevelam)
    • Calcium carbonate (effect generally small)
    • Phosphate binders (lanthanum carbonate, sevelamer)
  • Increased thyroxine metabolism, CYP3A4 induction
    • Rifampin
    • Carbamazepine
    • Phenytoin
    • Sertraline
  • Impaired T4 → T3 conversion
    • Amiodarone
  • Mechanisms uncertain or multifactorial
    • Estrogen
    • Pregnancy
    • Lovastatin & simvastatin

Drugs and other factors that may decrease levothyroxine dosage requirements:

  • Advancing age (>65 years)
  • Androgen therapy in women

Drugs that may decrease TSH without changing free T4 in levothyroxine-treated patients: Metformin

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman with breast cancer presents with a rash on her hand as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Gottron papules on the hand. With a history of breast cancer, the most likely diagnosis in this patient is dermatomyositis.

The classic cutaneous signs in dermatomyositis include:

  • Eyelid erythema and edema - heliotrope rash
  • Gottron’s papules
  • V-sign
  • Shawl sign
  • Nail bed changes with dilated capillaries

The aboce image shows characteristic upper eyelid lilac erythema or heliotrope rash, which is pathognomonic of dermatomyositis.

The above image shows a macular rash on the anterior chest in dermatomyositis, known as V-sign.

  • Anti-Mi2 antibodies (directed against a helicase implicated in nucleosome remodeling) show a strong association with prominent Gottron papules and heliotrope rash.
  • Anti-Jo1 antibodies (directed against the enzyme histidyl t-RNA synthetase) are associated with interstitial lung disease, nonerosive arthritis, and a skin rash described as “mechanic’s hands.”

questions.text: The results of a meta-analysis of studies comparing a novel drug for diabetes to a reference drug are given below. Which of the following conclusions can be drawn from it?

choices.text: Study E has the lowest sample size.
Studies A and C are statistically significant.
The novel drug is better than the reference drug.
Studies D and E cross the line of no effect.

questions.solution:
The image shown is that of a forest plot. It is used for plotting the results of a meta-analysis. Since the diamond at the bottom, which represents the overall pooled results of all the studies, corresponds to a risk ratio of 2.2, it indicates that the novel drug is better than the reference drug.

In the plot for each study, the size of the rectangle represents the sample size. In this case, study 'E' has the largest sample size (option A). The horizontal line on either side of the rectangle represents the 95% confidence interval for that study.

The solid vertical line that corresponds to the odds ratio of 1 is called the line of no effect. It indicates that there is no significant difference between the reference and the novel drug. Any study line that crosses the line of no effect becomes an insignificant study. So studies A, B, and C are statistically insignificant (option B).

The dotted vertical line in the center represents the aggregate risk ratio and is not the line of no effect. Studies D and E do not cross the line of no effect (option D).

Related Pearl: Forest Plot

  • A forest plot is used to present the results of a meta-analysis.
  • It is also called blobbogram.

Interpretation of forest plots: 

  • The rectangles represent the single studies
  • The size of the rectangle is proportional to the sample size
  • The horizontal line on either side - confidence interval, the longer the lines, the wider the confidential interval, the less reliable the study results
  • The vertical solid line - the “line of no effect", which represents the odds ratio or relative risk. If it is the odds ratio, then the vertical line would be at 1. No difference between the intervention and the placebo (i.e., a risk ratio of 1). 
  • The location of the result - whether it favours the intervention (the statin drug) or not
  • A diamond shows the overall pooled result where all the individual studies are combined together and averaged
  • Lateral corners of the diamond represent the confidence interval, if these corners do not cross 'the line of no effect', then there is an overall statistically significant effect. If the diamond touches the vertical line, the overall result is not statistically significant.
  • The vertical dashed line represents the overall pooled estimate which represents the meta-analysed measure of effect.

Let's understand with an example - 

  • For study A- it has a wide horizontal line that crosses the line of null effect with a black box that is to the right of the vertical line. This most likely demonstrates a small scale study with few participants where the point estimate result favours the control used in the study. But because the study contains the null value in its 95% confidence interval, it is likely to have a p-value >0.05 and not be statistically significant.
  • For study B- it has quite a narrow line that does not cross the line of null effect with a black box that is to the left of the vertical line and is bigger than study A. This most likely demonstrates a larger study with more participants compared to study A, where the result favours the intervention used. Because the 95% confidence interval does not contain the null value, this study is likely to have a p-value <0.05 and hence the differences observed in the study can be regarded as statistically significant.

questions.text: The etiopathogenesis of which of the following conditions does not depend predominantly upon the production of mycotoxins?
questions.solution:
In ABPA, inhalation of Aspergillus fumigatus spores provokes a type I and/or type III hypersensitivity reaction and is not associated with the production of mycotoxins. Fungal presence is required for its pathogenesis though no tissue invasion occurs.

Mycotoxicoses are diseases caused by toxic secondary metabolites known as mycotoxins. Fungal toxins contaminate food and cause toxic effects. These diseases do not require fungal infection or invasion of tissue by the fungus.

Examples:

  • Aflatoxins are produced by Aspergillus species of fungi, such as A. flavus in contaminated groundnuts, corn, and peas.
  • Ergot alkaloids produced by Claviceps purpurea in contaminated rye
  • Fusarium toxins

Decreases from wakefulness

Increases (up to 30 percent) and varies from NREM

Decreases from wakefulness

Increases significantly from wakefulness

Similar to wakefulness

Absent

Blood flow to brain

Decreases from wakefulness

Increases from NREM, depending on brain region

Decreases from wakefulness

Increases and  varies from NREM, but may show brief stoppages; coughing suppressed

Airway resistance

Increases from wakefulness

Increases and  varies from wakefulness

Body temperature

Is regulated at lower set point than wakefulness; shivering initiated at lower temperature than during wakefulness

Is not regulated; no shivering or sweating; temperature drifts toward that of the local environment

Sexual arousal

Occurs infrequently

Greater than NREM

Related Pearl: Stages of Arousal and Sleep

Stage

Behaviour

EEG

Alert wakefulness

Awake, alert with eyes open

Beta rhythm(14-30 Hz)

Relaxed wakefulness

Awake, relaxed with eyes closed
  • Mainly alpha rhythm (8–13 Hz)
  • Changes to the beta rhythm in response to internal or external stimuli.

Relaxed drowsiness
  • Fatigued and tired
  • The head droops, momentary lapses of attention
  • Sleepy but not asleep

Decrease in alpha-wave amplitude and frequency

NREM 1 (N1) (5%)
  • Light sleep-easily aroused by moderate stimuli or even by muscle jerks
  • Continuous lack of awareness
  • Mixed frequency waves  (predominantly 2-7 Hz).
  • Gap in alpha rhythm is filled with theta (4–8 Hz) and delta (slower than 4 Hz) activity
  • Vertex waves

NREM 2 (N2) (50-60%)

Further lack of sensitivity to activation and arousal
  • Predominant theta activity (4-7 Hz)
  • K-complex and sleep spindles occur periodically

NREM 3 and 4 (N3) (15-20%)
  • Deep sleep
  • Arousal only with vigorous stimuli
  • Sleep-arousal most difficult

Delta>theta activity

REM (paradoxical) sleep (20-25%)
  • 50–90 min after sleep onset, episodes repeated every 60–90 min, each episode lasting about 10 min
  • Dreaming occurs, rapid eye movements, increase in brain O2 consumption
  • EEG resembles that of alert awake state.
  • Saw tooth waves

Note: According to the new classification, stage 3 and 4 of NREM are grouped together as N3. So as per recent staging NREM has 3 stages (N1, N2, N3)

questions.text: A female patient comes to the OPD with complaints of  passage of blood instead of urine at night. She is found to have a mutation of the PIGA gene. Her lab investigations include a Ham test. What does this test detect?

choices.text: Lysis of RBCS in alkaline pH
Lysis of RBCs in a mildly acidic pH

questions.solution:
The given history of passage of blood instead of urine at night and mutation of the PIGA gene points towards a likely diagnosis of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). Ham test or acidified serum lysis test detects lysis of RBCs in a mildly acidic pH due to complement fixation. 

PNH is a chronic acquired hemolytic anemia that occurs due to mutations in the phosphatidylinositol glycan complementation group A (PIGA) gene. PIGA is an enzyme that is essential for the synthesis of certain membrane-associated complement regulatory proteins.

Thus, PNH blood cells are deficient in three glycosylphosphatidylinositols (GPI) linked proteins that regulate complement activity:

  • Decay accelerating factors or CD55
  • Membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis or CD59
  • C8 binding protein

Clinically, the patient would have hemolysis, pancytopenia, and a tendency for venous thrombosis. Intravascular hemolysis may be nocturnal and paroxysmal or chronic hemolysis without the dramatic hemoglobinuria. Some patients may complain of recurrent attacks of abdominal pain that may be related to thrombosis in abdominal veins. Investigations show iron deficiency anemia (due to chronic hemoglobinuria), and elevated LDH levels (Option A).

The gold standard for the diagnosis of PNH is flow cytometry. It provides a sensitive means for detecting red cells that are deficient in GPI-linked proteins such as CD59.

Investigations in PNH include:

  • Flow cytometry (gold standard) - deficiency of CD59 and CD55
  • Ham test (acidified serum lysis) - lysis of RBCs in a mildly acidic pH due to complement fixation
  • Bone marrow biopsy -
    • Hypercellularity with erythroid hyperplasia is seen in classical presentations
    • Patients who develop pancytopenia will have hypocellular bone marrow
  • Imaging - to evaluate venous thrombosis 

Eculizumab is used in treatment. It is a monoclonal antibody that prevents the conversion of the complement C5 to C5a.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of breathlessness on lying down and chest pain. He was diagnosed to have congestive cardiac failure and was administered torsemide. This drug inhibits which of the following type of transport mechanism?
questions.solution:
Torsemide is a loop diuretic that inhibits Na+ K+ 2Cl- co-transporter on the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. This is an example of secondary active transport.

Transporting more than one substance together using a single transport protein against the gradient is known as secondary active transport. As one of the substances (e.g., sodium) diffuses down its electrochemical gradient, energy is released, which is used to drive another substance (e.g., glucose) against the gradient. Thus, secondary active transport does not require energy directly from ATP.

Examples of secondary active transport

Counter-transport/exchanger

  • Na+ Ca+ exchanger
  • Na+ H+ exchanger
  • H+ K+ exchanger

Co-transporters/symporter

  • Na+ Glucose co-transporter
  • Na+ K+ 2Cl- co-transporter

Related Pearl: Characteristics of different types of transport

Type Simple diffusion Facilitated diffusion Primary active transport Secondary active transport Cotransport Secondary active transport Countertransport
Electrochemical gradient Downhill Downhill Uphill Uphill Uphill
Carrier mediated No Yes Yes Yes Yes
Metabolic energy No No Yes Indirect Indirect
Na+ gradient No No -- Yes (same direction) Yes (opposite direction)

Inhibits Na+-K+ pump

 		 -- -- Inhibits Inhibits  Inhibits
