questions.text: A patient with fatigue was found to have hepatomegaly on examination. The JVP waveform is given below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given JVP waveform shows the presence of C-V waves — the merging of the C and V waves of JVP, without proper x descent. This is a feature of tricuspid regurgitation.

Other physical findings that may be seen in tricuspid regurgitation include hepatomegaly with systolic pulsations, peripheral edema, and positive hepatojugular reflux. All these findings are due to the volume overload on the right side of the heart. 

A prominent RV pulsation in the left parasternal may be seen, along with a holosystolic murmur on the lower left sternal margin.

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text:
During your labor room postings, you perform a cardiotocography (CTG) on a woman who is in labor at 38 weeks of gestation. The tracing that you obtain is as shown in the image below. Which among the following may cause this finding?
  1. Placental abruption
  2. Excessive use of oxytocin
  3. Epidural anesthesia
  4. Fetal head compression
  5. Umbilical cord compression
questions.solution:
The given CTG shows late decelerations. The fetal heart rate begins to drop after the end of uterine contraction. It is mostly associated with uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia.

Causes of late decelerations:

  • Placental pathologies like - post-maturity, hypertension, diabetes, placental abruption
  • Excessive uterine contractions
  • Excessive use of oxytocin
  • Epidural anesthesia

The CTG given below shows early decelerations. The deceleration coincides with the uterine contractions. It seen in fetal head compression.

The CTG given below shows variable decelerations as seen in umbilical cord compression.

The CTG given below shows a sinusoidal pattern. It resembles a sine wave. It is often associated with fetal anemia, fetomaternal hemorrhage, and fetal acidosis.

Related Pearl: Deceleration patterns on cardiotocography (CTG)

Early deceleration: seen in head compression

 

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia

 

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression

questions.text: All of the following lesions appear hyperintense on T1 except
questions.solution:
Destructive multiple sclerosis lesions appear hypointense on T1-weighted images.

Lesions that hyperintense on T1 weighted MR images are

  1. Gadolinium-based contrast agents
  2. Hemoglobin degradation products (intra- and extra-cellular methemoglobin)
  3. Lipid-containing lesions (lipoma, dermoid cyst, implanted fatty materials, laminar cortical necrosis)
  4. Substances with high concentrations of proteins (colloid cyst, craniopharyngioma, Rathke’s cleft cyst, ectopic posterior pituitary gland)
  5. Melanin (metastatic melanoma)
  6. Lesions containing mineral substances such as calcium (calcifications, Fahr’s disease), copper (Wilson’s disease), and manganese (hepatic encephalopathy, manganese intoxication in intravenous drug abusers).

Related Pearl: T1 vs T2 MRI

questions.text: A 27-year-old male patient presents with a history of urethral discharge for the last four days. A gram stain smear of the discharge is shown in the image given below. Which of the following transport media can be used for the causative organism?
questions.solution:
History of urethral discharge along with the image showing gram-negative diplococci within the polymorphs is characteristic of Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection. Stuart’s medium is the transport media used for Neisseria.

Gonorrhea is a sexually transmitted disease caused by N. gonorrhoeae. The major symptoms include urethritis, vaginal discharge, dyspareunia, and dysuria. In the laboratory diagnosis of N. gonorrhea, the discharge on Gram's stain reveals gram‐negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes. It acidifies glucose but not maltose in serum sugars. Stuart's medium is used for transport while Thayer-Martin agar is used as a selective medium used to isolate N. gonorrhoeae. Cultures can be obtained from chocolate agar or Mueller-Hinton agar. 

Stuart’s medium is the transport media used for Neisseria gonorrhea and Neisseria meningitides. It is a semisolid, non-nutrient medium. Charcoal present in the medium neutralizes certain bacterial inhibitors while a reducing agent prevents oxidation.

Other options:

Option A: Cary-Blair medium is a buffered solution of sodium chloride, sodium thioglycollate, disodium phosphate, and calcium chloride at a pH of 8.4. It is a suitable transport medium for Salmonella, Shigella, and Vibrios.

Option B: Pike's medium (Option B) is a blood agar containing 1 in 1,000,000 crystal violet and 1 in 16,000 sodium azide. It is used as transport media for Streptococcus.

Option D: Autoclaved seawater serves as a holding medium for Vibrio cholerae. 

Related Pearl: Organisms and their transport media

Organism Transport media
Streptococcus Pike’s media
Neisseria Stuart media
Shigella, Salmonella Cary Blair medium
Vibrio cholera

Cary Blair medium

Venkatraman–Ramakrishnan medium

Autoclaved sea water

questions.text: A patient with celiac disease presents with peripheral neuropathy and decreased vibration and position sense. Investigations show hemolytic anemia and normal methylmalonic acid levels. Which of the following is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has chronic malabsorption due to celiac disease, and has now presented with peripheral neuropathy and posterior column involvement (loss of vibration and position sense). The presence of hemolytic anemia along with these features points to a diagnosis of vitamin E deficiency.

Vitamin E (α-tocopherol) acts as an antioxidant by scavenging free radicles. It is a fat-soluble vitamin, and so the deficiency is only seen in patients with prolonged malabsorption, such as celiac disease and chronic cholestatic liver disease. Children with abetalipoproteinemia cannot absorb vitamin E and also show symptoms of deficiency. 

Deficiency of vitamin E causes axonal degeneration of myelinated neurons, causing posterior column and spinocerebellar involvement. Patients can have peripheral neuropathy, ataxia, and loss of vibration and position sense. Along with this, there is hemolytic anemia because of unchecked lipid peroxidation of the RBC membrane in the absence of the antioxidant effects of vitamin E.

Vitamin B12 deficiency (option C) can also present with involvement of the posterior column, but the following features differentiate it from vitamin E deficiency:

  Vitamin E deficiency Vitamin B12 deficiency
Anemia Hemolytic anemia Megaloblastic anemia
Peripheral smear Acanthocytes Macroovalocytes with hypersegmented neutrophils
Serum methylmalonic acid levels Normal Elevated

Other options:

Option A: Pyridoxine deficiency presents with epithelial changes such as cheilitis, along with peripheral neuropathy, personality changes, and depression. There is no involvement of the posterior column tracts. Pyridoxine deficiency can cause microcytic hypochromic anemia due to diminished hemoglobin synthesis, since the aminolevulinate synthase enzyme in heme synthesis is PLP dependent. 

Option B: Folate deficiency presents with megaloblastic anemia without neurological symptoms. There is an elevation of serum homocysteine levels but methylmalonic acid levels are normal, versus vitamin B12 deficiency, where both are elevated.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes degrade the triglycerides present in the chylomicrons coming from the intestine?
questions.solution:
Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) degrades the triglycerides (TGs) present in the chylomicrons.

LPL is an extracellular enzyme, present in the walls of the capillaries. Although it is present in most tissues, it is predominantly seen in adipose tissue, skeletal and cardiac muscles. It is activated by the apo CII present on the chylomicrons, hydrolyzing the TGs into free fatty acids and glycerol. The fatty acids are either stored in adipose tissues, or used for energy requirements of the muscles. 

LPL synthesis in various tissues is dependent on the nutritional status. In fed state, the insulin levels are high and LPL synthesis is favored in the adipose tissues. In fasting state, LPL synthesis is increased in the muscles. 

When most of the TGs in the chylomicron are metabolized, what remains is the chylomicron remnant. The remnants are removed from the circulation by the liver. Hepatic uptake is mediated by apo E present on the chylomicron remnant. 

Other options:

Option A: Pancreatic lipase degrades the dietary TGs in the small intestine.

Option C: Hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) is responsible for degrading TGs in the adipose tissues. When glucagon levels are high, there is an increased release of free fatty acids from the adipose tissues, and the glycerol released along with them is used for gluconeogenesis.

Option D: Hepatic lipase breaks down TGs present in HDL2, converting it to HDL3. It is also involved in degrading TGs in VLDL and chylomicron remnant.

Related Pearl: Hormone sensitive lipase Vs lipoprotein lipase

   HSL  Lipoprotein lipase
Location  Adipocyte  Capillaries
Action  Hydrolyse TAG in adipose   tissue  Hydrolyse TAG in chylomicron , VLDL
Acts in the state of  Fasting (Glucagon)  Fed (Insulin)

questions.text: Binocular vision is well established in a child by______
questions.solution:
Binocular vision is well established in a child by 4 months.

Shortly after birth, a baby is capable of fixing their gaze and tracking the movements of a person or a dangling ring held approximately 8-10 inches away within a range of 45°. This range expands to 90° by the age of 4 weeks and further extends to 180° by 12 weeks. Around 1 month of age, the baby can focus on their mother's face while she engages in conversation. Around 3-4 months, the child demonstrates intense fixation on objects presented to them, almost as if they are attempting to reach for those objects with their eyes.

Binocular vision, the ability to use both eyes together, begins at approximately 6 weeks and becomes well-established by 4 months. By 6 months, the child starts adjusting their position to keep track of objects of interest, and by 1 year, they can follow rapidly moving objects. As the child grows, their visual abilities further develop, allowing them to not only identify smaller objects but also recognize them, demonstrating increasing visual maturity.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man who frequently travels barefoot is suspected to have acquired a parasitic infection via skin penetration. Any of the following parasites may be implicated in this case except?
questions.solution:
The mode of infection of Ancylostoma, Strongyloides, and Schistosoma is by the penetration of the skin. Ingestion of eggs containing rhabditiform larva is the mode of infection in Ascaris. 

Ascaris lumbricoides is an intestinal nematode that causes ascariasis. Infection occurs through food or water contaminated with nightsoil or human feces having eggs of Ascaris. These eggs contain the infective rhabditiform larva. 

Options B: Ancylostoma duodenale (Old World hookworm) and Necator americanus (New World hookworm) the infective third-stage filariform larva can penetrate the skin and enter the subcutaneous tissue. Severe itching caused at the site of penetration is known as ground itch and migration of the larvae in the subcutaneous tissue is known as creeping eruptions.

Options C: The third stage filariform larva is the infective form of Strongyloides stercoralis. These larvae can penetrate the skin and enter the circulation.

Option D: Schistosoma haematobium, S. mansoni, and S.japonicum are blood flukes that live in venous plexuses. The infective form in these organisms is the fork-tailed cercariae. These cercariae have suckers and secrete lytic substances that help penetrate intact skin. Following the penetration, intense irritation and skin rash develops at the site and is known as swimmer's itch or cercarial dermatitis.

questions.text: A 43-year-old lady presents to the OPD with complaints of pain in her left hand. On examination, there is swelling and tenderness over the radial styloid. The test shown in the image was performed and it results in acute pain. Identify the test and the condition involved.
questions.solution:
The test shown in the image is Eichhoff's test. Pain on performing the test points to the diagnosis of De-Quervain's tenosynovitis.

To perform Eichhoff's test, the individual is instructed to place her thumb inside their hand and make a firm grip by closing the other fingers. The examiner would then gently move the hand towards the ulnar side (away from the midline) in an outward direction. If sharp pain occurs along the distal radius, De Quervain's tenosynovitis is suspected.

De Quervain's disease is a stenosing tenosynovitis of the extensor tendons of the first dorsal compartment, namely extensor pollicis brevis (marked as A) and abductor pollicis longus (marked as B). It is prominent among females, especially women of childbearing age.

Clinical features of De Quervain's disease include visible swelling over the radial styloid, palpable thickening of the tendon sheath, tenderness at the tip of the radial styloid, and pain on resisted thumb extension (hitch-hiker’s sign).

To perform Finkelstein's test, the examiner securely holds the patient's hand with the (patient's) thumb tucked into their (examiner's) palm. The examiner proceeds to rotate the patient's wrist fully towards the ulnar side (ulnar deviation). If the test result is positive, this maneuver will cause sharp pain in the affected sheath.

Treatment:

  • The majority of the patients are treated conservatively with steroid injection and splinting.
  • Few require surgical release of the 1st dorsal compartment (housing the APL and EPB tendons).

Dupuytren's contracture is a condition characterized by the flexion deformity of one or more fingers. It occurs due to the thickening and shortening of the palmar aponeurosis. Specifically, the affected aponeurosis, or a portion of it becomes thicker and gradually contracts, causing the fingers to bend inward at the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints. The ring finger is commonly the most affected, and the contracture usually involves the middle three fingers.

The exact cause of Dupuytren's contracture is unknown, although there is evidence of a hereditary predisposition. It has been observed to be more prevalent in individuals with liver cirrhosis and in those taking sodium hydantoin medication for epilepsy.

Clinical features of the condition include nodular thickening in the palm or finger. Initially, the nodules are painless, but they may later become slightly tender. Typically, both hands are involved. Over time, the nodules may thicken and form cords, and if these cords extend into the fingers, they can cause flexion deformities at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and PIP joints.

In elderly patients with mild contracture, treatment may not be necessary. However, if the deformity is significant and interferes with the patient's daily activities, surgical excision of the affected palmar aponeurosis (subtotal excision) may be required.

questions.text: Imatinib is the drug acting on the receptor shown in the image below. For which of the following diseases is this drug indicated?
questions.solution:
Imatinib is indicated for the treatment of chronic myeloid leukemia.

Imatinib belongs to the class of tyrosine kinase inhibitors, which are the first-line drugs indicated for the treatment of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). It is also used to treat other conditions:

  • Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST)
  • Philadelphia chromosome-positive acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL)
  • Hypereosinophilia syndrome
  • Adult myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative diseases
  • Systemic mastocytosis

Classification of BCR-ABL kinase/tyrosine kinase inhibitors: 

  • First-generation: Most likely to be associated with resistance
    • Imatinib 
  • Second-generation: Active against imatinib-resistant CML cases, but not those with T315I mutation 
    • Nilotinib
    • Dasatinib 
    • Bosutinib 
  • Third-generation: Active against T315I-mutant CML cases and other known mutant cases. 
    • Ponatinib

Adverse effects of these drugs include GI symptoms (diarrhea, nausea, vomiting), edema, and hepatotoxicity. Nilotinib and dasatinib might prolong the QT interval.

 

Related Pearl: Indications for Imatinib

BCR-ABL kinase mutations

  • Chronic myelogenous leukaemia (CML)
  • Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL)

C-KIT mutations

  • Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST)

PDGFR mutations

  • Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans
  • Hypereosinophilia syndrome
  • Chronic myelomonocytic leukaemia (CML)

questions.text: Which of the following would you not recommend in the treatment of CKD?
questions.solution:
CKD itself leads to a reduction in potassium excretion, causing its buildup. Thus, potassium supplementation is not recommended in a patient with CKD.

The measures used in the management of CKD and its associated complications include:

  • Antihypertensive therapy slows the progression of CKD, irrespective of the drug that is used. However, the use of ACE inhibitors and ARBs for this purpose has the added benefit of reducing proteinuria. Reduction in proteinuria also reduces the risk of progression.
  • Patients should be advised to limit their potassium intake by reducing foods with high potassium such as bananas. Potassium-binding resins such as patiromer can also be used.
  • Sodium bicarbonate supplementation may be indicated in patients who have chronic high-anion gap metabolic acidosis.
  • Active vitamin D metabolites such as calcitriol should be given to patients with renal bone disease.
  • Hyperphosphatemia is treated with restriction of high phosphate foods such as milk and eggs, and with phosphate binders such as lanthanum and sevelamer.
  • Anemia associated with CKD is treated with darbepoetin after replenishing the iron, folic acid, and vitamin B12 stores of the body.

questions.text: Certain organisms can produce structured microcolonies that are enclosed in a self-produced glycocalyx matrix. This is visible as a slimy coat over solid surfaces. Which of the following statement is false about this?

choices.text: Exopolysaccharide matrix may act as a diffusion barrier for antimicrobials
Bacteria that form biofilms are usually metabolically more active
Can be seen in Staphylococcus epidermidis, Viridans streptococci and Pseudomonas aeruginosa

questions.solution:
Biofilms are structured microcolonies of organisms that are enclosed in a self-produced glycocalyx matrix. Bacteria within biofilms are usually metabolically less active.

Biofilms are aggregates of bacteria that are enclosed in an exopolysaccharide matrix that is produced by there bacteria itself. The biofilms are attached to solid surfaces and form a slimy layer over them. Organisms that produce biofilm include (Option C):

  • Staphylococcus epidermidis on medical devices and implants
  • Streptococcus viridians on heart valves
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa lung infections
  • Staphylococcus aureus on catheters
  • Legionella pneumophila colonization of hospital water systems

The exopolysaccharide helps in protection against the host's immunity. It acts diffusion barrier for antimicrobials (Option A) and makes the organism relatively insusceptible to drug action. Bacteria embedded in biofilms frequently become metabolically less active or dormant (Option B). It is thus harder to eradicate these organisms with antibiotics.

These bacteria within biofilms also produce small molecules, such as homoserine lactones. These molecules are taken up by adjacent bacteria and function as a communication system called Quorum Sensing (Option D) and help turn on certain genes at a particular time.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes transcortical sensory aphasia?

choices.text: Comprehension impaired, repetition impaired, speech fluency normal
Comprehension impaired, repetition impaired, speech fluency increased
Comprehension impaired, repetition normal, speech fluency normal
Comprehension normal, repetition normal, speech fluency decreased

questions.solution:
Transcortical sensory (posterior) aphasia is characterized by impaired comprehension, normal repetition of spoken language, and preserved speech fluency.

Related Pearl: Aphasias and Related Conditions

  Comprehension Repetition of Spoken language Naming Fluency
Wernicke's Impaired Impaired Impaired Preserved
Broca's Preserved Impaired Impaired Decreased
Global Impaired Impaired Impaired Decreased
Conduction Preserved Impaired Impaired Preserved
Anterior (nonfluent) transcortical Preserved Preserved Impaired Impaired
Posterior (fluent) transcortical Impaired Preserved Impaired Preserved
Isolation Impaired Echolalia Impaired No purposeful speech
Anomic Preserved Preserved Impaired Preserved except for word finding pauses
Pure Word Deafness Impaired only for spoken language Impaired Preserved Preserved
Pure Alexia Impaired only for reading Preserved Preserved  Preserved
